Black Portraiture[s] II: Revisited. Imaging the Black Body and Re-staging Histories - Conference at NYUÂ 
Saturday, February 19-20, 2016Â 
Kimmel Center for University Life | Grand Hall, 60 Washington Square South. NYU
Admission: FREEÂ 

This two-day event reconstructs a selection of panels from the most recent conference in the series held at Villa La Pietra in Florence, Italy here at New York University’s Washington Square campus. Â 

Black Portraiture[s] II: Imaging the Black Body and Re-staging Histories, explored the impulses, ideas, and techniques undergirding the production of self-representation and desire, and the exchange of the gaze from the 19th century to the present day in fashion, film, art, and the archives. Thus, the seventh conference will revisit that amazing experience that attracted over 800 attendees â€“ an occasion that brought together artists and scholars from an assortment of disciplines and practices and offered comparative perspectives on the historical and contemporary role played by photography, art, film, literature, and music in referencing the image of the black body in the West.

Discussions will focus on aesthetics, style, history, and music in describing a sense of place and identity. The conference will also invite visitors to conduct a diverse visual reading of the notion of a black portrait while challenging conventional perspectives on identity, beauty, cosmopolitanism, and community in Africa and its diaspora. Â We hope you will join us in New York City!

Organized by NYU Tisch Office of the Dean, Allyson Green, in celebration of the 50th anniversary of the founding of the School of the Arts at NYU along with Awam Amkpa (Social and Cultural Analysis; NYU), Ulrich Baer (Vice Provost for Faculty, Arts, Humanities, and Diversity; NYU), Manthia Diawara (Institute of African American Affairs; NYU), Henry Louis Gates, Jr. (Hutchins Center for African and American Research; Harvard), Thelma Golden (Studio Museum in Harlem), Robert Holmes, J.D. (NYU Alumnus), Ellyn Toscano (Villa La Pietra; NYU) and Deborah Willis (Department of Photography & Imaging; NYU).

For our very first post we had the honor of talking to, Sue Ann Kwan, president of HKSA NYUÂ (Hong Kong Students Association). Sue Ann is currently a senior in CAS majoring in Economics. When asked if she has anything to share with everyone, she said:

I want everyone to read this Generasian article.

Right on Sue Ann, now letâ€™s get started!

Tell us about HKSAâ€™s vision:

Our vision, wow. Let me thinkâ€¦ Well, Hong Kong has a very weird identity and being a student overseas its sometimes difficult to understand our origin. HKSA is to remind them, remind us, about our origins. (Beautifully said)

What is your favorite thing about HKSA?

The people (AWHHH). The stupidity of the people (awh?)â€¦ I like how we always treat each other as familyâ€¦ and of course the food.

Weâ€™ve all heard of book drives, and maybe youâ€™ve even dusted off a few of your old books and contributed. But what happens when you use design thinking to integrate technology with book distribution to underserved children?

In 2007, Hediya Sizar (NYU Steinhardt â€˜2017) and her brother Sohale Sizar founded the Bring on the Books Foundation, a non-profit literacy organization that redistributes gently-used books to low-income neighborhoods in the New York City area. It began as a local book drive at a suburban high school, encouraging high schoolers to reroute their books to low-income schools in Philadelphia. Â Since its humble origins, the initiative has grown into an impactful nonprofit organization, collecting over 70,000 books at high school and college campuses across multiple states. With its adaptive nature, the organization has begun integrating technology to take the program to the next level. Now run through a cloud-based app platform, Bring on the Books directly connects donors to donation sites at their nearest location.

Hediyaâ€™s dedication to closing the access-to-books gap is deeply personal. At the age of nine, her parents relocated from her small town in Pennsylvania to South Korea. She recalls that, Â â€œMy brother and I were the only international students in my new school. There were many language and cultural barriers, making it difficult to interact with my peers, so I found my sanctuary in books.â€ Hediya found Laura Ingalls Wilderâ€™s Little House on the Prairie especially poignant because this 19th century pioneer family maintained positivity and strength throughout unimaginable hardship. Hediya notes, â€œtheir story encouraged me to appreciate my experience in South Korea. The charactersâ€™ resilience helped me work across differences and learn different perspectives, encouraging me to make friends with my peers in Korea.â€

Hediya knows first-hand that the stories found within the pages of books can build across differences. Scaling this vision into a nonprofit organization required taking stock of her own values and how to turn those into a tangible mission.

Hediyaâ€™s transformative experience as an NYU Leadership Fellow in (Class of 2014-2015) helped her on her journey to becoming a successful leader at Bring on the Books. The highlight of her fellowship was working on a group team challenge. Hediya reflects, â€œWe created a social media campaign and event called #ImNotPerfect, which celebrated our flaws as leaders and encouraged students to be open about vulnerabilities. During the creation of this project, I learned the importance of teamwork and I developed lasting relationships with my team. They are now some of my closest friends!â€

As an NYU Leadership Fellow, Hediya worked one-one-one with a coach to create an individual development plan. Hediya expands that â€œThis helped me learn about myself as a leader and person in life. If it wasnâ€™t for the Fellows Program, I wouldnâ€™t be able to create measurable and effective goals to work on my strengths and areas of growth.â€

She also cites meditation and mindfulness as practices that shape her leadership style. In fact, she participates weekly in Generation Meditation sessions at Global Spiritual Life. She explains, â€œI incorporate mindfulness with leadership by engaging in empathetic listening, practicing more self-awareness, and learning how to stay focused in the present moment. This has helped create stronger clarity of my vision and be a better team player.â€ Hediya continues to hone her leadership skills around campus. She serves as a Program Assistant at the NYU Leadership Initiative, helping to grow and facilitate the same fellowship program that enhanced her own leadership skills.

And as Â a Media, Culture, and Communication major in Steinhardt, Hediya utilizes the many resources available to her at NYU to scale up Bring on the Books from the frequent donation model to a technology-driven crowdsourcing platform. In her own words she say says:

â€œI wanted to build a love for literacy that would bring youth together. I wanted to share the beauty of stories. I wanted adolescents to know that they are not alone in this world, but rather there are characters who share the same emotions and experiences as them. I pursued my vision through a full time commitment to Bring on the Books.â€

If you have any books lying around, reroute them Â at the â€œBring on the Booksâ€ Drive happening now during Violet 100 Week (Feb. 22nd-26th). Drop off all books in the Kimmel Center, 7th Floor!

If you would like to nominate an individual, pair or group of students to be featured in our #LeadershipSpotlight series, simply email leadershipinitiative@nyu.edu with a name and email as well as two to three sentences about how your nominee(s) is practicing ethical, collaborative, and inclusive leadership!

We’ve all been there. Maybe your parents want to see how their little angel and the love of their life is doing at college, or your friend from high school wants to see what the City is like. While itâ€™s always great to catch up, you can’t just hang out in your room, watch Netflix, and go to Third North for lunch. Sometimes itâ€™s tough to plan the day outside of what youâ€™ll have for food, so if youâ€™re struggling for ideas, hereâ€™s our first itinerary that will be sure to show off your urban home to parents and best friends alike.

Not only do your visitors want to see Bobst, Kimmel, and Washington Square Park, they want to see the City through your eyes. So, start with Washington Square Park area and show them the cool academic buildings, as well as some of the awesome food vendors between campus and 6th Avenue. From there, you can work your way west.

The West Village is where it gets cool no matter how old you are. Kitschy little stores, cool coffee shops, and picturesque streets full of quaint little townhouses. Stop byÂ Magnolia Bakery, or the Whitney Museum of Art (which is free for NYU students and a guest btw!) before continuing your journey.

Who doesnâ€™t love urban revival? As you work your way up and around the different quirks and areas of the Highline, there are tons of spots to take a picture and enjoy the view.

But what’s this? Two food markets? Food markets are a spectacular place to walk around, sample things from multiple vendors, or sit down for a larger, delicious meal. The tacos and Num Pang are great at Chelsea Market, and thereâ€™s no clear winner at Gansevoort Market, as everything is equally spectacular.

From there, you can continue up the Highline to Hudson Yards (Catch the 7 train, which leads into midtown) or walk along 23rd Street to the Flatiron Building and Madison Square Park. The park holds Shake Shackâ€™s first location, and the line is worth the wait. Weâ€™re working on more route suggestions, so stay tuned!

“It may seem like we’re just going out for free bagels, but we’re really doing much more. The simple joy of getting together with people, for even something as mundane as bagels in this world class city, cannot be stressed enough. To put it frankly, as a faculty fellow in resident at Palladium, you [Rich] inspire that in nearly everyone. Getting Bagels with people is like a celebration of life. There aren’t any deadlines or expectations, no academia or statuses, just sharing our lives with each other.

That’s probably one of the most important things you can do at a school like NYU. Everyone gets so busy to the point life becomes stratified and to itself. It’s like we’ve forgotten how to have genuine fun with one another. Events like this help keep us human.”

Palladium Resident
Bryan Oliveira

With some help from How to Get Away with Murderâ€™s Professor Annalise Keating!

1. Why are you considering law school?

Make sure you want to go to law school for the right reasons. Law school is tough! If you are not truly invested in the material, it is likely that the workload will overwhelm you.

2. What do you plan to do after law school?

This is extremely important to think about when considering law school. Where you go to school will impact what and where you practice. Do your research!

3. Are you planning on taking time off between college and law school?

You donâ€™t have to go to law school as soon as you graduate college. Some people prefer taking some time off to work or travel in order gain perspective. Taking this time may help you decide if this is truly what you want to do.

4. Are you okay with the schedule?

Law school puts even more pressure on the student than college. Your performance is predominantly measured by your final grade and your score on The Bar Exam, so it is very important to manage your time and stay on top of the material.

Want more insight and information on law school? Come to Law School 101 on Tues 2/23 at 6:30pm!

I believe that marketing strategy is a wonderful tool for great ideas to be realized, and digital marketing is an essential way to engage with customers.

Before coming to study at NYU, I have 2 year of work experience at JPMorgan Taiwan as foreign exchange sales; all my work life was about numbers, rate, and revenue, for clients and company. It was a great job that I learned to pick up things really quick and respond to market and clientâ€™s request timely and accurately, and I got the chance to work with people from different trading rooms in different branches around the world. Jut that I still fell like some things is missing: every deal is coming and done so fast that I don’t even have time to think about it, to plan it and put my thought in it, everything is according to foreign exchange market. At the mean time, I looked at some of my friends who work in marketing role in marketing-driven companies such as Lâ€™Oreal or Pepsi Co, their life is pretty different; they plan for marketing campaigns, promotions, and events. They are trained to have fresh eye on the market trend, and use different tools and approaches to catch customer needs and cerate opportunities. This sounds more like a job I can do and enjoy for a long time, so I decided to leave JPMorgan and applied for master in marketing program in states, trying to change my career path.

After one semester here, though those basic marketing classes, internship experience and some events such as advertising week and marketing mix in NYU Stern, Iâ€™ve learned so much about digital marketing. Digital marketing world is like a comprehensive ecosystem and it keeps changing every day. From my previous intern at an e-commerce start-up, I learned to observe customer behavior through Google Trend, Google Analytics and Google AdWords; and use those information to create marketing campaign for social media platforms, website, emails, and influencers outreach. Fortunately all these effort turned out to be actual sales and increased likes in social media platforms, I feel like that we have built a good connection with customers. From all these precious experiences I found myself enjoy doing digital marketing strategies, so Iâ€™m excited to take the digital marketing class this semester to learn more of it, and apply to my internship and job in the future. ï¼šï¼‰

I know Iâ€™ve been neglecting the blog recently; I apologize. After classes started, I found it harder to find the time to really just sit down and write a post!! Iâ€™ll try to be better about it going forward!!

But yeah, settling into a new country is never easy nor is it seamless and if you let it, time will really get away from you. A LOT has happened since my last post. Iâ€™ve strengthened incredible friendships, told secrets, made memories, tried new things, spent more money than I should have, and most importantly, made a lot of food. And thatâ€™s what todayâ€™s blog post is dedicated to: home-cooking away from home.

Food is pretty amazing. Now that Iâ€™m thinking about it, the real reason for my #SydneySquad is probably because in the first few days of not knowing anyone or any place, we always came together to eat. None of us knew how to cook; weâ€™ve not taken classes or trained as chefs, but insofar as cooking for our friends in a place so far from anywhere any of us have ever known, it seemed appropriate to think back to the food in our own homes.Â â€œI remember the _____ mom would make for usâ€¦â€ And in thinking about the edible magic our moms used to bring our families together, I guess we tried to emulate some of that magic too.

So I present to you,Â â€œThis Is How My Mama Made Itâ€:

First night cooking. Thinking WWMD (What would mom do).

Pesto pasta, fried dumplings, bok choy in oyster sauce. Simple but tasty.

Red sauce pasta, leftover hot pot, and Rappoki (ramen ddukboki AKA spicy rice cake) which my mama taught me how to make.

When Ryo made us all Japanese ramen.

When Ryo made us Japanese Gyudon.

Ryo cooks again and makes Spaghetti Bolognese. Heâ€™s single ladies ;)

Benson packs us lunch. Chicken fried rice yummmm :)

Dinner last night. Chicken fried rice by Ben (again because it was so good), snow peas in stir fry sauce by Amanda and Lina, kkakdugi (cubed radish kimchi) and marinated stir fry chicken with mozzarella provided by moi.

Improv at its finest.

I canâ€™t believe itâ€™s already been 3 weeks since Iâ€™ve come to Sydney. When I was in New York, I never cooked for myself, not really. I was too lazy. Iâ€™ll just skip dinner. Iâ€™ll wait till I get to the dining hall. Iâ€™ll just have a bag of chips instead.Â Food seems so mundane when youâ€™re eating by yourself. I speak mostly for myself when I say Iâ€™ve not really been homesick but maybe thatâ€™s because Iâ€™ve been sharing my home and myself in bite-size pieces with my friends.

Iâ€™ll leave you with this image below:

Sent to my friend group chat a couple weeks ago whilst drunk. Misspelled:Â â€œIâ€ notÂ â€œu.â€
I love the snow. I love the work. I love you, NYU. Itâ€™s moments like these that I know Iâ€™ll look back and reminisce on some day.

How This MFA Built Her Own Production Company While Managing Her Student Loans

Five years ago Noel True decided to leave the acting world and start her own film production company. She was prepared: she had a vision for the company, a business plan, and a business partner in her husband Rob King.

But there was just one thing holding her back: student loan debt. And a lot of it.

True graduated with her MFA in acting from New York University in 1998, and worked for more than a decade as a performer in New York and Los Angeles.

â€œWhen they interviewed me for admission to NYU as part of the admission process, they asked me â€˜How do you plan on paying for it?â€™â€ she recalls.

  • Who: Noel True
  • Lives in: Los Angeles, Calif.
  • Profession: Founder, Little Pictures production company
  • Her degree: MFA, 1998, New York University
  • Annual cost of attendance (two semesters), 2015: $88,000

â€œI was 21 years old and I thought, â€˜Well, I donâ€™t know how right now, but I know this is what Iâ€™m going to be doing for the rest of my life. I know Iâ€™m passionate about it, and I know Iâ€™ll find a way.â€™â€

That â€œwayâ€ included taking more than $100,000 in student loans for graduate school.

But the unpredictable schedule of being a working actor on shows like Veronica Mars, Bones and How I Met Your Mother meant that her income â€” and paying off her loans â€” was erratic. True had to use loan forbearance several times and that meant she fell behind on paying them off for good.

Moving behind the camera

Then, in 2010, True decided to move behind the scenes and began freelancing in the video production business. She officially formed her own company, Little Pictures, in 2012.

While her professional life was moving forward, her loan burden remained and affected her personal financial progress. In fact, when she and her husband decided to buy a house, they omitted her name from the loan so she would not appear as a liability.

At that point, she says, her students loans payments were so large and the principal had been capitalized so many times, â€œI was beginning to wonder if I was going to be paying for my childrenâ€™s grad school before I even paid off my own grad school.â€

Noelâ€™s money tips:

1. Research newer refinancing options even if you have been out of school for many years.â€œFor so many years policies changed but they never included people like me whoâ€™d been out of school for so long or whose debt was so great or who had exhausted their forbearance efforts.â€


2. Get your personal finances in order to improve your professional finances.“When starting your own business, your financial house has to be in order, your intentions have to be in order, and your confidence and your abilities have to be in order.”

A new peace of mind

Even though she had been out of school for more than 15 years, she began researching options to help get her student loan debt into a better place especially now that she was running a successful production company.

Earnest, she says, appealed to her for its non-traditional way of considering borrowers.

That included people like herself: self-employed and had the means to pay back a loan but didnâ€™t necessarily look that great in a traditional model on paper. â€œI needed to refinance so I could take back my life and not have this thing from 18 years ago hanging over my head as I started a new venture in my life,â€ she says.

True’s story bucks the current narrative that student loans are holding back entrepreneurship. While startup activity by younger Americans is below historical trends, True’s experience reveals how entrepreneurs saddled with student loan debt are finding innovative ways to deal with it.

By refinancing, she shaved $400 off her monthly payments and reduced her term from 12 to four years.

Today, getting her student loan debt into a better place has helped her to be able to fully focus on the growth of her company, and better satisfy employees and customers.

â€œStudent loans used to be something that I thought about constantly. Now that mental bandwidth is occupied with much more constructive things like how to grow my business or how to offer new products to my clients or how I can be of service.â€

New to Earnest? Earnest is a technology company using software automation, smart design, and exceptional service to restore trust in the lending industry and help clients take control of their finances.

Sleeping was a thing for Aira, that she didn’t need. Didn’t even thought about doing usually. The same went for this night. Aira’s eyes stared upwards to the skies, looked at the unclouded nightsky, that seemed to be so easily reachable. She listened to some voices. Calm and definitly not angry at her, most not even nooticing her at all.

Only one voice…definitly was aware of her.

Â¤ So? Do you think, this will work out, Aira? Â¤

The stargazer simply smiled and closed her eyes, sighing out loudly. “I mean … things changed …”, she whispered as an answer, a rusty laugh returning. She knew just well enough he wasn’t up there, knew he couldn’t be up there. Never. Not in a million years again. “She is … I …”

Stopping, she sighed out loud and shook her head. “She is … as important to me as Relius was, father …”, she said and closed her eyes smiling. A friendly humming was all, that answered her, the last answer she got from NanrahÃ»n this night. The following silence was incredible deep and long, swallowing all sounds, that they could make, as she slowed her breathing, preparing for the conversation.

“You wonder who I was talking to…right?”, she simply said without turning towards the person that was behind her somewhere. The leaves of the tree she was sitting in rustled from the wind, her hair hiding her face for a moment, as she closed her eyes. “You wonder if I am talking to myself. If I am a madwoman, cazed by something, believing, I am eternal or something like that.”, she said and finally turned towards the other. “Then, let me ask you: Do you think it is crazy, that I can see you? When the night comes and she falls asleep…it is your time, isn’t it? Or am I wrong … Nocturne?”

Like what the actual fuck

I got into Columbia but not NYU

What the actual fuck

You walk through a gilded entrance of steel and glass, returning smiles and welcomes with a passing glance. There is no time; you are on a mission. Maneuvering past a forest of violet, grey, and white, you reach your target. Youâ€™ve arrived.

Suddenly, you find yourself swiping your NYU Card through roaring slot machines at the back of the NYU Bookstore, waiting to pull the perforated edge off the wafer-thin list of seemingly limitless expenses. You glance down.

R.

R.

R.

R.

R!!!?!

ALL required?!!!?!


You donâ€™t need this. We donâ€™t need this. No one needs this.

So youâ€™ve recently been instructed to purchase a 1,532 page textbook with an extra mandatory supplementary companion totaling an amount some may consider rent money (…maybe not in New York, but definitely somewhere). And if thatâ€™s not heart-wrenching enough, these textbooks are on the brink of an update so your copy will have absolutely no resale value by the end of the semester. We feel you, friend.

Thankfully, you have some options.


Option #1: Tried, Tested, and True

Listen, weâ€™ve all been there. Spending money on textbooks may not be as fun as spending money on mozzarella sticks, but the NYU Bookstore makes it an easy, (almost) painless one-way trip.

Locality, immediacy, and accessibility are all things Amazon Prime just cannot deliver. Letâ€™s be real â€” nobodyâ€™s got time for two-day shipping!

If you want to get a better sense of your textbook options, NYU Bookstoreâ€™s price comparison toolÂ is pretty sweet! Whether you are renting, buying a used copy, or treating yourself to a brand spanking new textbook and all that new textbook smell, the NYU Bookstoreâ€™s got you covered.


Option #2: J-Stor…and more!

There is more to our adorable mascot than just good looks. The BobCat, an abridged version of NYU libraryâ€™s â€œBobst Catalog,â€ is representative of a â€œstrong link between academic and athletic excellence at NYU.â€ Whether you cheer on the Violets or not (NYU Football?!), a big â€œhurrahâ€ should be reserved for the Bobst library for subscribing to legions of onlineÂ databasesÂ with access to transcribed, digital copies ofâ€¦ you guessed it! Textbooks! All with just your NetID and password.


Option #3: Just Keep Renewing, Just Keep Renewing

If you are oh-so-fortunate, a copy of your textbook is miraculously sitting on a shelf in Bobst library or any of its affiliates!. (And none of that Held-Hostage-At-Bobst-Course-Reserves nonsense! One to have and to hold from this day forward, for better, for worse…until the semester do you part.)

Snatch it up before the rest of your 200-person lecture catches up! But beware â€” cross your fingers no one requests it or back to the library it goes.


Option #4: (textbook_name).pdf

Sherlock traveled into the 21st Century; so can you! You donâ€™t need a mind palace for some smart Web 2.0 sleuthing. Here is a shortlist of public textbook resources to get you started:

  • Project Gutenberg
  • Library Genesis
  • Online Library of Liberty
  • Ebookee
  • Many Books
  • Free Book Spot

Itâ€™s elementary, my dear!


Option #5: Textbook Tinder

Who said NYU didnâ€™t have a community? Our Free and For Sale and Textbook Exchange Facebook groups beg to differ. Unless youâ€™re taking the new virtual reality class, chances are, you are not the first person to take Texts & Ideas: Antiquity and the 19th Century.

Your new(ish) textbook may bring you new friends, insightful Half-Blood Prince-style notes, and perhaps even an e-BAE just in time for Spring Breakâ€”all in one fell swoop! Take the textbook off their hands, and just take their hand! ğŸ˜ğŸ˜ğŸ˜


When all else fails…you can try to find a kind soul in lecture that will send you the course pack for nothing, just because. Or split the financial heartache between new friends; a perfect way to lament over the indignities of the current socio-economical landscape.

No matter how you get your textbooks (if you choose to at all!) â€” have an excellent semester everyone!

I met the actress on the right (aka Audrey)


I stood and watched them for ~2-2.5 hours, and eventually, got to meet Audrey and Sullivan (aka Detectives Zapata and Weller) because they walked up to me on the way to a coffee break. It turns out that Audrey went to NYU (her graduation year is 2008) and lived in Third North (just like lady gaga). Â I also talked to a few members of the crew, and the background actors (who I learned get payed more than Production Assistants (PAs) Â because theyâ€™re part of SAG). They talked to me for a while (and had a lot to say, it was some very interesting conversation) and they were superÂ nice (as were the actors!!!)


By the end, they told me that if I wanted a job as a PA (just to be on set), I should talk to the woman in charge of hiring. So, after I went back inside and got into something warmer, I gave her my number (hopefully sheâ€™ll remember we talked and call me back but most likely not..)

And finally, we get to the end of my week, Thursday (aka the day all of New York was tortured with 20 degree weather and scything, murderous wind). I was literally gone from 8am until 11pm. I woke up, went to Politics of Work, went to recitation for Anthropology, went to Xiâ€™an famous food with another one of my friends (and ate the Oil Seared Veggie Noodles!) went to a speaking freely class (japanese), went to Write! I kid you not, my whole day was walking from place to place to place, and I only had time to eat one meal (but it was a heavy one so it lasted me all day hehe)

And that was my week.

Last week I had the privilege to visit a public school in Brooklyn to the learn about the NEST ASD program embedded within it.Â 

NEST is an inclusion program within the New York City Department of Education designed for children on the Autism spectrum. Implemented within supportive New York City community schools, the program helps support children with ASD â€œlearn how to function well academically, behaviorally, and socially in school and in their community,â€ without isolating them from their peers and the rest of their school environment. For more detail about the NEST program and model, see this brochure and this video.

Since I didnâ€™t know anything about the NEST program prior to my visit, I was excited to absorb as much information as possible. Since this visit was organized through the fabulous Showcase Schools program, not only did the group of educators gathered at the school hear from its principal and teachers, but we also visited multiple classrooms in order to see elements of the program in action.Â 

Some of the most striking examples of smart thinking and strategies for ASD-focused inclusion were the simplest â€” and also often ones that had clear benefit for all students in the class. For instance, the school had developed basic movement andÂ volume scales to help kids rank their movement and voice level in the classroom and hallways.Â 

Another ingenious and simple example was the problem scale, which helps kids determine whether the issue theyâ€™re experiencing is more of a 1 at aÂ â€œglitchâ€ level, or a 5 at the other end of the spectrum, which is an emergency requiring intense adult help. Tools like these scales provide a method and vocabulary for kids to use in both identifying and explaining the problem they face, as well as learning what qualifies as an appropriate response.Â 

Lastly, every classroom I visited had constructed aÂ â€œbreak area,â€ where students could take a self-elected pause from whatever was happening in class to calm down or find a moment of quiet. The break areas were outfitted with comfortable seating such as a bean bag, and various things to read or play with; one even had candles on a shelf that kids could smell. The idea was to provide a safe space to self-soothe and regain composure away from peers â€” something I think most adults in the workforce would beg for if they had the opportunity! Tools like this break area not only echo some of the workplace psychology influencing the office environments of tech companies like Google and Facebook, but also encourage self-care and health of theÂ â€˜whole child,â€™ not just the academic student.Â 

While I was impressed by the teachers I saw in the classrooms, I was mostly surprised and heartened by the children. The students in these classrooms exemplified a range of learners â€” some held onto â€œfidgetsâ€ to help keep their hands occupied while they listed, some wore noise-canceling headphones while reading, some used the support of bouncy ball chairs orÂ â€˜pitch scalesâ€™ to monitor their own voices. All of them, however, were happy and eager to explain their tools; none were embarrassed or susceptible to the idea that these tools meant they were at allÂ â€˜less thanâ€™ or hadÂ â€˜special needs.â€™ It was a helpful reminder that sending the message that everyone has needs, and that we should embrace the tools that help us each meet them, is an extremely important thing for teachers and schools to do in cultivating a healthy, supportive and inclusive community. Go, NEST ASD program!

semesterintheuk:

One of the best pieces of advice I received before going abroad, and one that I would give to anyone else who is abroad now, is to do something different every day. I know that when Iâ€™m studying in New York I can get stuck in my routine of class, work-study, internship, reading, homework, and essay writing, that whole portions of the semester can blur together in my memory. This semester in London I want to make every day as unique as it can be, whether thatâ€™s doing something small like taking a new route to the NYU Academic Centre or something spontaneous like taking the tube to a neighborhood Iâ€™ve never been to and exploring a different part of the city for the day.

I actually, quite wonderfully, have a few minutes to spare for the first time in almost a month. And what is even more wonderful is that there was a window seat in Argo Tea. As I drink some hibiscus apple cider - because today is very fucking cold - I’m just looking out at the street. Greene and Washington Place. It’s one of those little moments when I sort of breathe in the everydayness that still surprises me. It still surprises me that I’m here. Today me and some friends from high school were talking and laughing about old times. When I think back to those times, it kind of astounds me I’m here now; so far away, and in the place I had always wanted to go. A place I’d never even seen until after I left school. I am so beyond happy that I’m here. Even though it’s crazy, busy, stressful, tiring and sometimes not easy. But I like that it’s not a simple place where nothing happens. I like walking with people who know how to walk. I like doing homework in the library and seeing the financial district grow dark outside. I like glancing out of my bedside window to see what colour the Empire State Building is each night before I go to sleep - if it’s before 2am, that is. I like drinking overpriced coffee and pretending to be American when I order it. Mostly I love seeing my friends and acquaintances every day and talking to them about anything. They’re all such beautiful, fun, smart people and after even a two minute conversation I feel a burst of happiness that I am lucky to have met all of these wonderful people. From all walks of life and backgrounds with a vast array of paths and goals. I love the people who live in this city. And when it’s all getting too much and overwhelming, I remind myself of the girl I used to be, who spent her every waking and sleeping moment desperate to be here, doing what I am doing. I wouldn’t change my time at the Atlantic for anything. It has been precious and invaluable and beautiful. Even if they do send us off campus too much. I do love it. And even though my goals and dreams today are not the same as the goals and dreams I had when I was sixteen, they’re still completely bound up with this city and all the experiences I have undergone here. I’m promising myself that I’ll never take anything about this place for granted. None of it. Well. I finished my tea and now my free time is done. I’ve got to run to my Zionism and Israel class, one of the most fascinating things I’ve ever learned about and something else on the endless list of things I’m thankful to have in my life. So happy. So stressed. So blessed. Total mess. That’s my life and I wouldn’t have it any other way.

I used to stay awake at night dreaming about living in New York. In my idealistic, adolescent mind, it was a city of dreams; it represented freedom, opportunity and celebrated cultural diversity and artistic expression. My decision to attend NYU Shanghai started with one thing: the desire to attend college in China. Being a Chinese adoptee I wanted to return to my home country on a mission of self discovery. During the NYUSH application process I focused on essay writing, interview skills and the like. I didnâ€™t focus on the price tag because I doubted I would get admitted.

Â Once admitted I was thrilled for a good five minutes before I checked my NYU account and realized how much financial aid I would receive. Iâ€™d heard of people getting full rides and how the Shanghai campus apparently had better FA than the NY campus. When I learned Iâ€™d only be getting $20k a year off the $63k tuition I was crushed by the idea that by the time I graduate I will be hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt.Â 

Â My parents were very supportive. They said theyâ€™d try to help me out and that I should chase my dreams. They also brought up the point that attending NYU could be a good investment in my future. I, however, was not so sure. Iâ€™d read various articles informing me not to drop huge amounts of money for my undergrad degree and horror stories of NYU grads being crushed with debt and without a solid job. I had other schools offering me much more affordable tuition and only two weeks to decide (since Iâ€™d applied to NYUSH ED).Â 

After many hours of tossing and turning late at night, sometimes crying to myself, I finally decided to go for it. While Iâ€™m still scared about the debt prospects, I truly believe that down the line I will regret not going for my dreams more than spending too much on my tuition. I also firmly believe that the connections and education Iâ€™ll attain to NYU SHÂ will help me get a job in the future.Â

BY LARISA CASILLAS

â€˜Your head is a haunted house.â€™

Sometime during the Occult Humanities Conference this phrase was uttered and it stuck with me throughout.

Afterwards, during a private viewing of Language of the Birds: Occult and Art (which will show at NYU February 12-13) I was able to see what it meant.Â 

Spanning over a century of occult art, the exhibition has 60 works by different modern and contemporary artists who delved deep into their minds and tried to transcend rationality. The exhibition is curated by Pam Grossman, the creator of the occult blog Phantasmaphile, and also the co-organizer of the Occult Humanities Conference. Â 

“By going within, then drawing streams of imagery forth through their creations, each of these artists seeks to render the invisible visible, to materialize the immaterial, and to tell us that we, too, can enter numinous realms,â€ she writes.

Language of the Birds is divided into 5 sections: Cosmos, Spirits, Practitioners, Altars and Spells. The art ranges from the visually beautiful to the unnerving and intellectually engaging; from Aleister Crowleyâ€™s alter ego self-portrait, Ken Hensonâ€™s portrait of the goddess Ishtar, Robert Burattiâ€™s dreamy Sub Rosa and Paul Laffoleyâ€™s Astrological Ouroboros, with the twelve signs of the zodiac paired with the twelve stages of changes of attitude toward life - each piece challenges you to feel rather than analyze.


Â 

Â 

Â 

Speaking to Luna Luna about the current appeal magic and the occult has on the younger generation, Grossman cited that for women it honors cycles and gives agency, â€œwitchcraft is about embracing the body,"Â  she says. And as for men, it gives them the freedom to explore alternative types of spirituality â€“ â€œyou donâ€™t just need one book,â€ she concluded.

Language of the Birds: Occult and Art
January 12 â€“ February 13, 2016
80WSE, 80 Washington Square East, NYC
Gallery Hours: Tuesday â€“ Saturday 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.Â

They’re one of the great stories of this generation. A resurgence of flaps of cardboard, plastic pieces, and complicated rulebooks. They may be the product of a hipster fad like the return of vinyl records, but I have to be honest: I think board games are the ultimate escape for anyone willing to sit down and take the ride.

My fanaticism for board games isn’t old. In fact, by comparison to some of my good friends I’ve met through the years, I’m a relative newcomer to the scene. But damn did it get a grip on me. Nowadays I jump at every opportunity to experience a new game, and thankfully (or woefully, depending on the situation) the city is willing to oblige me of my numerous vices.

Such an opportunity came to my doorstep in the form of my good friend Mike shooting me a call, letting me know he would be in the city with his significant other Erica. Mike is one of my few friends I keep in contact with from my prep school days, and over the years we’ve shared a multitude of interests. These days he lives nearby Rutgers, so the opportunity to shoot the shit with him in a crowded space full of games seemed like a fantastic experienced not to be passed up on.

The smell of fresh rainfall permeates the typical odor of the village as I make my way through Washington Square Park. The park is surprisingly empty at this time of day, which in retrospect was also a product of the earlier rainfall. No matter, I’m trekking through to the Uncommons, a small jewel of a game shop located on Thompson street just south of the NYU campus.

It’s hard to put an accurate size to the Uncommons, but I’d guess the main space is probably around the size of a walk-in closet. You make friends fast in this kind of environment, because (like most spaces in NYC) personal space be damned. The system here is simple: pay up, grab a game from the myriad available from the walls surrounding you, and put it back the way you found it when done.

A lot of the games have largely seen better days, with some well-worn and a few others with a piece or two missing. But there is a certain care taken to this space by those who frequent it, a reverence and awe you can feel immediately upon entering. Perhaps that is what’s really driving the board game renaissance: happy, friendly people searching for a few hours of fun and distraction from the world outside.

Most of the typefaces in the fonts below are Serif, Script, and Decorative.Â 

  • Lavanderia -Â Script; Designer:Â James T. Edmondson
  • Trend Slab - Â Serif;Â Designer(s):Â Daniel HernÃ¡ndez and Paula Nazal Selaive
  • New Cuisine - Script;Â Designer:Â Stephen W. Rapp
  • Luella - Â Decorative ; Designer:Â Cindy Kinash

  • Carolyna Pro Black - Script/Decorative; Designer:Â Emily Conners


Fav. Typeface

My favorite typeface would have to be between Serif and Script. Serif makes the font easier to read and helps make your point come across easier and softer on the eyes. I personally like Script because it gives flair to a design and helps carry the aesthetic to build around it. Decorative fonts are pretty nice too because they come in all different variants and help set the tone for the designated design. Fonts/typefaces set the mood for who the viewer sees our design and it is up to the artist to make that experience as comfortable as possible.

“What are you most proud of?”

“Probably learning 6 languages at this point in my life. When I was growing up I had a speech disorder that prevented me from speaking in complete sentences, and that put me at odds with speaking with my family- who doesn’t speak a lot of English. Speaking other languages made me feel like I’m compensating for the fact that I couldn’t talk to my family so I talked more to other people. But now that my skills in mother’s tongue has gotten better, it feels better now. I feel more complete, more able to talk with my family, and more connected with my heritage than before.”

“What is one important lesson you’ve learned this year?”

“I’ve been learning more and more of the value of community. A Bible verse I’ve been mulling over recently has been 1John 1:7 (NIV). It’s necessary, for any kind of healing, that confession and vulnerability occur, and that can only happen when we create space for that, and I’m really thankful that I’ve found that space here at NYU!"Â

Week One and done

The first week is officially over and I am tired. In a good way!

I didnâ€™t expect everything to blast by the way it did but the first day of nervousness and anticipation has passed by (still jet-lagged though). Florence has definitely been an experience thus far. If you ask anyone here, theyâ€™ll say it feels like weâ€™ve been here for 3 weeks as opposed to 5 days but even still, itâ€™s been a blessing. Strangely enough if I could compare to anywhere it would be New York. Just much, much slower (and of course, different language). The city is much more international than I had previously thought. Yes, itâ€™s filled with students and tourists but even the native people are diverse. It made me think about cultural diffusion. In fact, one of our first readings basically explained that Italian was and still is a hodgepodge of several different languages (i.e. German, English, and Spanish). So thatâ€™s fun.

Iâ€™m not fluent in Czech. I took an intensive 9 hour language seminar in Czech the first week I was here, but it really only taught me the basics: greetings, the numbers 1 to 20, common foods, etc. It was really more of a survival class aka How to Get By on the Bare Minimum for the Next 4 Months.Â 

Mostly, I havenâ€™t really had problems with my lack of knowledge. My classes are all in the Old Town, the most touristy area of Prague. Most shopkeepers there know how to speak English or are extremely kind when I try my remedial Czech with them.Â 

For instance, the lady who runs the coffee shop next to the NYU building is very sweet. I think she is very familiar with all the NYU students who pass by her shop before and after class for our New York college student coffee fix. She smiles at us when we sayÂ â€œDobry denâ€ as a greeting andÂ â€œDekujuâ€ ofÂ â€œDikyâ€ as a thanks, but she takes our orders in English and is generally a very positive woman. I think sheâ€™s probably one of the more openly cheerful Czech people Iâ€™ve encountered here, as the general disposition of most Czechs towards strangers is more reserved than Americans.Â 

There are a few times when I go out around my dorm in Holesovice that I encounter the language barrier. When I go to the grocery store here, I have to hope and pray that pointing, smiling, and sayingÂ â€œAmericanâ€ is enough to get them to understand my confusion.Â 

I am always a little embarrassed when that happens, but Iâ€™ve gotten used to reading the situation andÂ â€œdoing as the locals do.â€ Maybe my hesitance to just leap into new situations head first is a sign that Iâ€™m not totally comfortable here in Prague yet, but I think my observations of how locals behave on the trams, in the super markets, on the streets, etc. has let me integrate a lot more smoothly (if a little more slowly). NYU is known for its extensive global network. With campuses at 13 different cities across the globe, you are guaranteed to find the experience of a lifetime. From Shanghai to Buenos Aires, here are some things that pretty much all study away students can relate to.


You use local slang

â€œAnyone need to use the loo?â€ or â€œå“å‘€, I dropped my lunch!â€ Every place in the world has their own special lingo, and you cannot help but get caught up in using it! Just, try to ditch it when you come home, no one will understand why you keep calling the subway a â€œtube.â€


You spend every weekend in a different country

Waking up in the morning, and realizing you canâ€™t remember which country youâ€™re in is a realistic part of studying away. France? Korea? Egypt? But, I guess thatâ€™s not too bad of a problem to have.


You celebrate holidays you have never heard of

Being a student at NYU opens you up to a lot of diverse holidays and experiences, but sometimes you donâ€™t even know certain things exist until the day of. Whether you are fighting with water guns during Thailandâ€™s Songkran Festival or buying immense amounts of unnecessary things on TaoBao for Singleâ€™s Day in China, experiencing the fun of other cultures is one of the best parts of studying away.Â 


You consume SO MUCH gelato/bubble tea/etcâ€¦.

There is always that one food you canâ€™t stay away from. Itâ€™s almost impossible to walk by Pret in London or a gelateria in Florence without stopping in. Maybe it is because they are everywhere, or maybe it is just because they are so. darn. good.Â 


You feel way too cultured

If you can, try to refrain from word-vomiting everything you learned while abroad the minute you talk to someone from home. Try to throw it in casually during conversation. And whatever you do, try to find another phrase other than,Â â€œWhen I lived in…â€ to start your sentences. Donâ€™t worry, people are just jealous of your immense cultural growth.Â 


You can book airbnb in your sleep

If youâ€™ve been away, you know travelling via airbnb is the way to go. Staying with people who live and breathe the culture of the city everyday is a totally unique experience you canâ€™t get at a hotel. Oh, and itâ€™s usually way cheaper #brokecollegekidproblems


If you go somewhere with a weaker currency, you feel like a millionaireâ€¦.

A coke for 25 cents? A cab ride for two dollars? What are these majestic lands? Watch out though, a lot of cheap little things can add up fast. You may not be in New York, but youâ€™re still no BeyoncÃ©. Refrain fromÂ â€œtreating yoâ€™selfâ€ too much.Â 


â€¦.and places with stronger currencies make you feel like a peasant.

Itâ€™s not easy to get more expensive than New York, but there are places out there that are. Walk everywhere and eat budget food. Save the little money you have left to travel, it is so worth it. Worse comes to worse, scout out a royal. Maybe youâ€™ll become the next Kate Middleton.Â 


You inevitably gain the freshman 15… againâ€¦

You might bring your workout clothes with you, but the truth is youâ€™ll be too busy seeing awesome sights and eating delicious food to ever use them. You may gain weight, but you also gain memories. #noregrets


You donâ€™t know how youâ€™re going to live without your study away friends once you go back home

When you go to a new place with new people, everyone bonds in a special way. Study away friends may be some of the best friends you ever have. After living, adjusting to new cultures/languages, and travelling the world together, there is little that can tear these friendships apart.Â 

If you are interested in learning more about the awesome experience that is studying away at NYU, check out the experiences of our global bloggers at THIS IS NYU.Â

Nyu/Lucy

This week was sick (literally and metaphorically)

If you couldnâ€™t tell by the first line, I was sick this week. Nothing too bad (just a cold) but I was not too happy about it.Â 

And now the cool part: this past Saturday, I was eating at a community table with my sister for lunch (I was helping her move, ugh) and we were just talking about life, and I briefly mentioned that I was going to be a cinematographer for the movie that weâ€™re shooting in my class Write! Shoot! Edit!. Just as weâ€™re rapping up, the woman sitting across from me and next to my sister is likeÂ â€œoh hey, youâ€™re a film student at NYU? Want to come and do this job for me with a bunch of famous people?â€ She name drops a few people, gives me her number, and tells me to call her tomorrow.Â 

So, Iâ€™m sitting here like,Â â€œWTF just happened?â€ and my sister, my mom and I are having this three way chat where my momâ€™s likeÂ â€œthis is sketchy, what if sheâ€™s a serial kidnapperâ€ and my sisterâ€™s like,Â â€œOH MY GOD SHE TEXTED OUR PICTURE TO [INSERT FAMOUS PERSON HERE]â€ and Iâ€™m like,Â â€œoh wow this is going to be awesome.â€Â 

So, on Sunday I talk to her on the phone and she basically tells me that this could shoot my career up and Iâ€™m likeÂ â€œomg this is sickâ€ and sheâ€™s telling me all about the doors and opportunities that will open up for me in the next four years and then she tells me the date of the shoot (which is in a few weeks) and then we say goodbye. Little did I know, I would spend the rest of the week being harassed by my parents about the possibility of a kidnapping. Iâ€™ll admit, the situation was different, and being cautious is probably better than not being cautious, but I like to think thereâ€™s some good left in humanity and that this woman is going to get my film career started.

Sunday was pretty normal: I officially joined Under the ArchÂ (which is basically the bloggy and creative version of Washington Square News) and attended my first meeting as one of Assistant Managers for Cabaret. Both were very enjoyable, and I cannot wait to see how Cabaret is going to be in April! So that was the weekend.

Now on to the week: Monday was pretty mundane (for my normal week, not in general). I went to class and then rehearsal (where I got to watch the cast sing and dance so that was cool). Tuesday was a little more fun. I went to Xiâ€™an Famous FoodsÂ for dinner and ate some Spicy Hot Oil Seared Hand-Ripped Noodles.Â 


Afterwards, went to a (supposedly) popular ice cream place called Van Leeuwan



It had a cute atmosphere, that reminded me of small town combined with a hipster-y touch.


I mean you canâ€™t look at those jars and tell me theyâ€™re not hipster


Saloon anyone?


I got some cookies and cream ice cream (the one pictured is my friendâ€™s Earl Grey with Fluffernutter), and overall the ice cream wasnâ€™t too bad. However, I definitely like Sundaes and Cones better.



Wednesday was boring until dinner, when my sister and I went and met our cousinâ€™s new baby (my cousin is in his early 40s, so he already has a 12 year old whoâ€™s now an older sister). Our aunt was there (and made an awesome homemade dinner!!!) and we all sat around and talked until I snagged a ride home in my sisterâ€™s Lyft and did homework while singing Hannah Montana songs with my roommates.Â 

This Thursday was my first recitation ever in college, and I found it to be surprisingly nice (before recitation, that line said â€œboring and unhelpful to my college career so thatâ€™s saying something). We were greeted by a seemingly chill TA, and she basically showered us in chocolate (which I happen to love so sheâ€™s already won me over) and I made some friends– in fact, I had lunch with one of the girls I met in recitation today. I might officially incorporate anthropology my concentration after this semester.Â 

Anyhow, that was my week. Stay tuned for next week if you want to know how the shoot went!

â€œMy name is KP Mendoza, and Iâ€™m a sophomore at the College of Nursing. My parents are both nursesâ€”they grew up in the Philippines, and so I figured that that would be the best optionâ€”to do nursing. I like to, at the heart of it, see people smile, and I think thereâ€™s no better gift you can give than the gift of life and health to someone else. A guest post from our friends of the 2019 Class Activities Board…

To My Fellow First Year Violets,

First and foremost, congratulations making it thus far at NYU; these next couple years will no doubt be filled with some of our most amazing experiences. As you trudge across the Washington Square campus with your new WTE books and slowly start questioning your decision to have 8 AMs, an asked question may be: â€œAre you going to the SnoBall Dance next Friday?â€Â (Think NYU Welcome Week Music Festi-Ball but the Spring Semester version). As the theme for this yearâ€™s 10th Annual SnoBall dance is Hollywood, feel free to pull out your Weekend Best, 8 AM Worst, or that brand new fashion piece youâ€™ve been itching to wear. And also, understand the efforts and intentionality the 2019 Class Activities Board has put into making this NYU tradition a reality.

While there may be elements of the Oscars in our Hollywood-themed SnoBall aesthetics and decorations, we want you to know that we acknowledge the Oscars can be problematic. Recently, thereâ€™s been a social movement that has gained visibility on Social Media and in the news â€“ #OscarsSoWhite. Why? This movement calls attention to the absence of color and diversity seen in the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciencesâ€™ 2016 Oscar nominees. For the second year in a row, ALL 20 actors/actresses nominated in the lead and supporting acting categories are white. In the Academy Awardsâ€™ 88-year history, only 14 black actors have won acting Oscars. Furthermore, representation of people of color of other identities is even lower. In the history of the Oscars, only 5 Latino actors have won (most recently, Benicio Del Toro in 2001) and only 3 Asian actors have been recognized with a win (the last was Haing S. Ngor in 1985). These facts were found in this article, please let us know if you have other info for us to amend our facts.

In response, many actors made a commitment to boycott the Oscars in solidarity if no changes were made. In spreading their message, the movement has gained widespread support. Amidst the movement, the 51-member committee decided the implementation of new rules. Some of these include a commitment to doubling the number of women and minorities in the academy by 2020 and limiting lifetime voting rights.

With the 2019 Class Activities Boardâ€™s (CAB19) SnoBall Dance coming up, we are excited to celebrate the diversity that NYU and New York City has offered us this past semester. Be sure to check out our own nomination process that we created to celebrate our NYU 2019 community. Throughout the next week, weâ€™ll be celebrating you so stay tuned by liking the Official NYU Class of 2019 Facebook Page.

Weâ€™re so excited for you to enjoy the First-Year tradition of the SnoBall Dance (complete w/ DJ, dance floor, and free food!) And when youâ€™re dancing among your peers, we hope you appreciate and celebrate the diversity that New York City has to offer; the diversity NYU has to offer; and the diversity you have to offer.

tl;dr: The NYU 2019 Community proudly values diversity. Come out to the 10th Annual SnoBall Dance on Friday, February 12th from 8PM to 12AM hosted by the 2019 Class Activities Board (CAB19). Nominate your friends and celebrate each otherâ€™s awesomeness. Much love to the fam. See you there!

Dimitri Henry, Executive VP of the 2019 Class Activities Board
Isabella Villacampa, Program Administrator for the NYU Student Resource Center

Nicole Dâ€™Alessio, Class ofÂ â€˜17

The creaks of the acrobatâ€™s skin sliding down the shaking trapeze are the only sounds in the theatre. The spotlight cuts in and out, every three seconds or so, finally revealing that she is using only the arch at the back of her neck to remain suspended, hundreds of feet in the air.

Music usually accompanies acts like these. But Ocktobre pointedly leaves the background noise out of this performance, and the effect is electrifying: each gasp from the audience is amplified. The only light in the theatre is a single shaking spotlight on the performerâ€™s near-naked body, above an unlit chandelier. Circus isnâ€™t usually like thatâ€”in fact, itâ€™s an art form known for its flashing lights and intricate costumes.

But the aim of Circus Now is to test everything we think we know about circus. Itâ€™s an ancient art form that began in Europe and was later brought to America, where it evolved into what we see todayâ€”think elephants and sequins. Circus Now is different. They let the talent of their artists do the talking, not their elephants or set displays. The show wasnâ€™t a display of â€œprogressiveâ€ circus at all, but instead a return to what the circus genre was built upon: the talent of the artist. Â 

The Acrobatic Conundrum, which performed Thursday night, included a solo act by a Cyr wheel artist, who began by imploring us, the audience, to look at him instead of the other acrobats on stage. This spiraled into a monologue about perfectionism and the struggle for attention in a high-tension performing art. Then he lunged into a meticulously timed display of superhuman strength and skill, while standing inside the Cyr wheel and grasping itâ€™s rim, causing it to spin gyroscopically and performing acrobatic moves inside the rotating wheel.

We sat startlingly close to members of the Bindlestiff Family Circus, and other (remarkably well-dressedâ€”think, sideshow-vintage-chic) fans of circus.

The Emcee, Sxip Shirey, shared stories about his international circus travels, and an audience member corrected his details, â€œNo, that act used five rigs, not three!â€ Someone else shouted â€œHallo!â€ when Sxip mentioned a German troupe he toured with fifteen years ago. We begin to get the feeling that everyone in the theatre is somehow connected. And that I, a mere outsider to the mysterious and illustrious world of circus, was bid a very welcome entry to their world, led me to realize why people run away to the circus:

Acceptance. Itâ€™s an embrace, no, a glorificationâ€”of every uncategorized or perceivably â€œstrangeâ€ talent that wouldnâ€™t have a context anywhere else. And people cheer encore for it.

Outside I sipped coffee during intermission, and ran into a small band of jugglers, the next act, who were waiting to walk on stage. They said hello in unison as I walked by, as if they werenâ€™t holding bowling pins in each hands and wearing uniforms. â€œHello,â€ I said. â€œMy name is Nicole.â€ They fumbled to trade bowling pins so we could shake hands, one by one. And after I left the music kicked in, and they went on stage.

Circus looks different from the inside: itâ€™s a warm, welcoming environment where you can forget about reality for a while as the very laws of gravity are defied and your heart soars. In Circus Now the roots of circus are exposed, and the art form has never been more bracing. Moreover, I now have a bunch of friends who travel the world in caravans.

Information on Circus Now 2016 can be found on NYU Skirballâ€™s website.Â

Itâ€™s been roughly about a week since arriving in Prague and I feel like itâ€™s been months, in a good way~

Iâ€™ve learned so much about Czech history, the Czech language, and Czech culture in familiarizing myself with the country Iâ€™ll be living in for the semester. I am mostÂ surprised, though,Â about how much reflection Iâ€™ve done about myselfÂ in the context of all that is around me. I thought I grew into myself years ago, but the discomfort in culture shock and getting adjusted has shown me thereâ€™s so much more to learn.

I am so thankful for this opportunity and for the tiny blessings that have come my way that have helped me in the adjustment process of facing culture shock. It was disorienting leaving home, figuring out which key fits which door, how the shower works, getting a Czech number, if I could work the stove or the microwave without causing a fire, how to get around on public transit without getting lost… From flying with a friend in the program, from accidentally being placed in housing with friends of friends, from the events organized by NYU that provided structure and got us familiar with our new beautiful campus and Czech history, to the RAs that told us of spots to eat and get groceries– these training wheels in the beginning of the study abroad process, have created a smoother transition process than I would have ever expected. I canâ€™t wait to begin the next four months of my life in Central Europe, gradually take off these training wheels, and take every opportunity that NYU in Prague has to offer to learn, to create, and to grow.Â 

I feel like Iâ€™m living the sweetest of dreams.Â

Reading through the The Non-Designers Design Book helped me see how, for example, alignment and proximity are very important to any design aspect. We often see good design in our everyday life and we just donâ€™t notice it. It could be your own business card or the stop sign on the street. All these things are designed in a way to grab your attention while still being visually appealing to the eye.

I think the most important concept I learned was proximity. I didnâ€™t really notice before how having an object next to another can affect the designs outcome so much. Being well aligned and proximate allows for good organization in your design. Another key topic was white space, which I thought was very useful. You want to leave enough whitespace to focus the design on a few aspects but not so much that it looks barren and boring. All these points are crucial for good design that doesnâ€™t make your eyes hurt and can be easy to read to get your message across effectively.

Something that confused me I would say was repetition. We are expected to make a design look random, but at the same time intentional. How can one do that effectively? Can we be randomly intentional? We must keep the consistency the same but in a random and intentional order.Â 

I think the photo below is a good representation of alignment and proximity because of its ample white space. This helps maintain the center of attention for Â its audience while being simple enough to convey a clear message. The logo and tag line at the bottom also help the viewer know who mad it just in case they are unfamiliar with the company without overpowering the message. I think this is also a good example of repetition because you see the logo twice on the ad. In the spring itself and in the corner of the ad that way the audience will leave knowing who the ad is for and what they are selling.

Camouflage for the Digital Age: How to Stymie Predators Who Feed on Your Data

You know that Google is reading your emails, that an idle Sunday afternoon search for a new coffee table can send Crate & Barrel ads skittering across your screen at least through Wednesday, and that you shouldnâ€™t post anything on Facebook that you wouldnâ€™t want printed on the front page of the New York Times. You know that around every virtual corner lurk would-be thieves poised to abscond with your credit card information, that your four GPS-equipped devices track your every move, and that with each new app download youâ€™re agreeing to a long list of terms thatâ€™d make you queasy if you managed to decipher all that fine print.

And yet (gasp!) youâ€™re online anyway. All day. Every day. What choice do you have? Parting with your personal data is an inevitable fact of gliding through your thoroughly modern life, with your maps and pictures and music and calendars trailing merrily behind you in the cloud. Â 

Thatâ€™s a common assumptionâ€”and the one Steinhardt media, culture, and communication professors Finn Brunton and Helen Nissenbaum seek to upend in their book Obfuscation: A Userâ€™s Guide for Privacy and Protest, in which they argue both that your privacy is being eroded through acts way, way more heinous than you might think, and that contrary to popular belief, there is something you can do about it. This past week was NYU Sydneyâ€™s O-week (â€Oâ€ forÂ â€œOrientationâ€). And weâ€™ve been doing a lot of (enjoyable) touristy things. For example, a boat tour on which we got to see Harbour Bridge and the Sydney Opera House (Wed, Jan. 27th):

And a walking tour on which we got to explore The Rocks neighborhood which is near where The Science House is located. Very historic and charming (Thurs, Jan. 28th):

Lastly, an overnight trip to Milson Island which was essentially like a summer camp:

Me as Katniss Everdeen

Mariah, Serena, and I. In love.

From left: Ryosuke, me, Amanda, Lina, Serena, and Benson

More or less the entire NYU Sydney program

It was interesting what being on Milson Island did to me. Maybe it was the whole â€œsummer campâ€-type setup but it brought out a side of me Iâ€™d almost forgotten. Itâ€™d been a long time since Iâ€™d seen my 8 year-old self, worn her shoes and laughed the way she laughed. And in doing so a lot of little fragments of that time surfaced and bobbed in my conscious. Like, memories from Girl Scouts camping trips - especially how to make a good sâ€™more. Like, the Kookaburra song (apt because I am in Australia) that we learned for Small World Day in third grade. It was so hot on the island; Australian sun is really much harsher than East Coast US sun (sunscreen is a MUST!) but even when I was sweating like a pig, I still ran around playing cricket, hiking, swimming, kayaking. I didnâ€™t care that I was tired and gross and tanned. The world was infinite fun and challenge, the way recess had been so long ago. It was like all the restrictions Iâ€™ve internalized of every passing year since fell away and all that was left was an openness to relish every moment. In time, the ridiculous shorts-tan Iâ€™ve achieved will fade or blend, but for now itâ€™ll remind me to take a step back and see the world as an 8 year-old.Â 

On Sunday, we explored a little more of Sydney on our own. Iâ€™ll write about that in another post but for now, first day of classes today. Wish me luck!

I just finished my first week here at NYU Prague, and what can I say? Iâ€™m in love. The city is beautiful. Everyday I wake up and feel like Iâ€™m in a Medieval movie! The architecture, which my Instagram followers are probably well aware of by now, is almost all gothic/romantic. Iâ€™m sure there is a better term for the style, but unfortunately, I havenâ€™t taken an architecture tour yet. Soon, I promise!

The food here is one of my favorite things Iâ€™ve experienced so far. Beer culture is alive and well in this city. First and foremost, Czechs are proud of their Pilsner Urquell. Youâ€™ve probably heard of Pilsner beer–well Pilsner Urquell was the first type of beer of this kind (from Plzen, a city in CZ). Itâ€™s far above the traditional PBR and Budweiser you can get in America, and usually a large glass is a little over a dollar. Beer might not be cheaper than water here, but itâ€™s damn close.Â 

Iâ€™ve found that the Czech people are generally much quieter and more polite than the kind of people youâ€™d find in America. The tram that I take everyday to get to the city center and my classes is quiet aside from a few whispered conversations. Usually it is us NYU students who make up the majority of the sound every morning. Furthermore, Iâ€™ve noticed that, while homelessness is a lot less obvious here as it is in New York, the poor people Iâ€™ve seen here are generally quieter and more respectful of your personal boundaries. I have yet to see a visibly homeless person on the trams, and the few that I have seen usually are silently bowing on the streets with their hands stretched in supplication. Itâ€™s odd to me as an American to see such resigned, dignified posture among the homeless.Â 

Also, they donâ€™t give plastic bags out for free in the stores here in Prague! Itâ€™s strange but also makes me so pleased! I always thought America was the center of environmental friendliness. Especially in my home town of San Jose, CA, I figured that the US led the way in terms of green technology (i.e. hybrid cars). However, it was only just recently that my city placed a plastic bag tax on stores. We havenâ€™t even outright banned plastic bags–itâ€™s still the default to have your items bagged this way. But in many stores Iâ€™ve been to in Prague, the cash register will not bag your items unless you specifically ask for a bag (which I think is called tasku in Czech).Â 

Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™ll have more observations later, but these are the biggest things Iâ€™ve noticed so far.Â 

—–

Anyway, on to the scary accident of the night: some friends and I were returning on the late night tram after a nice round of drinks at the Hemingway Bar (a touristy 20s themed bar with amazing cocktails). We just got on the tram we needed to take back to Osadni and were about a minute into the last leg of our tram ride home.Â 

Now to preface the story: In Prague, trams here are aboveground and typically have the right of way because their mass makes it hard to slow down fast. So as a pedestrian, you have the right of way when it comes to crossing the street in front of a car, but you donâ€™t have the right of way when it comes to trams. Same with other vehicles: cars must stop for trams.Â 

Anyway, I was standing facing the front of the tram, looking over the back of my friend who had grabbed a seat in front of me. Honestly, I was slightly tipsy, but out of the corner of my eye, I saw a car come from the street that merged through the tram tracks.Â 

It was as if everything had slowed down. In the back of my mind, I thought to myself,Â â€œThat canâ€™t be safeâ€ when all of the sudden the tram and car collided! Luckily I was holding firmly onto a pole so I wasnâ€™t thrown out of my seat or anything. I can say right now I escaped with no injuries, nor did my friends!Â 

The tram driver emerged from his little driving compartment and muttered,Â â€œDebilâ€ under his breath. Donâ€™t ask me why, but I know this word meansÂ â€œassholeâ€ in Czech. They didnâ€™t teach me this in Czech class, just FYI.Â 

A minute later, he got back on the tram. I was afraid he would rattle off a list of instructions in Czech to us and i wouldnâ€™t be able to understand anything he said. Thankfully, the rest of the people on the tram seemed to start filing off, so my friends and I took this as our cue to get off and leave. We werenâ€™t too far from Osandi by then, so we decided just to take the walk back on foot.Â 

It was a strange way to end the night, and Iâ€™m grateful it looked like everyone on the tram and even the carâ€™s driver were unharmed. It also makes me wonder about the traffic laws in Prague. I havenâ€™t seen muchÂ â€œunsafeâ€ driving, but I do remember my first reaction to hearing the right of way laws regarding trams my first day here was skepticism. There are very few stop signs and lights at intersections and merges here (at least compared to the US). While that means less traffic backup and a smoother ride overall, I can only guess what that means in terms of safe driving.Â

Itâ€™s expensive but my dad wants me close to home.

So, this semester I managed to get all of my textbooks without having to pay for any of them. I go to New York University, but I feel like a lot of other collegiate libraries have similar features and therefore this might be of use to non NYU folk!

Basically, NYUâ€™s Bobst library is seriously vast and connected. It is most likely that the book you are looking for has a place on the shelves. Start with a search on BobCatÂ and select the filtersÂ â€œat Bobstâ€ andÂ â€œavailableâ€ to see if that book is on the shelf right now for you to go and get. This was the case for about 20% of my textbooks. If you canâ€™t find the book on the shelf and it says itâ€™s available, a librarian can do the search for you (at a time when you arenâ€™t counting down 15 min between classes)

The next line of defense is EZ-Borrow, which is an expedited book-exchange system. EZ-Borrow keeps track of the availabilities in library catalogs in the tri-state area. I just ordered like 5 books to be at Bobst from Penn State and Rutgers. The book will arrive at Bobst in 3-5 days, so I stocked up on everything for the rest of the semester so I wouldnâ€™t be caught without a text at the last minute.Â 

Finally, there ILL (inter-library loan), aka We Will Get This Damn Book For U. ILL goes beyond just NYU/affiliated college libraries and sources from places like the NYPL. This is also how you get non-book materials to Bobst. ILL is also great for requesting *sections* of a book, so if you only need specific chapters, a librarian somewhere in the world will find them, beautifully scan them, and send them to Bobst. That way you donâ€™t have to worry about a giant book orÂ a due date. Yeah! (These materials also arrive in 3 to 5 days)

Both EZ-Borrow and ILL let you keep the book as long as if youâ€™d checked it out from Bobst (12 weeks).Â 

If all else fails, Bobst has an option where you can literally put in a request for a book you think they should have on their shelves. Of course that canâ€™t guarantee theyâ€™ll buy it by the time you need to finish that research paper, but surely future generations will thank you.Â 

I know a lot of this might seem obvious, but I have spent hundreds of dollars on textbooks for the past 7 semesters of college just because of the convenience and the thought that thereâ€™s really no better way. But after sitting down today and requesting all of my books from the library, I found just clickingÂ â€œrequestâ€ 50 times was easier than spending hundreds of dollars and eating halal food for dinner that night (lol).Â 

Libraries are basically the shit and I definitely wish Iâ€™d taken advantage of these resources before it was my last semester of college!!

I hope this helps at least one person! <3

So youâ€™re back from study away! Welcome back (or rather, welcome home). Just like when you first arrived to your site, thereâ€™s a (re)adjustment period you canâ€™t really avoid. But know that youâ€™re not the only one, and going through these six stages will only make you more appreciative of your time away and back home.


1. Excitement

The familiarity of your home campus brings back all those fuzzy feelings. It feels like freshman year again â€” you walk around the city with a smile on your face, rediscovering everything.

Â 

2. Satisfaction

You need a local overload, stat. Go back to your favorite spots, eat your favorite treats. In NYC, having Shake Shack, dollar pizza, and four bagels in just one day is more than acceptable. Youâ€™ve been craving these things for so long â€” you deserve them!


3. Shock

You start to notice little things that have changed â€” some are awesome, some less so. Maybe a new coffee shop popped up but your favorite little bookstore closed down. Well, thatâ€™s just the circle of life.


4. Confusion

Which one is Waverly Place again? Is that parallel to Greene or are you thinking of Mercer? What stop do you get off to visit your friend on the other side of the Huangpu River? How do you not remember these things?! Donâ€™t worry, it happens when youâ€™ve been gone long enough, and youâ€™ll relearn it all in no time.


5. Longing

You look back at pictures from study away, and you miss every second of it. The trips, the food, the scenery… You try to find places nearby that serve your favorite dish, but itâ€™s not really the same. You tell yourself youâ€™ll go back one day, whatever it takes.


6. Acceptance

In the end, you love your study away site and home campus just as much. Itâ€™s not a competition at all, and missing one doesnâ€™t mean you canâ€™t enjoy the other. All you can do is be grateful for the wonderful times youâ€™ve had, and make the most of wherever you are.

Welp, itâ€™s a big day as the semester starts off for lil olâ€™Â me: Sophomore in Film & TV at the lovely NYU Tisch School of the Arts.Â 

Today is blog-ably noteworthy for a few reasons, the first being that I’m very exciting about my new classes, especially New Cinema and Business of Producing (hell yeah #BEMT minor), secondly cause I met with the new President of NYU Mr. Andy Ham and his charming (get it, cause theyâ€™re Brits!) wife Jeanine and thirdly cause, well cause its Tuesday but tomorrow is my last day of classes for this week cause God blessed me with scheduling magic.Â 

Today part 1: Expanding Cinema: New Media, the Movies and Beyond

Wow. With a course title like that (and the painfully vague course description) Â I didnâ€™t have an exact idea what this class would be, but I did have high expectations.Â
