My name is Matthew Gibson. Â I am a sophomore in the Gallatin School of Individualized Study where I concentrate in Globalization. Â I choose classes that focus on global culture, especially conflict studies, as well as international development and the world economy. I am also pursuing a minor in Mandarin Chinese. I was born in the United States in Southern California but moved to Missouri when I was 11. Then I ended up in New York when I started at NYU and now I am studying abroad at NYU Shanghai. The decision to study at NYU Shanghai was an easy one to make since I have incorporated the study of Mandarin Chinese into my education and China is a major player in the rise of globalization. My goal for the coming semester is to learn outside of the classroom through working internationally, socializing with Chinese nationals, and traveling throughout this vast country.

I arrived in Shanghai nearly five days ago and this is the first moment where I have had a chance to breath and assess. These past few days have been overwhelming, but not as a result of culture shock or even exploring, but rather, with work. This semester I am in a unique situation for students at NYU Shanghai because I am both a study away student and a Resident Assistant. While my fellow classmates spent the first three days in China with orientation sessions and the chance to learn about their new academic facilities and surrounding city, I was busy training for at least eight hours each day. By the time my fellow RAâ€™s and I were dismissed at the end of every day there was nothing that I wanted to do other than sleep. So, until recently, I have been without cell service, a bank account, food, laundry detergent, a transportation card, a clear understanding of this city and my new school, or enough blankets to combat the extreme cold.

By no means am I trying to complain. I love every second I am here! Because even without all of those things, I have spent every day in China with a combination of Chinese national and international students who live and study in Shanghai and who are some of the best people I have ever met. Anique gave me a plug adapter so I could charge my laptop. Shari bought me milk, cereal, and fruit so I wouldnâ€™t be hungry in the mornings. Myra was my guide and translator as I triedâ€”and failedâ€”to get cell service. There was no grace period when I arrived in Shanghai, but I would not have it any other way. I still do not have a bank account, a working cell phone, or an extra blanket as I face another night at below freezing temperatures, but I have been spoiled by the people in my new environment that have made me feel safe and welcome. I will not be able to do enough to thank them while I am in Shanghai, so I sincerely hope they choose to study away in New York in the future so that I can repay them for everything they have done for me.

While so far my time in Shanghai has been heavily focused on work and classes, I know that my situation is an amazing opportunity to integrate myself into this community and embrace my new environment.

Best,

Matthew Gibson

I landed in Prague last night after two relatively uneventful plane rides.Â 

My first leg of the trip went well! I landed in Frankfurt after an 11 hour flight that went pretty smoothly. There was little turbulence, and I spent the time reading TenÂ Thousand Skies Above by Claudia Gray and watching a few movies (Julie and Julia, The Maze Runner: Scorch Trials, and Straight Outta Compton). Unfortunately, due to jetlag, I couldnâ€™t find it in me to sleep longer than a couple hours (something that would really bite me in the ass later).Â 

After I landed in Frankfurt, I was solely focused on getting to my gate. The walk from the terminal our plane landed in to the next gate took forever! I was so surprised how large the airport was. The other thing that surprised me was the ease at which I passed through customs. There was a small border gate with a nonexistent line. The guard (who looked like a young Michael Fassbender *swoon*) barely looked at my passport, asked me pleasantly if I was going to Prague to study, and sent me on my way. It took all of 5 minutes. After that, I had to pass through another security checkpoint. This took a little longer, mostly due to my poor planning. 1) I hadnâ€™t emptied my water bottle that Iâ€™d filled in San Francisco, so I had to chug the whole thing before passing through this next gate. 2) I didnâ€™t take out my Kindle when I sent my backpack through the scanner. In the U.S., I never had any problems leaving my e-Readers in my backpack, so I was surprised when the guard got angry at me for leaving mine in my backpack.Â 

After all the hassle at the security checkpoint, I found my gate about an hour and a half before boarding. I could already tell who was an NYU student and who wasnâ€™t (mainly by who was young and speaking American English). Our plane got delayed for boarding by another 45 minutes due to inclement weather in Prague.Â 

The flight to Prague was short – only 40 minutes in the air. It still hadnâ€™t hit me yet that I was going to be living in a foreign country for the next 4 months! I was more concerned about finding my luggage and getting to the dorm in one piece. Luckily, after I landed, I was able to get both of my suitcases without any problems (#blessed) and found the NYU Prague staff waiting for us at the airport. There were a lot of us on the Frankfurt flight, and it was clear that we were all exhausted from our journeys. While waiting for the Prague shuttle, we all were gathered in a sort of miniature herd based on our dorms. It was mostly silent although there was some small talk that essentially served to keep us alert.Â 

I almost fell asleep on the shuttle ride to my dorm, Osadni. The one thing I noticed was that the radio station playing in the shuttle played mostly American pop songs. I wonder if thatâ€™s because of Western media dominance in Central Europe or if the driver wanted to please our American music palettes. Â

There is so much snow outside that itâ€™s hard to believe Iâ€™ll be going anywhere let alone leaving for the other side of the world tomorrow. To give you some perspective, Iâ€™ve taken these photos from the warmth and comfort of my suburban Pennsylvania home.

The snow started around 7 PM last night and is still going. Weather forecasts say that itâ€™ll keep up till 1 AM tonight. So far, my flight has yet to be cancelled (fingers crossed that it doesnâ€™t!) but Iâ€™m still monitoring the flight status closely.

Edit: My flight was delayed by 9 hours……………………… More on that here.

A little bit about my flight.

Economy seat on Cathay Pacific from JFK to Hong Kong International Airport. 5 hour layover. Then HKG to SYD. Then, the same coming back with a 1 hour layover at the end of the semester. Iâ€™d put off buying my tickets until only a month before my departure so I was looking for the best price that I could find. After hours of scouring the internet (on Incognito mode! - thanks Saemin and Erica), I found that usually, Google Flights is a good place to look for the best deal, but I ended up buying my roundtrip tickets fromÂ StudentUniverse. Roundtrip tickets from Australia usually cost around $1,300 to $1,500 + tax and looking 2 to 3 months in advance will really help you in getting the best price.

As far as luggage goes,

Iâ€™m allowed two pieces of checked baggage that are 50 lbs. each - which Iâ€™d finished packing yesterday. According to one article, I should pack like Iâ€™m heading to California. (Both places enjoy warm weather and an active lifestyle.) However, by the time I leave the only continent-nation in the world, it will be fall. Temperature highs in Australia in January average around high 80s. In May, they average mid 60s. So even though Australia alludes an eternal summer in imagination, I had to pack knowing that it will get a bit chilly toward the end of my stay.

I also had to make sure that I didnâ€™t pack too much because usually, I am either over-prepared or grossly under-prepared. (Thereâ€™s really no middle ground…) I tried to mix the way I packed for Buenos Aires, Argentina 3 weeks ago with my September in New York looks. Hopefully, Iâ€™m moderate-prepared this time.

Corradiâ€™s Corner is a monthly segment in which NYU Sociology Professor Juan Corradi takes on an issue relevant to undergraduates. This weekâ€™s edition tackles division, isolation, and social relations.

The lament is familiar. The major political parties fail to attain compromises and instead engage in demonizing each other. Â Extremists and demagogues who indulge in vituperation sometimes seize them. The citizenry, and especially the young, feel disaffected from the entire political process. Â Observers attribute the current stalemate to a host of vices: the corrupting influence of big money, the circus of the primaries, the manipulation of voting districts, and the rise of social media, which divides rather than unites groups of potential voters. Â 

This is probably all true, but it stays on the surface level of politics and far away from our mundane concerns. Â I suspect it mirrors what goes on underneath. The term â€œgerrymanderingâ€ (named after a long forgotten governor of Massachusetts) means to divide a territorial unit into election districts to give one political party an electoral majority in a large number of districts while concentrating the voting strength of the opposition in as few districts as possible. But arenâ€™t we doing the same in social relations, the very fabric of our daily lives? Â I wish to submit to you the following paradox in our age of social media: Â the more we stay connected with friends, acquaintances, and strangers, the more we isolate ourselves into gated virtual communities of like-minded people. Â Connectivity leads to fragmentation. In social media life resembles a kaleidoscope of solicitations, and we seek temporary refuge in fickle tribes, which are the electronic districts of the similarly inclined.

Â When we go beyond the fickle in search of the more stable and steadfast we land in the domain of identity politics. But this makes a bad situation worse. Communication does not improve. If and when these â€œtribesâ€ have to share a public domain, if they are to avoid a war of all against all, they agree on a compact of mutual respect that goes under the rubrics of â€œdiversityâ€ and â€œtolerance.â€ Â But at what price? Â The upshot is often a reluctance to say anything that might offend somebody, and so the common language descends to the level of the anodyne. We have a surfeit of messages, but we are starved of conversation. Â Certain names, books, topics and tropes are to be avoided in the name of a supposed harmony among those who do not really wish to engage each other in genuinely common pursuits. Â This is especially perverse in the case of institutions of higher learning that once were proud of the title of liberal arts. Â For decades these bastions of academic freedom protected the different and unpopular from the pressures of outside orthodoxy. Â But recently many of these former bastions want to protect insiders from each other, lest they make each other uncomfortable with opinions that are not a repetition of their own. Â 

The guardians of the new orthodoxy are bureaucrats, not teachers. Â Socrates no longer roams the corridors making everybody uncomfortable with challenging questions. Â An army of professionals is replacing the search for veritas by the management of in loco parentis. Â Since colleges are very expensive undertakings in an increasingly unequal and competitive world, and since they are run like a business, there is a natural tendency to please customers more than to engage students. Â As in the enclaves of Club Mediterranee, everything should be smooth, uncontroversial, and comfortable â€“at a hefty price.

We risk moving from collegium to Club Ed. The old ideal was of colleges and universities helping to think creatively and enrich the spiritual and intellectual life of faculty and students. Â The new model is reduced to a bunch of practical skills plus entertainment, with a supplement of the therapeutic. Â Caveat emptor: Â Some daring instructor (soon to be suspended) might assign On Liberty by John Stuart Mill!

Learn more about Professor Juan E Corradi here.

Anyway, here are my must-have items:
-medicine
~ this includes but is not limited to eye drops, cough drops, cold medicine, allergy medication, etc.
There are, of course, medicines in Italy, but I’ve noticed that it doesn’t hurt to be prepared with something that you trust to get rid of that unavoidable and annoying cough or cold that creeps around at the beginning of the semester.
-luggage locks
~ yes this may be an item that you already use to secure your luggage but the trick is to bring extra locks for back packs (when staying in hostels or airbnbs to secure your belongings) or to have just in case one of your friends needs it.
-phone plan
~ let’s face it, most of our communication takes place with our phones. I personally recommend either unlocking your phone before your departure if you know that you want to get a monthly plan when you arrive at your destination or asking your home provider if they have a plan that might work for you abroad.
-money
~this sounds like a no brainer but go into study abroad with a financial plan which includes your budget. Always have a plan B in case something goes wrong. I would not recommend money wiring, but I would highly suggest that you obtain some sort of bank account which someone back home also has access to because that way they can step in and help just in case something goes wrong.
-personal hygiene care items
~if you have a favorite toothpaste, deodorant, feminine care product, skincare item, etc you might want to bring it because chances are that you won’t find that exact same product abroad.
-positive mindset
~ this is extremely important because you need to be open-minded in order to make the most of the incredible adventure that you are about to embark on. There will be ups and downs, but what matters the most is you learning and making the most of every experience that comes your way.

Happy travels!
Un bacio,
-Amy

Iâ€™m teaching a 7-week class at NYU Shanghai calledÂ â€˜Expressing Dataâ€™. Here is the syllabus of the class:

Expressing Data

Mon/Wed 4:00pm - 5:30pm

Course Description

Human beings are producing, consuming and sharing data at any given moment. However, what kinds of data are meaningful to us? How do we capture and collect that data? What are the best ways to present it? What stories do we want to tell with data? This course will explore these questions and more. Students will learn basic techniques for data collection and filtering. Student projects can be digital, physical, visual, musical, or (with approval) take any form imagined.
Prerequisite: Interaction Lab

Learning Objectives

* Students will understand data compositions behind objects.
* Students will learn basic technologies of capturing and visualizing data.
* Students will explore online data through APIs.

Assignments

There are 4 assignments and 1 final project in this course. In the first 4 weeks, students will capture one data series per week, sketch out the data in paper as Monday assignment; learn some related computer technology, and sketch out the same data in code as Wednesday assignment.
* Week 1: Capture data about stuff you eat or drink in text
* Week 2: Take photos about people or things you see
* Week 3: Record audios about sound you listen
* Week 4: Track locations about places you go

From week 5 to week 7, students will learn technologies related to larger dataset and work on their final projects.

Readings

‘The Visual Display of Quantitative Information’ by Edward Tufte
* Chapter 4 ( Page 90 - 105 )
* Chapter 6 ( Page 122 - 137 )
* Chapter 9 ( Page 176 - 191 )

'Envisioning information’ by Edward Tufte
* Chapter 3 ( Page 52 - 65 )
* Chapter 5 ( Page 80 - 95 )

Grading

Grades will be determined based on the following breakdown:
* 20% Attendance & Participation
* 60% Assignments & Exercises
* 20% Final Project

Attendance

Attendance in all classes is mandatory. Unexcused absences and tardiness will effect your grade. Please let me know ahead of time so that I can help you determine how to make up the material. Cellphones not permitted in class.

Weekly Breakdown

* Week 1
Â  * Introduction, Text Visualization Inspirations, Data Formats
Â  * Charts, Color, Shape and Typography in Data Visualization
* Week 2
Â  * Assignments Review, Image Visualization Inspirations, Image Capture
Â  * Image Process and Visualization Techniques
* Week 3
Â  * Assignments Review, Audio Visualization Inspirations, Audio Capture
Â  * Audio Process and Visualization Techniques
* Week 4
Â  * Assignments Review, Location Visualization Inspirations, Location Capture
Â  * Location Data Process and Visualization Techniques
* Week 5
Â  * Assignments Review, Using APIs
Â  * Workshop
* Week 6
Â  * Collecting and Filtering Data
Â  * Workshop
* Week 7
Â  * Workshops
Â  * Final Projects

Links

In film school, I got my first taste of being a director and it changed me.Â 

It was my TV Production class. Iâ€™d written the script, assembled the crew, cast all the parts and now it was time to direct. On the first day of shooting I actually showed up to set early. Not on time - early. I wore sensible shoes with a small heel and I sat in the control room drinking coffee and going over the shot list as everyone else arrived and congregated around the craft table (food).Â 

When it was time to roll camera I felt this surge rush through me like electricity. Iâ€™d never felt that kind of power in my life and - not gonna lie - I liked it. It did something for me. It did something to me.

Something like made me an asshole. Kind of.

Most directors have a reputation for being bullheaded and temperamental. I guess I had those moments over the years. But I wasnâ€™t an asshole and it only happened when I was feeling particularly passionate about the project. Thatâ€™s just the nature of being a director though.Â 

But I remember walking to set at 721 Broadway for day 2 of shooting when I ran into him. This guy Iâ€™d had a massive crush on since freshman orientation 2 years prior. The first time I laid eyes on him he was singing in the Black Student Union office. I just about melted at the sound of his voice. It was the end of everything for me. He knew it too. He knew I wanted him. He did not return those feelings though he did mess with my head for five years, but I digress.Â 

He intercepted me just as I was about to enter the building. We made small talk. I told him about my project. Or rather, I boasted about how awesome the project was going. For once, my mind was not on him and getting in his pants. I was thinking about my set, my crew, my actors. I was in director mode. I guess it came off as arrogant to this guy. Because he said so. He actually said I was being arrogant and I shouldnâ€™t let this whole film business â€œgo to my head.â€Â 

Instantly, a switch went off in my brain.Â 

From that moment on I vowed I would not let the film business â€œgo to my head.â€ Like a robot, my brain kept repeating that in my head over and over again until it stuck. Until I had it in my body. I went through the next couple of years of my career putting that into practice just in case he would see me in action again. Just in case Iâ€™d have the opportunity to show him Iâ€™d heeded his advice. Just in case it would make him love me.Â 

Keep in mind I was 20. I was horny for this guy, I was young and most importantly, I was dumb. If anyone was to say something like this to me today I would spit in their face. Because I wasnâ€™t being arrogant or a jerk or rude. I was simply distracted and excited about shooting my project,which Iâ€™d graciously taken the time to talk to him about despite my being in a hurry to get to set. He just didnâ€™t like the fact that I wasnâ€™t drooling all over him.Â 

But of course I didnâ€™t know that at the time.Â 

At one point, sometime after graduating, this guy and I had a falling out and we havenâ€™t spoken since. I donâ€™t actively try to remember him or anything he ever said to me. In fact, most days I donâ€™t think of him at all. But every once in awhile, I find myself checking in with myself. Asking the usual questions,Â â€œis there a kinder way I can phrase this? Am I coming across as arrogant? Will this upset someone if I say this? How can I shrink myself so that I seem humble and not intimidating?â€Â 

I try to stop those thoughts. To remind myself that I am a kind person and I donâ€™t intentionally try to hurt others. But when Iâ€™m reminding myself of that fact that I see myself and I know who I am better than that guy or anyone ever did or ever will, Iâ€™m thinking about him and that moment outside of Tisch.Â 

Itâ€™s funny what sticks with you no matter how hard you work to forget.

I know now that changing who I am wonâ€™t make someone love me. He will never love me. So I donâ€™t need to replay that moment in my head ever again. I donâ€™t need to hold on to that unsolicited, inappropriate and unnecessary piece of advice.Â 

But one good thing came from that interaction. Iâ€™m always actively trying to practice kindness. Because as the saying goes, people may forget what you did and what you said but theyâ€™ll never forget how you made them feel.Â 

I want people who work with me to always have a good feeling about me. If not love me. (just kidding)Â

On Sept. 11, students and faculty gathered in the Shanghai Symphony Hall to watch the much-anticipated NYU Shanghai Reality Show performed by 12 brave and open-minded NYU Shanghai students. NYUâ€™s president, John Sexton, who will soon pass his position on to Andrew Hamilton, spoke a few words before the performance. He primarily praised NYUSH students for taking a â€œless conventional pathâ€ in their higher education.

â€œThe theme of [the Reality Show] is, weâ€™re here for each other,â€ said Sexton. â€œWe just need you to know that there are other people out there that care about you. Maybe youâ€™ll remember something that was saidâ€”or a song from the show.â€

First written eleven years ago in New York City, this yearâ€™s Reality Show encompassed a wide range of topics relevant to any NYU student. Executed in several skits accompanied by songs and choreography, the show ultimately conveyed the message that NYU is, in fact, â€œhere for you,â€ as Sexton said. No matter what problem an NYU student encounters â€“academic, health, social, or culturalâ€“ there is always hope and, as the show repeatedly points out, help can be found simply by calling the schoolâ€™s Health and Wellness Center. Â 

The show also emphasizes that NYUSH is unlike any other college in the world because of its international community. One of the first musical skits â€“a piece about roommatesâ€“ demonstrated that overcoming cultural barriers requires a willingness to embrace and understand one anotherâ€™s differences. The show also included other relevant topics such as sexual consent, safe drinking, peer competition, fiscal responsibility, and body image.

The baseball skit threw the audience into uncontrollable laughter, as performers (Lilly Korinek, Oscar Fossum) educated a young student (Ben Weilun Zhang) about the rules of playing baseball, a euphemism for safe sex. â€œWhen you hit a home run, make sure that your gloveâ€™s on,â€ sang Fossum.

â€œSo the whole point of baseball is getting a home run?â€ asked Ben Weilun Zhang.

â€œWell, getting a home run is great, but some people donâ€™t get past first base for a long time. Just remember to have fun and respect the other teamâ€¦ Good luck, kid,â€ responded Korinek.

After a moment of silent confusion, Zhang responded: â€œWaitâ€“ these kids are talking about baseball? Iâ€™m just looking for a condomâ€¦â€ The comment resulted in thunderous laughter.

Another skit satirized the academic pressure that many NYU students feel on a daily basis, which is influenced by the competitive environment fostered by their peers. Defne Inhan, in a skit about peer competition, â€œcreated world peace.â€ â€œI created intergalactic peace,â€ shouted Cheryl Li in response. This type of competitive attitude is prevalent at many prestigious universities, and NYU is no exception. Â Sometimes it can be overwhelming when everyone is talking about internships, company start-ups, and building resumes when one is simply trying to pass a certain class. â€œDonâ€™t waste your energy trying to be better than others,â€ concluded Korinek in a public-service announcement, similar to the type that followed each performance.

The show lasted about two hours, and if laughter were bricks, the performance could have built the Great Wall of China. Still, a few skits illuminated the more serious aspects of college life, such as abusive relationships and drug use, which the audience met with respective and completive silence. Â 

â€œI thought the Reality Show was a very genuine portrayal of life in Shanghai both for students and people in general. I appreciated the honesty in which the performances presented themselves on stage, and as an audience member I felt engaged as well as touched by various moments throughout the show,â€ said Lou Demetroulakos â€™19 when asked about the show.

Orsi Liddiard â€™19 said: â€œI thought they approached the topics in a very relatable way, meaning that people could understand what was going in in the show, and while doing so, draw parallels between the show and their own lives at NYU Shanghai.â€

The Reality Show not only educated the audience about relevant social topics, but also entertained. Ultimately, the Reality Showâ€™s greatest accomplishment was the encapsulation of the enterprising spirit of NYUSHâ€”diversity, inventiveness, ingenuousness, and fallibility. As Sexton said, â€œIf itâ€™s legal and moral do it once. Play another octave of the piano. Reach out to different people. Thatâ€™s the vision of NYUSH and its global network.â€

Josh Fattal was one of three Americans detained by Iranian troops on July 31, 2009. He was hiking in Iraqi Kurdistan with friends Shane Bauer and Sarah Shourd when a border guard accused them of illegal entry into Iran. The three were later imprisoned and charged with spying. Fattal spent 781 days in an Iranian prison, 100 of those in solitary confinement. He was released on September 21, 2011. Josh Fattal is now a PhD candidate in NYU’s history department, studying jurisdictional tensions, or how various forms of government (local, state, national) respond to similar issues. He lives in South Brooklyn with his partner, Jenny Borhman, and their son, Isaiah Azad Fattal. Azad means “freedom” in Farsi. Fattal, with Bauer and Shourd, is a co-author of the 2014 memoir “A Sliver of Light: Three Americans Imprisoned in Iran.”

NYU â€” home to people from all walks of life. Just by hanging around or talking to students on campus, you can get a feel for the NYU lifestyle pretty quickly. While weâ€™re all a little different, we canâ€™t help but notice some similarities among those we see and meet at NYU.


The Born and Raised

Their navigation of the subway is flawless and their sense of fashion sophisticated. Their excitement to be in the City for Welcome Week is barely noticeable compared to yours. Who are they? New Yorkers, and itâ€™s easy to tell.


The Low-Key Celebrity

They may not be famous themselves, but their phone full of A-listers might convince you otherwise. Their #tbt is a picture of them sitting on Martin Scorseseâ€™s lap, and that late night Facebook check-in is tagged with Lorde.Â 


The One Who LOVES New York City

Studying in New York is great â€” no doubt about that â€” and they make it well known. Well, at least their Instagram does. Itâ€™s an agglomeration of overfiltered pictures of the Manhattan skyline with lengthy captions about how the city has changed them. Weâ€™ll cut them some slack, because we totally get it.


The Purple Bleeder

Theyâ€™ve been involved with student leadership before classes even started, attend all undergrad events, and have enough NYU swag to dress in purple for a couple weeks straight. We kinda admire their Violet pride, tbh.


The Bobstworm

You donâ€™t know their names, you donâ€™t know their years, but you know their faces. You always see them in that same spot at Bobst â€” studying, eating, or sleeping â€” whether itâ€™s the first week of classes or the last day of finals. But if you always see them there, arenâ€™t you a Bobstworm too?


The Incoming Transfer

You know youâ€™re talking to a transfer student when youâ€™re both juniors and they donâ€™t know how to pronounce Bobst. But weâ€™ll let that slide, because they made the smart choice to transfer from wherever they were before.


The Outgoing Transfer

You should have seen it coming ; they had been wearing that Columbia sweatshirt for a while now.


The Singer

They bring Broadway to your bedroom. They play multiple instruments, practice their arpeggios every morning, and sing in the dining halls around their singer peers. Theyâ€™re your enemy at 7AM on a Monday, and your best friend at karaoke at 1AM on a Saturday.


The Student Film Director

They collect tripods and camera lenses and are usually seen in Washington Square Park giving directions to a confused group of â€œactors.â€ Theyâ€™re always on the lookout for â€œactorsâ€ such as you, humble student. Get ready.


The Artsy One

Studying a blend of social sciences and visual arts courses, they are always up-to-date on the latest happenings of the many underground worlds. Every social media platform they use is a collection of abstract art photographs captioned with elusive phrases that leave you confused. Theyâ€™re just on a different level.


The Vegetarian

While their motives may vary, they all carefully monitor their diets and make sure everyone is aware of it. You sometimes wonder if theyâ€™re serious when asking for the vegetarian menu at Just Salad…?


The Business Student

Theyâ€™re often found walking in packs, wearing the business attire they received for Christmas with their computer briefcases in hand and business card ready. How do you know they go to business school? Theyâ€™ll tell you.


The Entrepreneur

They try to attend as many networking events as possible, with the strong hope that their idea be the next Etsy.


The Greek Lifer

Yes, itâ€™s a thing here, despite our lack of frat houses and lawn parties. They move in packs and are actually some of the most tight knit communities at NYU.


The â€œPromoterâ€

Usually a friend of a friend, they have enough contacts to guarantee you *free* and awesome* NYU rooftop parties almost every night of the year if you say their name.


The Freshman

Lanyard.

It has been an interesting, emotionally, stressful last few months to say the least, but despite all that has happened I am leaving for Australia. I am about to embark on one the most amazing experiences of my life! I cannot wait. However, I felt the need to talk about the long journey that led to this day. So here goes…

When I got accepted to NYU Sydney, I was so excited to do study abroad! Then it hit me, I was going to have to pay a lot of money to make that happen. At the time my family was experiencing the worst financial issues we have ever had. However, due to my schedule this semester was the best time to study away. Also, I had already applied and been chosen to be the Student Government Site Ambassador for NYU Sydney and applied for the internship program. Study abroad was shaping up to be an amazing experience that I couldnâ€™t miss. My mom being the most amazing woman I know, vowed that we would get me there. She taught me the important lesson of determination and self belief! If it wasnâ€™t for her strength and support, I would never have been able to make it to Sydney. For that, and so much more, I will be forever grateful to her!

So I just finished my third semester, and classes are definitely getting more challenging.

I accomplished my goal of writing more comedy, and I think my confidence is slightly raising in that field! Which is great because thatâ€™s literally what I want to do for a career and I have to stop being so intimidated by it. I was writing more because I had to for some comedy classes I was in, so Iâ€™m hoping my motivation doesnâ€™t go away next semester!Â 

For those that donâ€™t know, Iâ€™m concentrating inÂ â€œpolitical satireâ€ in Gallatin, so I basically want to write and produce comedy for TV. Last semester I took 2 comedy classes, which really helped me focus on what I want to do. Iâ€™m taking fewer comedy-centric classes next semester, but Iâ€™m taking more classes to expand my concentration and studies as a whole. Hereâ€™s the breakdown:

1 TV writing class, in which Iâ€™m going to write a script for a half-hour comedy!
1 class thatâ€™s technically about politics (â€Politicsâ€ is in the title, but Iâ€™m taking this class mostly to satisfy 3 different requirements!!!)
1 Producing class for my producing minor, I think Iâ€™m also writing a TV script in this class, not too sure…
1 film class thatâ€™s a prereq for a comedy study abroad program Iâ€™m applying for! The study abroad program is literally calledÂ â€œComedy Writing and Production for Television,â€ so Iâ€™m realllllllly excited about it :)
And Iâ€™m taking a 2 credit course that I created about Political Satire in Late Night!!! Weâ€™ll be analyzing how shows like The Daily Show or the Colbert Report affect political activism and participation. This class is really going to help fine-tune my concentration!

I also switched advisors and the switch will be taking effect this semester! My new advisor is also conveniently teaching that TV writing class, and he teaches a lot of comedy writing, so Iâ€™m excited to learn a lot from him.

Overall, my studies are really pointing me in the direction that I want to go in, but Iâ€™m pretty clueless in the internship area. I need to get an internship somehow related to comedy, but the deadline to intern for most TV networks was months ago. Hopefully I can find an internship Iâ€™m passionate about!

I canâ€™t think of any other way to put it than to just come out and say it: Everything here has a been a complete dream. In every aspect, in every neighborhood, from every delicious meal to the treasured foggy mornings to the uke performers singing on the R train.Â 

I have a suitemate who likes to spark conversation with the same question, sometimes with the same people: Whatâ€™s been your best night here so far?
Just one? The best? I guess I should consider myself lucky to have too many best nights to count on one hand.

Every time I call my mom back home in California and tell her about my new favorite Brooklyn cafe, or the Frank Stella exhibit at the Whitney, or the extravagant Fifth Ave holiday window displays (you’re welcome Mom for the pictures), I know she gets a little envious of my young-girl-in-the-big-city endless vacation. She sometimes wishes we could trade spots. But what she doesn’t know is that I already have a head start on being her.

Each time I find myself enamored with the exposed brick interior of a tiny ramen shop, or taking pictures of the florist displays at the Union Square farmers market, or inside Anthropologie just to look at the interior design, I know Iâ€™ve grown into my momâ€™s world-traveled shoes. Except Iâ€™ve traded her mountain-hiking Asolos for concrete-tred Docs.

The center of the world, also known as Manhattan, is the most densely populated region in the United States. With so many people living and working in the same place, it is practically impossible to see and visit everything that it has to offer.Â 

The Empire State Building may have great views of #NYC, but this is better.

A photo posted by HashtagNYU (@hashtagnyu) on Jul 3, 2015 at 4:25pm PDT

After a while, however, things may get kind of repetitive, and there are many other boroughs for you to explore! Manhattan is just an island, after all.


Queens

The world is yours #NYU! #NYC

A photo posted by HashtagNYU (@hashtagnyu) on Sep 19, 2015 at 6:03am PDT

Flushing Meadows-Corona Park (7): The fourth-largest one in NYC, the park houses some very large (and very old) monuments that were constructed for the two World Fairs that took place in New York in 1939Â and 1964. Some of these installations include the Unisphere, the New York Pavilion, and the Queens Museum (free with your NYU Card!). Thereâ€™s also the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center and Citi Field, homes of the US Open and the Mets, respectively.Â 

MoMA PS1 (7, E, M): The MoMA contemporary art wing is not in its Manhattan home base, as this location allows for larger, more ambitious, and overall crazier works to be on display. The name PS1 comes from the buildingâ€™s previous name, the Public School #1 of NYC. As with the â€œregularâ€ MoMA, it is free for NYU students!


Staten Island

“We build too many walls and not enough bridges.” ~Isaac Newton

A photo posted by Helen (@leader_no_title) on Nov 3, 2015 at 2:11pm PST

Historic Richmond Town (Staten Island Ferry, S74 Bus): Sometimes new isnâ€™t always better. This living history village (think: Colonial Williamsburg) offers a window into the past with its original 17th and 18th century public and private buildings, as well as other activities such as pumpkin picking, country dancing, and candlelight tours. And this is all in Staten Island â€” who knew?!

Snug Harbor Cultural Center and Botanical Garden (Staten Island Ferry, S40 Bus): This former home for retired sailors dates all the way back to the 19th century has now been transformed into a modern facility with performing arts space and a botanical garden!


The Bronx

The old #NYU campus at University Heights. Such rich history and fame!

A photo posted by HashtagNYU (@hashtagnyu) on Apr 26, 2014 at 10:21am PDT

Bronx Zoo (5, 2): Home to more than 4,000 animals and 650 species, the Bronx Zoo is one of the most important and largest metropolitan zoos in the United States. It is a system of four different â€œsub-zoosâ€ and an aquarium, and some of the exhibits are free to the public, year-long!

New York Botanical Garden (4, 5, D): More than a simple â€œpark,â€ the Cityâ€™s botanical garden contains more than a million different plant species and is a National Historic Landmark. Because of its size and plant variety, it offers spectacular sights and seasonal exhibitions throughout the year, so be sure to visit it multiple times!


Brooklyn

Worth the subway ride. #NYU

A photo posted by HashtagNYU (@hashtagnyu) on Oct 4, 2015 at 1:47pm PDT

Prospect Park (2, 3): Designed by the same guys behind Central Park, this massive park is full of trails, meadows, lakes, and other miscellaneous attractions like a zoo, a boathouse, and even a villa.

Brooklyn Museum (2, 3, 4, 5): With more than 1.5 million works in its collection, the Brooklyn Museum is a place that cannot be ignored. It contains everything from Egyptian antiquities to cutting edge contemporary works. Plus, like the Met, itâ€™s pay-what-you-wish, all the time.

Brooklyn Bridge Park (A, C, F): You canâ€™t appreciate a forest if you only see the trees up close! The same goes with Manhattanâ€™s skyscrapers, as one of the best ways to truly appreciate its magnificent skyline is from a distance, and Brooklyn Bridge Park offers unparalleled views.

Brooklyn Botanic Garden (2, 3, 4, 5): Located next to Prospect Park, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden hosts outdoor exhibits as well as other activities and workshops year-round!

Coney Island (B, F, N, R, Q): A beach, boardwalk, and amusement park… What else can you ask for? This historic site is also home to one of the oldest roller coasters in the world!

I remember this time last year I was an anxious mess, still recovering from college apps and actually planning out scenarios in case I wasÂ rejected from every school, tear stains on my pillow, yet here I am in 2016, in the same spot on my bed, except I go to NYU and Iâ€™ve basically aced my first semester.

Iâ€™m always surprised when I read articles that reveal going to college might not be advantageous for some students due to the growing cost of higher education. Â I couldnâ€™t disagree more.

I tried to navigate life for fifteen years without having finished college. It was brutal. I never thought it would be because I came to New York to attend a two-year acting conservatory. I didnâ€™t mind working odd jobs when I first started out of the gate. I was all about â€œpaying my duesâ€. But as the years stacked, my â€œduesâ€ werenâ€™t moving me in the direction I had hoped. I soon realized I didnâ€™t have much to offer the working world. I had zero office skills. Without a degree, I was met with many closed doors of potential opportunities at media companies that might have offered a new perspective on life.

I grew envious and felt inferior to my peers who had completed their education. They appeared stronger at problem solving and critical thinking than I was. I was always searching for ways to make myself feel whole while I pursued acting. I challenged myself with situations that were not in my comfort zone, I traveled solo to Europe and Asia, I took tons of classes, attended various lectures and museum exhibits, but in my mind I was always coming up short and didnâ€™t know how to catch up.

For years going back to school was never an option that was on the table because I saw it as giving up on my passion to be the actress that brought me to New York in the first place.

Passing on learning in the classroom for 30 + courses came back to haunt me years later. It also meant I passed on all the programs that colleges offered to help develop students in myriad ways. I missed the opportunities to try new things in a safe environment, creating passion projects without being certain how, and hosting events within school clubs.

College creates a protected space to not know, fail, and build upon those lessons all in preparation to enter the world as a well-rounded individual. When you are out in the world, you are expected to know fundamental skills. You arenâ€™t equipped with an overstocked supply of highly credible potential mentors at your fingertips willing to help you navigate life the way you do when you are in a college or university setting.

Perhaps if there isnâ€™t a solution to offer students an affordable higher education, the shift needs to happen within the pressure society places on students to finish within a four-year period. Perhaps we need to create more programs where students can work full time to offset the debt. Perhaps we as a society need to encourage students to attend school at their own pace.

I think higher education is invaluable and a necessity that needs to be fought for with great vigilance to ensure it happens for each one of us. Â I don’t think the question should be if students should attend college; I think the question should be how we can restructure college to fit into the new mold into which our society is developing.

On December 20th, I received my official NYU Shanghai acceptance package. I was already expecting it, seeing as that I received a digital acceptance already on the 15th. The envelope included a cool brochure in the format of a passport which I found really cute. Inside the larger folder was a print of my acceptance letter and a pretty print of the Oriental Pearl Tower.

I am so exited about attending NYU Shanghai, despite some major financial and emotional hurdles. I know it will be a great experience and I just have to reach out and take it. Someone once said that if your dreams don’t scare you, they aren’t big enough. This dream is really scary for me, but it’s what I wanted and I’m beyond proud of myself and thankful for the opportunity.

Pretty much everything art-related happens in NYC at some point. Itâ€™s NBD or anything, but we have some of the countryâ€™s (the worldâ€™s!) best museums and galleries. Plus, many artists live in NYC, and weâ€™d say having Tisch and Steinhardt nearby is pretty sweet… Luckily you can seriously take advantage of NYCâ€™s art scene for super low cost â€” so go out and get #cultured.


Museums

The obvious starting point. It does not matter how many times you go to a certain museum, thereâ€™s always something new to see.Â 


A photo posted by HashtagNYU (@hashtagnyu) on Dec 17, 2015 at 12:21pm PST

NYUâ€™S MUSEUM GATEWAY: MoMA, New Museum, the Whitney, and tons more are all free with your NYU Card. For some of them, you can even skip the line and get some discounts because youâ€™re considered a member! (If you’re all about the free memberships, getting your IDNYC might be a good plan, too)

THE MET & BROOKLYN MUSEUM: Two absolutely canâ€™t-miss museums with art from all over the world and many time periods. Although these museums are not free per se, they do have a pay-what-you-wish policy all the time, so it is really up to you!


Galleries

Yep, they’re free! They might be intimidating at firstâ€¦ just remember you donâ€™t have to buy anything.


A photo posted by HashtagNYU (@hashtagnyu) on Oct 13, 2015 at 1:49pm PDT

GREY ART GALLERY: This gallery is one of NYUâ€™s most well-known (itâ€™s location in the Silver Center probably helps) but is really just one of the many that are part of NYUâ€™s extensive gallery network.

GAGOSIAN GALLERY: This famous galleryâ€™s NYC space is just one piece of its international network. If youâ€™re into modern and contemporary art, this is the place to be!

KATE WERBLE GALLERY: If youâ€™re looking for a more immersive experience, this is the gallery to go to. They have some awesome exhibitions that are definitely worth checking out!


Public Art

Temporary, site-specific works of art are a staple of many parks in the City. Be sure to see thme before they disappearâ€¦ *forever*


A photo posted by Brooklyn Bridge Park (@brooklynbridgepark) on Oct 31, 2015 at 10:37am PDT

BROOKLYN BRIDGE PARK: Jeppe Heinâ€™s #PleaseTouchtheArt project is great for your next profile pic and a new perspective on getting social through art.

MADISON SQUARE PARK: Fata Morgana is the name of Teresita FernÃ¡ndezâ€™s public art project up by Gramercy Green. Definitely worth checking out (and getting some Shake Shack afterwards)!

What should I wear today?

Why canâ€™t my group project partner work at my pace?

Should I tell the people in the back of the line that the Kimmel pasta station is out of alfredo sauce?

Is it okay that I want Upstein Chick-fil-A for the fourth meal in a row?

Are people in Bobst giving me strange looks or is that just my imagination?

No worries! I love answering questions about NYU.Â 

What is life at NYU like? Well, that very much depends on the person. There are a lot of clubs/organizations you can join. Some people work or find internships. I guess this leads into your next question: How hard is it to make friends/socialize with other students? Some people find it pretty hard. Because the thing with NYU is that you are living in a city. Thereâ€™s a whole lot of independence there and everyone is sort of doing their own thing. BUT. You still have all of your classes and there are the clubs I already mentioned. But for me, it was super easy. All thanks to study abroad. I spent my freshman year in London, then went right on to Florence. I actually just came back from another semester in London. Study abroad is a great chance to meet friends- there are less people and you are thrown into an environment where you can constantly go on trips or explore. Itâ€™s wonderful. *that doesnâ€™t mean that studying abroad is perfect, mind you. it can be quite difficult being away from your security net and that is totally normal*

Is it a safe environment? Oh yeah. The NY campus is in a really REALLY nice area of the city.Â 

Whatâ€™s it like being an English Major? SO MANY BOOKS. MUCH READING. WOW.Â 

No, but really. I love the classes that Iâ€™ve taken so far. You can get a lot of variety. Iâ€™ve studied Gothic Lit and Shakespeare. Irish Drama. Science Fiction. (along with the required classes).Â 

Feel free to ask any more questions!

Living in NYC is the gift that keeps on giving. It gives us a great place to live, a great place to go to school, and great stories to tell our friends back home. Since the City gives us so much, shouldnâ€™t we give something back?Â 


Luckily, there are so many ways to do that! Whether you want to lend a helping hand specifically at NYU or you want to give back to NYC as a whole, there are tons of opportunities to volunteer, especially during the holiday season.


If you totally #BleedViolet:

Saying you have #VioletPride is an understatement. You love NYU and youâ€™re always looking for more ways to get more involved. Take part in some of the University sponsored service events to volunteer with your fellow Bobcats!


If youâ€™re really, really busy:

Youâ€™re super busy this semester. Your schedule is jam-packed leaving you with very little free time. Worry not! You can fit volunteering into your schedule with ease. Use your study break to send some words of encouragements or help out with someoneâ€™s Wishlist.


If youâ€™re a total foodie:

Your Instagram is full food pictures and your list of restaurants you want to try is longer than youâ€™d like to admit. Let your passion for food inspire your service activity. Deliver meals and pantry items to families in need!


If you’re a bit of a hoarder collector:

Your closest has been overflowing since Move-In Day and your desk space hasnâ€™t been used for anything but extra storage for weeks. Maybe itâ€™s time to pair it down. The 27th Annual New York Cares Coat Drive is the perfect opportunity to clean out your closet and give your gently-used coats to New Yorkers in need.


If youâ€™re a people person:

Some say youâ€™re too talkative, but maybe â€˜talkativeâ€™ is just another way of saying â€˜friendly.â€™ Nothing is more fun to you than hanging out and having casual conversation. With the City Meals On Wheels Friendly Visiting program you can put your small talk skills to good use.


If youâ€™re a dog person:

Youâ€™ve never walked past a dog without at least thinking about petting it. Whether big or small, all furry friends are *your* furry friends. Lend a helping hand, or paw, by volunteering to hang out with some adorable pups.


If youâ€™re indecisive:

If you canâ€™t decide on one service activity, why not do them all? New York Cares and NYC Service have tons of great volunteer opportunities so you donâ€™t have to limit yourself to just one.

Striving to Be the Adinkra Crocodile

In Accra, it is very common to find all kinds of symbols that have very important meanings that are called Adinkra Symbols. The symbols represent many objects and animals, but it is the deeper meaning that makes this system of symbols absolutely incredible. Upon first learning about them, I immediately decided that the one I liked best was the â€œDenkyemâ€ or the crocodile. It represents adaptability because the crocodile lives in water, but breathes air. The animal is able to adapt and thrive to both environments.

Basically, I applied to for an exchange program exclusive for Phd students at my university with the New York University, and I got accepted. I will be granted with exemption from fees, and will be provided housing and a meal plan. I will still have to cover the plane tickets, and the Health Insurance, but I have some savings and also my university provides like an scholarship with a montly allowance, even though I will try to get into a teaching assistantship program because that will give me financial security and an extra points for my academic cv.

Still, I have to be accepted by the NYU and apply for my university scholarship, get through the visa, buy the tickets and preparing myself mentally for this challenge. Iâ€™ll be by my own, even though I have a friend living in NYC, I still get anxious about being abroad again, because of my Manchester experience. I especially find quite stressing the whole process of travelling, because of the USA borders checking and stuff.

Anyways, fingers crossed I get through everything I need in order to be safe and sound in NYC by september 2016. My thesisâ€™ director has already told me I will never be the same researcher again: weâ€™ll see how it goes. If everything goes right, Iâ€™ll be living the American dream for 10 months. I canâ€™t still believe it!

From Madison:

Packing for a Year of Study Abroad

Today is Sunday, August 2nd. On August 25th, I will be hopping on a plane to Istanbul, Turkey with no intention of returning to the United States until May/June 2016. After spending a few days in Istanbul, I will travel to Prague and spend a few more with family before heading off to Paris. For the next nine months, I will call Paris my home as I spend my first year at NYU studying in France.

Receiving my acceptance letter in March, my interest was piqued by the notion that I could spend my first year abroad. To be completely honest, NYU was one of my safety schools during the college application process. But after thoughtful consideration about who I am and the person I want to be, I decided to take the leap into New York City and (what I hope will be) the greatest experience of my life thus far. Studying abroad in Paris was definitely a major factor in my choice.

I personally love the NY campus. Itâ€™s not as spread out as some people make it out to be. Most of the academic buildings are centered around Washington Square Park and all of the freshmen dorms are easily within walking distance of WSP. (I canâ€™t speak to upperclassmen dorms as I now will be living off campus in Brooklyn). I donâ€™t feel like itâ€™s hard to get around at all though. From what I gather from visiting friends as moreÂ â€œtraditionalâ€ campuses, itâ€™s not really much more walking than any other campus.Â 

The WSP campus gives a sense of community but also immerses you in the city. I think itâ€™s important that you visit before you commit to going there just to make sure the Manhattan life is for you. But if you enjoy the city, you will love NYU.Â

You know how the whole point of Man Repeller is to wear clothes that, well, repel men? Iâ€™ve loved that website for as long as Iâ€™ve had this blog, even though I may have taken the wholeÂ â€œsartorially offensiveâ€ thing a bit too far in the beginning, from middle school up through sophomore year. The point, however, is that these jeans are the most divisive garment I own (aside from the glasses): boysÂ hateÂ them and girls loveÂ them, which makes me love them even more.

I feel like NYU has cemented the look that I worked so hard to cultivate throughout high school: constantly disheveled, perpetually late, hair unbrushed, bags under eyes, black coffee in hand–in short, a mess. When Caroline came to visit me, she took a photo, which isÂ too embarrassing to post here, of me, having just woken up, wearing a sports bra and a pair of sweatpants and looking emaciated and exhausted. She captioned it,Â â€œThe NYU aesthetic.â€Â I guess what Iâ€™m trying to say is that Iâ€™ve always been a mess, except here, itâ€™s a look.

My first semester at NYU comes to a close in less than 2 weeks as I finish up my finals and head back to the midwest. People say that in college you grow up quickly and change incredibly, but I didnâ€™t necessarily find that the case. Rather, I felt that my perception of the world changed radically. The fall of 2015 wasnâ€™t exactly a cake walk for the rest of the world. Between mass shooting, discrimination, terrorism, and a litany of various other atrocities, the world stood watching, waiting, and saying what they felt. As I dived into my first semester of higher education during such a point in history, I couldnâ€™t hep but feel the tumultuousness of the times. Yet, as a quiet observer of such events, I realized how alike everyone was. We all act attempting for the well-being of the world. Every person goes about this in different ways, but we really all want the same thing. As this unsettling and dangerous year comes to an end, nevertheless opening another year to bear similar surprise, it would do us all well to look at the world in a broader context and know that weâ€™re all doing different things to achieve the same ends. Our differences are only marginal.

Thanksgiving in Prague was amazing! My friend from home came to visit for the weekend. She goes to St. Johnâ€™s in Queens but is also studying abroad this semester. We thought that it was nice to have a little bit of home for the holiday.

The food we made was amazing! There was green bean casserole, sweet potatoes, mashed potatoes, chili, salad, creamed corn, roasted veggies, stuffing and chicken/turkey from a restaurant around the corner. For dessert there was pumpkin pie, pumpkin cheesecake and apple pie! (My mom had to send me the pumpkin puree from the states lol). Given the circumstances and the fact that itâ€™s hard to find certain ingredients in this country, the whole day turned out to be great.Â 

The next day, a few friends and I went to Budapest for the weekend! We rented a little Skoda (we called it the Skoda that could), crossed through Slovakia and made it to Hungary! I love it there. The architecture is amazing, the Danube is actually blue (like a sea-green blue) and the Christmas markets were in full swing! I had the best hot apple cider Iâ€™ve ever had in my life there.Â 

All in all, a solid holiday weekend â¤ï¸

Last week, residents from NYC in the 60s had the opportunity to attend John Lennonâ€™s 70th Birthday Tribute Concert in Madison Square Garden with FA Cynthia. Greenwich Resident Elisabeth Moiso shared a bit about her experience below!:Â 

Seated in the intimate concert hall, the same room that I would soon share with living legends, Yoko Ono and Willie Nelson, among many others, I realized just how lucky I was to be a part of this school and to be a resident on this floor. Since this was a tribute show, each artist performed one song by themselves and then a second song with some of the other performers, leading up to a finale with all of the performers. This was a new format for me, but, as each artist and song was carefully chosen, each performer was better than the last, and I was left in awe. This being said, the performers who made the biggest impact on me were not these Grammy-winning artists and songwriters, but the members of the various New York-based organizations showcased, including the Stuttering Association for the Young and the New York Freedom Choir, which accompanied some of the other performers for Happy Xmas (War is Over) and Power to the People, respectively. These choirs demonstrated the strength and the love that John Lennon encouraged and showed just how powerful his legacy is. He would have been overjoyed to hear these amazing voices sing the songs that meant so much to him. This program was so special and it is something that I will continue to reflect on and remember throughout my life. John Lennonâ€™s messages of love and peace are timeless, necessary, and were played out in this awe-inspiring event. -Â  Elisabetta Moiso

This isnâ€™t something I do as a form of routine. And I donâ€™t know how to generally explain it. So Iâ€™ll just talk about how this came to be for this particular reason.

Iâ€™m currently writing a story where one of my characters attends NYU. Being that I have never been on an NYU campus, I needed to see what a typical NYU dorm may look like. Low and behold, theyâ€™re all bloody different depending on the building & neighborhood, but thatâ€™s goodÂ â€˜ol Manhattan for you.

So I searched on youtube and I watched one video with two girls and the next with a guy who is seemingly a pro skater. His video was more quirky & humorous and I thoroughly enjoyed it. His roommate James was filming the video and he introduced him briefly. I donâ€™t know what it was about James but I was interested. I always felt that NYU students had more going on about them than any other college. Itâ€™s NYC, everyone is artsy in some form. I wanted to know more about James lol. So I found out heâ€™s a film student…that was a plus. Not to mention he had a rad hairdo & facial scruff going on…another plus. By now I feel like a stalker but who cares, heâ€™s interesting and I found his Vimeo account because (1) heâ€™s a film student, of COURSE heâ€™s gonna be on Vimeo and (2) I wanted to check out his filming style considering Iâ€™ll be going back to college soon as a film major (hopefully, still waiting to see). Anyway…

I guess the overall bottom line is that I notice the people in the background. I stumble upon people and I see what their friends are about because, despite how much I might be against the whole liking-human-beings type of thing, I know there are some very interesting people walking this earth. You know, the type that do NOT deserve to be put on an island with no food. Awesome people still exist! So…thatâ€™s a thing I do once in a blue moon. Itâ€™s fun. Itâ€™s like how people watch a youtube video and 2 hours later, theyâ€™re watching a cat fight a laser.

Anyhoo…I thought Iâ€™d share one of Jamesâ€™s videos in an upcoming post. We may not know each other, James, but I hope you get far in life or wherever your heart desires.

Especially during midterms and finals, Bobst becomes an honorary NYU residence hall. During the day, itâ€™s a lively ecosystem with an ever-changing cast of characters studying for an hour or two before heading to their next location. But at night, it changes. Into the wee hours of the night, no one is at Bobst just to pass the time, they’re there to workâ€¦ or at least pretend to work. Here are the NYU students you inevitably will see in Bobstâ€¦ at night.



The Sleeper

Whether theyâ€™re snuggled up in a comfy chair theyâ€™ve managed to claim or hunched over a desk, this person can be found on any floor of Bobst on any day of the year. We get it though, itâ€™s been a long day.


The Insomniac

This person has obviously been awake for 24+ hours. Their unblinking eyes have overcome the heaviness of exhaustion and just vowed to stay open for the rest of eternity. Most commonly seen during exam season.Â 



The Texter

This person has been on their phone for two hours straight! Who are you texting so furiously right now? Hopefully a study partner?


The Disappearing Act

Their stuff has been taking up a cubicle space all night, yet they are nowhere to be found. Did they get lost on the way to the printer? Did they swing by home to grab dinner? Did they never really exist at all? Weâ€™ll never know…



The Casual Diner

We didnâ€™t think it could be done but this person managed to bring a full five-course meal into the confines of Bobst. Not only have they enjoyed it all at their study spot, they also have a array of snacks set aside for pre- and post-meal consumption. Hey, wanna share?


The Social Butterfly

Itâ€™s a misconception that Bobst is eerily quiet at night. Itâ€™s actually quite loud thanks to this person. They REALLY need to explain to the people around them how stressed they are for their essay due in four days. Shhhhhh!



The Speaker System

We get it. Hotline Bling is a total jamâ€¦ buuuuuuuut we REALLY need you to turn your music down.


The Resident

For this person, Move-In Day wasnâ€™t in August, it was on the day they decided that they might as well just stay in Bobst. Maybe just being in the presence of books will help the knowledge soak in?



The Procrastinator

Does anyone know if this person is a film major? We canâ€™tÂ sure… What we do know is that theyâ€™ve been watching films and shows on their computer screen since theyâ€™ve sat down. What are they really in Bobst for? The WiFi?


The Ideal Studier

No quirks or distracting habits. Just quietly studying for their upcoming test or writing a paper they put off for a little too long. Get your study on, friend.

Language of the Birds: Occult and Art

80WSE Gallery, New York University
January 12 â€“ February 13, 2016

Curated by Pam Grossman

Opening reception: Wednesday, January 13, 6 â€“ 8pm
Hours: Tuesday â€“ Saturday from 10:30am â€“ 6pm

Language of the Birds: Occult and Art considers over 60 modern and contemporary artists who have each expressed their own engagement with magical practice. Beginning with Aleister Crowleyâ€™s tarot paintings and Austin Osman Spareâ€™s automatic drawings of the 1920s, the exhibition traces nearly a century of occult art, including Leonora Carrington and Kurt Seligmannâ€™s surrealist explorations, Kenneth Anger and Ira Cohenâ€™s ritualistic experiments in film and photography, and the mystical probings of contemporary visionaries such as Francesco Clemente, Kiki Smith, Paul Laffoley, BREYER P-ORRIDGE, and Carol Bove.

The concerns and influences of each of these artists are as eclectic as the styles in which they work. While several of the pieces deal with â€œhighâ€ or ceremonial magic, others draw from so-called â€œlow magicâ€ practices and have deeply chthonic roots. The approaches in technique are varying as well, with some doing years of research and preparation for the act of creation, and others working entirely intuitively. Regardless of method, Language of the Birds suggests that all are part of the same lineage: one that pulls on threads from the esoteric web of alchemy, Hermeticism, Spiritualism, Theosophy, divination and witchcraft.

The exhibition takes its name from the historical and cross-cultural notion that there is a magic language via which only the initiated can communicate. Â Often referred to as the â€œlanguage of the birds,â€ it is a system rumored to operate in symbols, and to be a vehicle for revealing hidden truths and igniting metamorphic sparks.

The artists in Language of the Birds can be considered magicians, then, when seen through this mythopoeic lens. A visual vocabulary is offered up by them, so that we all might be initiated into their imaginal mystery cults and dialog with the ineffable. They speak to us in secret tongues, cast spells, and employ pictures for the purpose of activating profound change in both themselves and in us. Â By going within, then drawing streams of imagery forth through their creations, each of these artists seeks to render the invisible visible, to materialize the immaterial, and to tell us that we, too, can enter numinous realms.

Participating Artists

Kenneth Anger * Anohni (FKA Antony Hegarty) * Laura Battle * Jordan Belson * Alison Blickle * Carol Bove * Jesse Bransford * BREYER P-ORRIDGE * John Brill * Robert Buratti * Elijah Burgher * Cameron * Leonora Carrington * Francesco Clemente * Ira Cohen * Brian Cotnoir * Aleister Crowley * Enrico Donati * El Gato Chimney * Leonor Fini * JFC Fuller * Helen Rebekah Garber * Rik Garrett * Delia Gonzalez * Jonah Groeneboer * Juanita Guccione * Brion Gysin * Frank Haines * Barry William Hale * Valerie Hammond * Ken Henson * Bernard Hoffman * Nino Japaridze * Gerome Kamrowski * Leo Kenney * Paul Laffoley * Adela Leibowitz * Darcilio Lima * Angus MacLise * Ann McCoy * Rithika Merchant * William Mortensen * Rosaleen Norton * Micki Pellerano * Ryan M Pfeiffer & Rebecca Walz * Max Razdow * Ron RegÃ©, Jr. * Kurt Seligmann * Harry Smith * Kiki Smith * Xul Solar * Austin Osman Spare * Charles Stein * Shannon Taggart * Gordon Terry * Scott Treleaven * Panos Tsagaris * Charmion von Wiegand * Robert Wang * Peter Lamborn Wilson * Lionel Ziprin

Special Events Related to the Exhibition

Weds, Jan 13: Opening Reception Â  6-8pm

Weds, Jan 27: Performance of â€œThe Language,â€ a theatrical piece written by playwright Matthew Freeman, commissioned for Language of the Birds Â  Â 7pm

Fri, Feb 5 â€“ Sun, Feb 7: The Occult Humanities Conference at NYU Steinhardt â€“ a weekend long symposium of 14 lectures and performances which explore the influence of magical thought upon art, history, and contemporary culture

Weds, Feb 10: â€œArt Workingsâ€ Lectures and panel discussion with Professor Susan L. Aberth, Jesse Bransford, and William Breeze Â  7pm

About the Curator

Pam Grossman is an independent curator, writer, and teacher of magical practice and history. Â She is the creator of Phantasmaphile, a blog which specializes in art and culture with an esoteric or fantastical bent, and the Associate Editor of Abraxas International Journal of Esoteric Studies. Â She is also the co-organizer of the Occult Humanities Conference at NYU, and co-founder of the Brooklyn arts & lecture space, Observatory (2009-2014), where her programming explored mysticism via a scholarly yet accessible approach.

Her group art shows and projects have been featured by such outlets as Artforum, Newsweek, New York Magazine, Boing Boing, Art & Antiques Magazine, CREATIVE TIME, Time Out New York, Juxtapoz, Arthur, 20Ã—200, UrbanOutfitters.com, and Neil Gaiman’s Twitter.

Pamâ€™s writing has appeared in numerous mediums, including The Huffington Post, MSN.com, Film Society of Lincoln Centerâ€™s Film Comment blog, the Etsy blog, Sciences Occultes magazine, and various Fulgur press publications. Â As a featured guest on HuffPost LIVE, The Midnight Archive web series, and myriad other radio shows and podcasts, she has discussed the role of magic in contemporary life.

She is Getty Imagesâ€™ Director of Visual Trends, and she lives in Brooklyn with her husband, Matt, and their two cat familiars, Albee and Remedios â€œRemyâ€ Varo.

Aries: That social rights activist who is always protesting in WSP, getting in Facebook debates, and correcting non-liberals. Probably vegan. Doesnâ€™t wear a bra, because fuck the patriarchy.

Taurus: That kid who constantly Instagrams expensive food porn, goes to lavish apartment parties, and wears furs. Invites you to brunch every weekend.

Gemini: That liberal studies kid who transfers to Gallatin, but has a minor in CAS, and takes Steinhardt voice lessons. You have to ask them what theyâ€™re studying every time you hang out, and youâ€™re pretty sure they donâ€™t even know. You wonder how they will ever get a job.

Cancer: That kid who is falling apart at the seams, constantly complaining about the trials and tribulations of living in New York. Keeps forgetting to go to Yoga To The People, and is therefore full of stress. Frequently cries on the subway.

Leo: That Tisch musical theatre or recorded music kid who is always belting when youâ€™re trying to do your homework. Wonâ€™t stop inviting you to their cabarets. Has probably already been on Broadway. The epitome of sass and fierceness.

Virgo: That kid who is involved with CAB, or your residence hallâ€™s counsel. All the event promos they constantly post kind of annoy you, but they invite you to events with free food. You secretly envy their leadership at such a big school.

Libra: That kid who is actually a part of Greek life, and is obsessed with it. You want to ask why they would bother at such an urban school, but you donâ€™t have to, because you know itâ€™s for the false sense of community, and the Instagram likes. Goes on a ton of Tinder dates that never end well.

Scorpio: That Tisch film kid who wears all black, drinks black coffee, and smokes hand-rolled cigarettes outside of Tisch. Probably shot an experimental with deviant sexual themes that made you uncomfortable, but strangely aroused.

Sagittarius: That kid who actually goes out to â€œexperience New Yorkâ€ on the weekends. Goes to exhibits and shows all the time, mostly for the cool Instagram pics. Also, probably addicted to Soul Cycle.

Capricorn: That cold, heartless Stern kid who wears a suit to class every day and looks simultaneously ridiculous and fly as fuck. Has no soul. Killer resumÃ©.

Aquarius: That Gallatin kid who denies being a hipster, but is majoring in Political Food Blogging With A Focus On Gender Roles. Likes thrift shopping, dropping the term â€œheteronormativity,â€ and interpretive dance.

Pisces: That kid who makes their own clothes and drew their own sick tattoo. You catch them Photoshopping masterful works of art in lecture, on their MacBook Air. Probably does slam poetry on the weekends. Their chill vibes calm you down during finals week.

So… weâ€™ve all awkwardly bumped into somebody. Most of the time, you wave and they pretend to not see. Then the two of you go on with your lives, easy peasy. But here at NYU, itâ€™s a little different. There are SO many of us in a particular area at one time that run-ins happen practically every hour. Since no one likes an awkward moment, learn the ins and outs of turning that awkward encounter into an awesome one.Â 


Laundry Room

Sometimes the perfect time to do your laundry lines up with that floormate you sort of know but whose name escapes you. Pro Tip: Just bite the bullet and ask them their name! Another friend in your building means another person for Netflix-binging nights.


Residence Hall Â 

Getting to know your roommates at first can be a little tricky, especially when one is up until 4AM and the other wakes up at 5AM. Pro Tip: Arrange for a roommate â€œfamilyâ€ dinner. It gives you an opportunity to talk about whatâ€™s going on in your room while also eating. Itâ€™s the best of both worlds.


Dining Hall

Stuffing your face in the dining hall is a sight that only a select few of your friends have been approved to see. But at this point in college, people donâ€™t even think twice about seeing other people eat to their heartâ€™s content. Pro Tip: Always try to keep an open chair at your table. After all, whatâ€™s a better bonding activity than face-stuffing Palladium brunch?


Starbucks

Coffee is the answer to everything, except for when you run into someone you havenâ€™t seen since Welcome Week at the campus Starbucks. Pro Tip: Say hello and bring up something you saw them post on Facebook or Instagram. Conversation started!


Bars

When will the awkward encounters end? Never. Because thatâ€™s life. But itâ€™s not always awful. Seeing a professor at bar may seem like the end of the world, but it gives you an opportunity to see what they are like outside of the classroom. Pro Tip: Rather than avoiding eye contact, greet them like the grown-up that you are!


Subway

Seeing someone you know on the platform may seem like a damper on that majestic feeling of independence, but it really gives an opportunity to test your quick conversation skills. Pro Tip: Put the headphones away. Listening to â€œUptown Funkâ€ for the 10,000th time can wait 20 more minutes.


Bobst

When studying needs to be done, the library is always a good place for some peace and quiet. You didnâ€™t take the hike to Bobst to have a conversation about the latest episode of â€œOrange is the New Black,â€ but the person sharing your desk might believe that you did. Pro Tip: Tell them that you have to study at the moment, but youâ€™d love to catch up during a coffee break.Â 


The Classroom

Talking to people in class can be inexplicably hard. Youâ€™re both there for the same reason, yet finding a connection to a classmate is like tapping your head and rubbing your belly at the same time: difficult, but not impossible. Pro Tip: If nothing comes to mind, ask a question about the syllabus or next weekâ€™s reading.Â

Donâ€™t: Send the same cover letter to every position

Do: Specialize the cover letter to the job description

Donâ€™t: List out your skill sets

Do: Describe examples showing the things you have learned in your past experience

Donâ€™t: Talk about how this will benefit your career goals

Do: Talk about what the company will gain from having you on board

Donâ€™t: Write a novel

When you first arrive in a new city, chances are you are totally lost. New foods, new styles, new weather, everything is different. But, as time goes by you find yourself slowly melding into your new home. But just how well have you adapted to big city life?


1. You are a regular at a nearby place

Whether it’s a coffee shop barista, street food lady, or hole-in-the-wall juice shop owner, you barely have to say what you want and they’re already making it for you. And we thought technology would make us stop talking to peopleâ€¦


2. You have named the local stray animals that live around your building

Does that kitten in the convenience store hold the key to your heart? These little critters that roam around your neighborhood, whether it be cats, dogs, or even mice, no longer freak you out. Theyâ€™re part of the family!


3. Waking up early means experiencing a whole new population of the city

In every city there are certain types of people you see in the morning. For instance, old people doing tai chi in Shanghai and dog walkers in New York all seem to congregate in these early hours. None of that phases you anymore on your walk to your early class, though!


4. Tourist spots are a no-go

If you find yourself in a place like Times Square, you are probably not there for scenic pleasure. All around the world locals avoid tourist spots like the plague. One time up the Pearl Tower in Shanghai is more than enough; next time you go to the Grand Mosque in Abu Dhabi will be when family is visiting.


5. You have a restaurant on call for any type of food

One of the most awesome things about living in a big city is the even larger food choices! Whether youâ€™re craving pad tai, fish ‘n’ chips, or Indian curry, you most likely have a go-to place already in mind.


6. You know at least one bus or subway route like the back of your hand

It doesnâ€™t matter if itâ€™s one, two, red, or blue, you have that route covered. And hey, if you get lost, Uber is only a call away.


7. You stock up on city essentials when you go home for the holidays

Everyone back home wants those fake bags, kitschy souvenirs, and mini bottles filled with desert sand. And, of course, you cannot go more than one week without those snacks you can only get locally. Gotta stock up!
