New York Universityâ€™s Fales Library and Special Collections is home to about 560,000 books, manuscripts, and even two cuneiform tablets. Students must request special access to research in the stacks, located on the third floor of NYUâ€™s Bobst library. Many of the volumes are old and rare, and everyoneâ€™s so careful with them that you canâ€™t even bring a pen with you, lest ink bleed onto the pages.

The Marion Nestle Food Collection is just one small part of the Fales Library, acquired by NYU in 2001 from the private collection of Cecily Brownstone. She was an Associated Press food journalist and friends with James Beard, one of the most famous cookbook authors of the 20th century.

Everything from cookbooks to nutritional guides finds its home in these stacks. The 12,000-odd volumes from Brownstone are annotated in her own hand, many of them also inscribed by their respective authors. The rest of the books are just as interesting. â€œAt first I thought these stacks werenâ€™t all that different from other academic libraries, but as I learned more I started to appreciate how unique it was,â€ said Kendall Levison, one student who visited the collection.

Not least among these robust personalities is the director of the Fales Library, Marvin Taylor.Â Heâ€™s helped grow the collection into what it is today â€“ one of the largest food collections in America. With contributions from Conde Nast, Ladiesâ€™ Home Journal, and CafÃ© des Artistes, it now spans over 60,000 volumes.

Taylor is filled with interesting tidbits of trivia about the history of the food collection, as well as the food scene here in New York City. He describes Cecily Brownstone as aÂ â€œpiece of work,â€ and refers to the surprising number among the cooking community of the 20th century who were queer as theÂ â€œgay cooking mafia.â€

What really stands out is Taylorâ€™s passion for all this knowledge.Â â€œI wasnâ€™t really excited about the history behind cookbooks before Marvin started talking about them,â€ said Sydney Maynard, another visiting student to the collection.

And he clearly knows what heâ€™s talking about: He can name the title of Irma Rombauerâ€™s biography, â€œStand Facing the Stove,â€ taken from a common line in her book â€œThe Joy of Cooking.â€ â€œIt seems silly, but this book was first published during the Great Depression,â€ explained Taylor. â€œMiddle-class housewives were cooking their own food for the first time, so even the simplest tasks had to be explained.â€

â€œIt was cool to learn the history of cookbooks and the sociological insight they give,â€ said Elana Rubin, another student. Books always say a lot about the people reading them, after all.

All of this flavorful history helps spice up the initially boring-seeming stacks until there seems to be magic amongst the towering shelves. With books of all shapes, sizes, and colors, the smell of old paper perfuming the air, and Marvin Taylor as your guide, the food collection is an enlightening experience that teaches you how food has divided and brought together people of different times, places, and societies.

Cynthia Hooper’s videos patiently examine landscapes of waste, water, energy, and agriculture, with careful attention to the political and environmental policies that reorder these environments. Her most recent exhibition, “A Negotiable Utopia: The Humboldt Bay Project,” interprets the built environment of California’s second largest estuary.

Join us for a program of Hooper’s short films, followed by a discussion with Hooper and artist William Lamson.

…

  • Exportadora de Sal (2007, 7 minutes, Baja California) - The mysterious terrain of an enormous evaporative salt mine.
  • GEOTÃ‰RMOELÃ‰CTRICA: Cerro Prieto (2012, 5 minutes, Baja California) - A two-channel video about the perceptual and metaphorical characteristics of a gigantic geothermal energy field.
  • The Humboldt Bay Project: POWER (2014, 10 min, California) - Examines the regional energy infrastructure, from a recently upgraded nuclear power plant to renewable energy.
  • The Humboldt Bay Project: WATER (2014, 10 min, California) - Examines the natural and anthropogenic watersheds of Humboldt Bay, documenting distinctive water infrastructure and water quality issues.
  • The Humboldt Bay Project: SHORELINE (2014, 10 min, California) - Inventories the more than one hundred miles of shoreline that encircles Humboldt Bay.



CYNTHIA HOOPER’s videos, essays, paintings and interdisciplinary projects interpret water, waste, energy, agricultural, and urban landscape scenarios in the United States and Mexico. Her generously observational strategies and detailed investigations propose a nuanced, reflective, and often sympathetic reception for these places, and also advocate for the efforts of regional laborers, activists, and researchers who tactically refashion their complex geography.

WILLIAM LAMSON was born in Arlington, Virginia. His video works often find him playfully and strenuously interacting with his environment (both in the natural world and in his studio). Lamsonâ€™s work is included in the permanent collections of the Brooklyn Museum (NYC), the Dallas Museum of Art (TX), the Houston Museum of Fine Arts (TX), and the Progressive Art Collection (Cleveland, OH), among others.

Infrastructure Aesthetics is a graduate student organized event series exploring representations of infrastructure and the built environment in cinema, art, and literature. This event is supported by NYU’s Department of Media, Culture, and Communication and the NYU Urban Democracy Lab.

Itâ€™s that time of the year again, for like, the fourth time. Midterms are imminent, all the time; once you think youâ€™re done with them, another appears around the corner. Weâ€™ve helped you out with some tips on busting through those exams. At NYU, the only thing that is constant is changeâ€¦ and midterms.


1. Denial

What exam? What paper? We already had midterms, there canâ€™t be any more, right?


2. Pain

No going back now. Just thinking about it makes you want to cry. But weâ€™re NYU students â€” we are amazingly resilient.


3. Acceptance

Embrace it fully. Youâ€™re here for a reason. You can do it. After all, you did it once (or twice, or three times) already â€” whatâ€™s another round of midterms?


4. BargainingÂ 

The *you* that wants to get all Aâ€™s has to negotiate with the *you* that only wants to take a nap. Plus, that cold weather is really unmotivating when you need to get to Bobst.


5. Relapse

Things to avoid during this stage: Netflix, HBO, BuzzFeed. Things that might help: coffee, energy drinks, a walk around Bobst. Almost there…


6. Working Through

The only stage where youâ€™re actually doing something. Itâ€™s only a matter of time before itâ€™s all over; letâ€™s use that motivation to get stuff done!


7. Hope

Itâ€™s over, for now. You know you tried your best, and at this point you can only hope the next one isnâ€™t as bad… Good luck on those never-ending exams, NYU!

Iâ€™m here at work listening to Wolke 4.

Itâ€™s one of my favorite German songs by Philipp Dittberner and Marv. I listened to it (and other songs) constantly while I was in Berlin in an effort to improve my German comprehension and pronunciation skills.

Iâ€™m in New York now, not Berlin, but my playlists still consist of almost solely songs auf deutsch. Music has the fascinating ability of transporting us to moments that exist in our memories â€“ which for me, evidently, is Berlin.

And I canâ€™t help but think about how real and genuine â€œreverse homesicknessâ€ is. Iâ€™ve honestly never felt so much longing for a place before â€“ and yet, what is a place? But a physical area bounded by arbitrary lines? Or perhaps some number of square footage in which people share a language or that ambiguous thing we call â€œcultureâ€? Or as some sociologists would define as a web of a multitude of social interactions and relationships?

I try to be careful about how I view Berlin in my mind. Knowing that the next time I return it will be a different place, just as it was the day I arrived, and the day that I left. But I know it has changed all the more especially in light of the dramatic events that have occurred in the past few months.

And I still yearn to step down at that shabby airport and greet the disillusioned woman behind the immigration checkpoint window.

Thereâ€™s something special in Berlin that cannot be replicated in Auckland, Los Angeles, New York or London. Something that canâ€™t quite be articulated â€“ only experienced.

I do miss seeing the sky, undisturbed by skyscrapers and smog. I miss the commute and the subtle delight of being surrounded by people and voices and language and still not understanding a thing. I miss venturing into the night â€“ travailing through the cold dark winds, and suddenly stepping into a mass of warm sweating bodies â€“ betrunken, glÃ¼cklich, aufgeregt.

Inspired by the many hours of Jane the Virgin I watched this weekend, I made a sketch that displays the top 10 U.S. baby names for a selected sex and a selected year (between 1990 and 2014).

The data comes from the Social Security Administration website. The data I downloaded was a bunch of CSVs saved as text files, one for each year, going back all the way to 1880). Each file contained thousands of names, ordered first by sex (all the females, then all the males) and then by frequency. In other words, the first name was the most popular female name.

I copied and pasted the contents of each file into one spreadsheet and, for each year, cut out any names that were below the top 10 in either sex. Then I saved the file as a CSV and used Mr. Data Converter to create and save a JSON file of my data.

A user my select both a year and a sex in order to see the list. Under those conditions, a baby laugh and rattle sound are played when the submit button is clicked.

I created the dropdown menu for birth year using a for loop, one that ran backwards (i– instead of i++). I had to play around with the data from the JSON file at each level of coding to really understand how to get to my desired result.

Iâ€™m still having trouble getting divs to remove when I want to create a new one in its place. I think this is because Iâ€™m creating and calling these things in for loops; if these were separate, static divs, then it would be more straightforward. Iâ€™ll continue to play with it though.

If I were to take this project future, I would create a map of the U.S. that displays the top female and male names in a given state within a given year when hovered upon.

Hey y'all, I’m in NYMag.

by Hazal Kamisli

KuniÃ© Sugiura was born and raised in Japan. She first came to America in 1963 to study at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC). After graduation, she moved to New York City, where she still lives and works.

Â In Deadend Street (1978), the viewer is greeted with an unusual pairing of images: Two photographic canvases depicting a street under a railway are paired with two canvases painted black. The center of the piece remains hollow, drawing the viewers in. What continues to surprise the viewers upon close inspection of the work is the replication of the texture of the two depicted streets on to the adjacent black canvases. The black canvas next to the wet street is glossy, whereas the one next to the dry street has a matte texture. The empty central panel balances the understated trompe lâ€™oeil effect formed as a result of this optical structure.

Â The blurring of boundaries, characteristic of the period and seen in many of the works in the Grey Art Galleryâ€™s exhibition For A New World to Come: Experiments in Japanese Art and Photography, 1968-1979, is integral to the understanding of the work and its innovative spirit. The images of the street form the photographic element, while the texture of the canvases and the framing of the work have a sculptural touch. The painterly quality of the piece with its critique of the medium of paintingâ€“the emptiness in the center creates a space that painting has traditionally occupiedâ€“brings forth the question, â€œIs this a photograph, a sculpture, or a painting?â€ and the answer is that it is in fact all three.

Â For A New World to Come: Experiments in Japanese Art and Photography, 1968-1979, is currently on view at New York Universityâ€™s Grey Art Gallery through December 5, 2015. The New York presentation of this exhibition is shared with Japan Society Gallery.

To find out more information about the exhibition, please visit https://www.nyu.edu/greyart/.

Hazal Kamisli is a graduate intern at the Grey Art Gallery and is a Masters Candidate in Visual Arts Administration at New York Universityâ€™s Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development where she is expected to graduate in spring 2016.

Seriously, is there a different bug going around every week? Between midterm season and a dash of cold weather, the conditions are unfortunately perfect to catch an illness. But this is NYU, nobody has time to get sick! We canâ€™t all be blessed with amazing immune systems, but luckily there are some simple ways to help avoid whateverâ€™s flying around.



Get your flu shot from NYU

Uh, no brainer! Getting a flu shot will help you stay healthy and avoid the worst, and even better, itâ€™s free at these scheduled NYU events! Even if you missed the Wellness Expo, thereÂ are still plenty of opportunities.Â It pays to proactive!


Use your Dining Dollars for Emergen-C and juice

Dining Dollars are dope, and so is giving your body the fuel it needs to fight off the pathogens you might have found in Bobst, the subway, or that revolving door everyone touches. If you think you feel a sniffle or a cough lingering, it never hurts to have vitamin C on hand! Stock up at Sidestein, Hayden, Burger Studio, Palladium, or Third North to help you beat a cold before it hits.



Stay hydrated

Tea and water (and not too much coffee!) are excellent ways to help your body get better. Staying hydrated will help your body and possibly help with a sore throat. There are tons ofÂ dining locationsÂ andÂ coffee shopsÂ around campus to keep you hydrated!


Skip the night out for sleep

Hate to sound like your parents, but aÂ good nightâ€™s sleepÂ is one of the most important thing you can do for your brain and body! Canceling plans in order to take care of your body is something that youâ€™ll thank yourself for in the long run, believe us on this.



Wash your hands

Itâ€™s easy to forget, but washing your hands after the bathroom or before you eat drastically reduces the spread of germs and goes a long way to protect against infection. Get your hygiene on!


Go to the Student Health Center

These tips might help in little ways, but youâ€™re going to need more than orange juice to combat something more serious. If you think you caught a nasty cold or worse, book an appointment at a Student Health Center, either at 726 Broadway or 6 Metrotech. Itâ€™s one of the best resources NYU offers and can make sure you can get back to kicking your midtermsâ€™ butts!


For more info about cold and flu symptoms and prevention, NYU’s got you covered.

The summer weather came and went this Fall semester as quickly as Hurricane Joaquin blew by (though we definitely arenâ€™t complaining about that). Warm, summer breezes have been traded for chilly, autumn winds; venti iced coffees for Oprah Cinnamon Chai Tea lattes; and black Ray-Bans for black umbrellas. But with midterms piling on, bundling up in our NYU sweaters and clutching our hot coffee cups to keep warm is the least of our worries.



Halloween and midterms might fall in the same month, but only one of the two should leave you at your witâ€™s end. In any case, weâ€™ve got some tricks and treats to help you get through midterms season painlessly.



1. Plan your time



Studying for midterms is pointless if you donâ€™t know when they are! Buy a planner or even use your phoneâ€™s calendar app to keep all your dates straight. Know when things should be done and finish them by those dates.

Pro Tip: Plan out your day hour-by-hour the night before, so no time is ever wasted.


2. Figure out what pumps you up and keeps your mood high



If youâ€™re going to study for a couple hours, you might as well get pumped for it! A happy brain is a productive one, so set yourself up for hours of productivity. Want to go for a walk? Do it! Want to have a dance party? Dance away! Feel like doodling or cooking? Go for it! (Just don’t forget to buckle down afterwards.)

Pro Tip: Kill two birds with one stone and head out on a fun adventure above 14th Street or check something off your NYU Bucket List.


3. Organize your tasks



Make lists of all the things you need to do, then break down the big tasks into multiple small tasks so goals seem easily achievable. The more that gets done, the more accomplished youâ€™ll feel (and the better youâ€™ll do)!

Pro Tip: Gain some momentum by including trivial tasks on your to-do list â€” like eating a snack or taking a shower â€” so you have more to cross off.


4. Get rest



Whether you have midterms or not, you should always be getting a refreshing night of sleep. Pulling an all-nighter to study for that exam might sound like a great idea, BUT ITâ€™S NOT. Your body and mind are trying to tell you theyâ€™re at their limit, so donâ€™t push it! You need that beauty sleep to wake up feeling and looking flawless.

Pro Tip: Donâ€™t hesitate to take a 20 minute nap if youâ€™re dozing off midday. Naps can be just as important as sleep if you really need it. (Just be sure to set that alarmâ€¦ or maybe two?)


5. Clean up your workspace



Feng Shui 101: a cluttered desk is a cluttered mind. Clear out old papers, trash, and any unnecessary things from your desk to maximize your productivity zone. (This includes removing any possible distractions from the area, too.)

Pro Tip: Take time to tidy up not just before you work, but afterwards as well. That way, you can jump right into your next study session without headaches.


6. Shake it up



Donâ€™t always study in the same spot. Make things interesting for yourself AND your brain by changing up your test-prep location every once in awhile. Keeping your brain on its toes will keep it fresh for reviewing material.

Pro Tip: Weâ€™ve got a starter list of some of the best places on and near campus to buckle down and get to work.


7. Work in and out of study groups



Some people prefer to work in groups. Others prefer to work alone. Decide which works best for you and â€” if you do like study buddies â€” pair up with people who work the same way as you.

Pro Tip: Why not get the best of both worlds? Study solo to learn the material on your own, then teach it to your classmate or friend for review (and to share your overflowing knowledge)!


8. Listen to music



Warning: listening to music isnâ€™t for everyone! For some people, having the ambient sound is better than silence. For others, the quiet is focusing. Decide which is best for you and stick with it. Weâ€™ve got a nice range of songsÂ â€” from pumped-up playlists to soft music sets â€” to help you on your way.

Pro Tip: Love music but find yourself singing along to your jam too often? Listen to film scores or instrumentals instead.


9. Take breaks



Sure, youâ€™ve got a lot to do. But that doesnâ€™t mean you have to work for hours non-stop! Pausing for regular breaks after 25 minutes of focused, hard work will make all the difference in boosting your efficiency and mood.

Pro Tip: Briefly review the material you just studied before stepping away for a breather so your hard work doesnâ€™t walk off with you.


10. Keep up your health



You donâ€™t want to be sniffling and blowing your nose during your exams… Itâ€™s annoying for you and everyone in class. Plus, stress can seriously influence your overall health. Eat nutritious meals to power your study time with brain food, and always stay hydrated (that means water, not just coffee). Visit the Student Health Center or call the Wellness Exchange (repeat after us: 212-443-9999) if you need to talk something out.

Pro Tip: Grabbing a bite at an NYU dining hall? Get a fruit to-go and save it for your study sesh later.


11. Remain calm



Midterms will be over before you know it (and finals begin…). If youâ€™ve followed these tips, worked hard, and tried your best, you have nothing to worry about.

Pro Tip: Donâ€™t forget to treat yoâ€™self once itâ€™s all over. You did it! You made it through in one piece. Now go order some Insomnia Cookies and catch up on all those TV episodes you missed.

The reason Iâ€™m so pissed is because Iâ€™ve been having a terrible week to begin with, and midterms didnâ€™t even start yet. But this reminds me of a bigger issue that my school never seems to GET.

Thereâ€™s a great essay by Virginia Woolfe (Iâ€™m not well read, I read this for class once), calledÂ â€œA Room of Oneâ€™s Ownâ€, in which Woolfe says women needs opportunities which they donâ€™t have which is why they donâ€™t succeed. They donâ€™t have a room for them just to focus on what they want and think creatively.

THIS SAME IDEA APPLIES TO COLLEGE STUDENTS.Â 

When we complain to the administration that we donâ€™t have this or that, it feels like the administrators donâ€™t understand the validity of our complaints. Yes, some of it is because we are spoiled privilege rich kids, but on the other hand itâ€™s because we need to feel comfortable so we are able to focus and study. When thereâ€™s no wifi, weâ€™re not just mad because we canâ€™t access social media, weâ€™re mad because it hinders our studies- especially mine, because I have yet to be at a school with a decent library. I depend on online sources. When you give us alternative places to get internet access, they donâ€™t understand itâ€™s not a conducive study environment. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m willing to travel 40 minutes to a student cafe so I can focus more on my work.Â 

But then they assume weâ€™re just being lazy people. Iâ€™m sure men thought women were being whiny too for wanting to do more than cooking, and that doesnâ€™t mean cooking laundry.

Facilities should be a priority for students. Student well being in general should be more of a focus.


The school says that IT will be back on Wednesday to fix our wifi again. Thanks for wasting a week of me being able to quickly check something online in my room, reply to an email from the school, or even fucking skype in comfort and not in a public area. Iâ€™m one of those people who need to feel alone and have it quiet to study. Itâ€™s not just about having wifi, itâ€™s about the terrible alternatives given.

Iâ€™ve been spending a lot of time at NYU recently, having begun an internship at nearby nightclub and venue (le) poisson rouge in September and also occasionally coming in for a studio class here and there with faculty member Anne Lanzilotti, whoâ€™s actually an old student (and teaching assistant) of my own teacher, Karen Ritscher.

Karen, who herself is on the faculty at NYU, mentioned that a violist, Fang Han, had won the concerto competition at NYU the previous year with the Bartok, and so I went with a friend from nearby Barnard College to see her play it with orchestra tonight.

The program was as follows:

John Adamsâ€™Â â€œThe Chairman Dancesâ€

Bela Bartokâ€™s Viola Concerto

Dmitri Shostakovichâ€™s Symphony No. 9 in E-Flat MajorÂ 

John Adamsâ€™Â â€œThe Chairman Dancesâ€ (occasionally subtitled â€œFoxtrot For Orchestraâ€) (1985) started the concert on a deeply grounded footing; as a very representative piece of his, in terms of its strong minimalistic flavor, it did well under the baton of conductor Constantine Kitsopoulos. The repeated rhythmic cells wove together nicely, and a cohesive foundation in that regard paved the way for a very clean reading, though one wished occasionally for a bit more intensity, particularly in the strings.

Halfway through the work, the haze of sound thinned, revealing the timbres of the individual instrumental sections before returning to the sound-world of the first section, but not without allowing the winds, particularly principal flutist DeShaun Gordon King, to shine. Pianist Hakyong Park and the percussion section ended the work on a very cinematic note, the percussion almost inaudible at the last.

Bela Bartokâ€™s Viola ConcertoÂ (1945), along with his Third Piano Concerto, was the last piece he ever worked on; he actually died before finishing his draft of the score, and the concerto was rescued from oblivion by his student and close friend Tibor Serly as well as his commissioner, legendary violist William Primrose. Although alternative editions exist, this one remains the most commonly performed. In three movements, it runs approximately twenty minutes in this edition.

Violist Fang Han was frankly astonishing; nearly note-for-note perfect, she left the audience stunned. Her sensitivity was particularly appreciated in the pristine, prayerlike opening of the second movement,Â while her bite was ferocious in the beast that is the third movement. The orchestra suffered from some ensemble issues, particularly in the middle of the cadenza-like passage in the first movement, which features low string and brass interjections between which the viola spits out virtuosic chords and harmonics.Â 

Dmitri Shostakovichâ€™s Symphony No. 9 in E-Flat Major (1945), unlike other famous Symphony No. 9â€²s, is a humorous work, full of gaiety and a bit of biting sarcasm, although it reveals a darker side in the fourth movement, a stark Largo.Â 

There was an interesting observation to be made at the beginning of the first movement; while the individual string sections played very well with themselves, they seemed to have difficulty hooking on rhythmically with each other. Piccolo player Charles Page quickly patched things up, however, with a confident sound that hardly betrayed the difficulty of the writing. The second movement began with clarinets; principal Ki-Deok Park was contemplative and solemn in great contrast to the preceding music. The sonority of the strings was lush and dark with great blend, though the first violins suffered a grave episode of rhythmic confusion in a section solo that seemed to have an eighth note disconnect from the front stand to the last.

The third movement, a Presto that featured some ricochet action from the first violins, was solidly the highlight of the night in terms of string playing; the strings, perhaps galvanized by the prior movement, were wholly unified and as agile as ever. The brass were somewhat unbalanced, with the trumpets struggling to be heard and the trombones and tuba easily audible. The flutes were again an excellent-sounding section, adding sparkle and flair with their multitude of runs. The end of that movement went attaccaÂ into the next, introduced by deep brass tones reminiscent of the Mussorgsky-Ravel Catacombs (from Pictures at an Exhibition) that led into a long recitative for bassoon. Bassoonist Jarrett Grempel filled the hall with an intense, rather bright timbre that tended a bit sharp at times. As he led into the final movement, also an attacca transition, his sound warmed up and intonation stabilized. The Allegretto-Allegro was maneuvered smoothly, lackadaisical and more than a little bit neurotic. The playing was excellent, without hiccups, and an end to the concert that left more than a couple with grins on their faces. Â

His name is JESSE ST. JAMES. He is 18 years old, and originally from SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA. Heâ€™s currently a freshman at NYU, and has been paired with Claire Pierce for the project.

He is currently a TAKEN CHARACTER.

  • Jesse St. James is a very confident and loud person. He likes to do impromptu singing and dancing and heâ€™s very unapologetic. Acting like this makes people take a step back from him and even though he knows itâ€™s a problem he doesnâ€™t want to change the way he is for anyone. His parents have tried to talk to him about it but it has led to angry arguments and never anything good. He dreams about performing on a big stage someday and have tons of fans adore and love him which is a way of him to cope with feeling so alone.
  • He can seem very distant to people but heâ€™s really just afraid of getting close to anyone, due to being a lonely kid and having trouble making friends all his life. He doesnâ€™t really know how to act â€œnormalâ€ in front of others and always seems like he owns the world. His closest friends are those from his childhood that stuck with him and he misses them a lot. He likes to dress casually in darker colors but he still cares about looking good and having a fashionable style.
  • Jesse isnâ€™t the smartest person in the world; in fact heâ€™s struggling to make it in college at all. He feels like heâ€™s doing his best but in reality heâ€™s not. He spends a lot of time practicing his voice instead of doing homework or following up on what is happening in the classes. He can be very lazy when it comes to school but the opposite when it comes to his so called future on Broadway that he canâ€™t stop dreaming about. He also enjoys taking pictures of the outside and going on long walks to get a good view or scenery. It relaxes him.
  • He secretly likes the idea of having a soulmate and the thought of it makes him feel less lonely. He grew up questioning his sexuality as he found himself attracted to both guys and girls but he has never been able to explore these feelings. Both because heâ€™s too much in love with himself and because his parents doesnâ€™t like the idea of Jesse being with a guy. Heâ€™s still hiding these feelings and only truly shows who he is to the people heâ€™s closes to.

CHARACTER AESTHETIC

Jesse has semi-long curly brown hair and with deep blue eyes. He likes to wear dark colors like grey and black and rarely other colors. Heâ€™s very fashionable and shops expensive brands and how he looks is very important to him. He has no tattoos or piercings.

His name is PEYTON JORDAN ST. JAMES. He is 18 years old, and originally from SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA. Heâ€™s currently a freshman at NYU, and has been paired with Sam Evans for the project.

He is currently a TAKEN CHARACTER.

  • The St. James family was a very open and accepting one; they wanted nothing but the best for their boys, but were happy as long as their children were doing something they loved. They offered their support through every situation and had their arms open to any friends or loves that their sons brought into their home. Because of such a loving atmosphere, it wasnâ€™t incredibly difficult for Peyton to come out to Jesse and his parents when he was fourteen. If anything, Peyton was incredibly thankful because he knew how difficult coming out to your loved oneâ€™s could be for other people. Of his parentâ€™s, Peyton has always been the closest to his mother - finding his love for the piano through his time spent with her on itâ€™s bench.
  • Because of some heavy asthmatic problems, Peyton refrained from a lot of physical activity through school - opting to join the book club and take piano lessons instead of playing any kind of sports. In a school so big, it was easy to be labelled a nerd or an outcast because of his lack of interest in athletics but because of his kind and witty personality, he had an easy time fitting in with most people in his class. While he loved hanging out with all different kinds of people, he preferred the company of a few close friends over a crowd and spent most of his free time with them at their homes or his own.
  • A running joke in the St. James household is the fact that the boys were both given ambiguous names. Their parents chose the names for the kids right after they learned of the pregnancy because they were so overjoyed and couldnâ€™t wait to be parents. When they went in for the ultrasound to find out the gender of their twins, they were told that they were having girls. The names theyâ€™d chosen, â€˜Jesseâ€™ and ‘Peytonâ€™, fit well and they were happy with their choices. When, to their surprise, two boys were born they decided to stick with what theyâ€™d already chosen instead of choosing something that society would consider a generally male name.
  • While most eighteen year olds had no idea what they wanted to do with their future, Peyton had always known that he wanted to play music. Heâ€™d been playing the piano since he was five years old and singing in the high school choir all four years. So, when it came time to send in applications for colleges, Peyton was on top of sending his information to all of the top music schools in the country. While he didnâ€™t exactly want to leave San Fransisco, his acceptance to NYU couldnâ€™t be passed up. Heâ€™s incredibly excited to be starting his freshmen year in New York and even though itâ€™s going to be a very heavy work load studying two majors - Performance Studies through Tisch and Piano Studies at NYU - he knows what he wants for his future and working hard isnâ€™t going to be a problem for him.

CHARACTER AESTHETIC

Peyton isnâ€™t incredibly concerned about what he wears, as long as itâ€™s comfortable and not overly complicated. He usually keeps his hair short on the sides, longer on top and fairly messy - opting to gel the top if he hasnâ€™t just rolled out of bed or has to look decent for a performance. He very rarely lets it grow out much longer than his ears. There isnâ€™t a touch of dye in it, preferring to keep it brown. Eventually heâ€™d like to have more tattoos, but right now he only has a small treble clef behind his left ear and a small bass clef behind the right. He got them when he turned eighteen in a small act of rebellion. Because itâ€™s frowned upon for performances, Peyton stays away from a lot of piercings; having just one stud in each ear. Typically, he sticks to plain t-shirts, button ups, flannel and fitted jeans with oxfords or combat boots. Peyton wears contacts primarily, but occasionally wears glasses if he was too lazy to put his contacts in that morning.

Over the following week, as part of the first #NYULeadershipWeek, we will be featuring NYU students and alumni as they reflect on leadership:Â 

We donâ€™t often hear about failure and fear in stories about successful leaders, but for NYU Alumna Carla Fernandez, they are both important parts of her leadership process Â #nyuleadership week

Carla Fernandez (Gallatin â€˜09) Â currently works with Enso, a creative agency that promotes positive social impact. In her own life,Carla has found that leadership comes down to taking ownership of the process and not being afraid of fear.

What is a specific moment that for you that highlighted the reality of fear in leadership?

I run a project called the Dinner Party, a non-profit all about how we approach grief and life after loss. We had run out of funding and knew that we needed to put gas in the tank.

We knew we needed to have a crowdfunding campaign, but we didnâ€™t want to ask, we were just too nervous. The challenge was: how do we get to a place where we are believing enough in our idea that we can confidently ask our friends,our families, to invest in our project? ?

How did you come to own that fear as part of the process?

Our brains concoct why this a horrible idea, why we should give up, keep it small, or compromise. I think those are moments where you have to get up on the highboard, swandive off, and trust in the pool.

The question really is, you could stay away from pursuing your vision , but what is the cost if you never try? Sometimes, that is in and of itself almost a greater failure.

Has your relationship to failure changed?

I think I am finally at a place in my life where I am realizing how essential failure is to the process. Failure is not a bad thing. Failure is the other side of the same coin as success. You can make such huge leaps forward into better thinking and cooler ideas by looking at something you could have otherwise label as a mistake.

I think it’s important to frame those times in terms of a percolation or a gestation. The same way that a seed remains underground before it can grow, there is a period where ideas can feel scary or dark and unclear before they can really emerge and be strong and interesting for you Â and others who see the potential.

I think more and more we are realizing that the archetype of a fearless leader is false. Everyone has their own story and their own concerns and their own hopes and dreams.

An occasional series of inspirational stories of @nyuniversity students and alumni making leadership happen in real ways in the real world.Â

Yesterday for work, I got to take a field trip back to my Alma Mater b/c my company was having OCR (On-Campus Recruitment) interviews with NYU seniors who are looking for full-time jobs after they graduate next May. They brought me and a senior analyst who graduated from NYU in 2012 to mingle with the interviewees in the lobby while they waited for their turn. We were supposed to answer any questions they had about the company, the job, give advice, etc. I wasnâ€™t actually interviewing anyone, they literally just brought me to spend half the day chatting with nervous af college kids lol.Â 

But wow it was like deja vu. I canâ€™t believe I was in their shoes two years ago. I remember when I was a senior, a lot of the companies that came to do OCR also brought recent NYU alumni to network with the interviewees. At the time, I thought,Â â€œMaybe they’re secretly scrutinizing how we’re acting in the waiting room and theyâ€™re going to report it back to the interviewers. I better make a good impression on them too.â€ Hahahaha. I actually have pretty much have no say in who is getting invited back for a second round interview. The second round is also the last round, aka our â€œSuperday.â€ Thatâ€™s when the company is going to invite all of the students who they liked from yesterday to come to our office and meet with all of the managing directors one by one, then do a case interview, and then take them to dinner (and drinks if they are 21). Also there will be students from other schools like Columbia and Fordham and Baruch, and wherever else we did on-campus interviews. And then after Superday, they will decide who to give job offers to.Â 

Anyways, itâ€™s just so interesting being on the other side of things this time. And it makes me SOOOOOOO grateful I am not going through OCR right now lol. I do feel a little awkward helping my company out with recruiting season because of the fact that Iâ€™m simultaneously job-searching for myself under the table. But at least I wasnâ€™t lying when I was telling the seniors that I do think this is a great place to start your career!!!

October 1, 2015.

Adventure inbetween classes.

Berlin. September 25-28 2015.

I love Berlin. It is a mixture of young and old. There is so much history there, most of it sad, but it is quite an experience. This was my first trip in Europe, outside of the Czech Republic so you can say I was more than a little excited.

Our friend, Ericsson, came with us and it was great! He is the best third wheel. We now have a thing that when we go places with him we have to take a selfie of the three of us. We did this in Berlin and in Vienna.

When we first got to Berlin we took a bus to our Airbnb from the bus station. We met a very nice German lady, young and half German half Colombian. She let us know what sights to see on such a short trip.Â 

As soon as we got off the bus Ericsson realized that he dropped his wallet on the seat! We thought it was a goner for the longest time. Not too long ago I was going through my Facebook messages and noticed an unread message from someone I didnâ€™t know. It turned out to be the lady we met on the bus! She told me she has Ericssonâ€™s wallet and wants to send it to him! It was a miracle and we are forever grateful to her.

I recommend visiting Kreuzberg while in Berlin. It is theÂ â€œyoungâ€ section of town, like Brooklyn. The variety of food is outstanding and the shops are all hipster which is appealing.

Also, I ate meat :o I had little bites of whatever the boys had ordered: currywurst, veal meatballs, and some beef thing. All very good and I have slo-mo videos of myself trying each thing lol.Â 

I hope to try a little bit of meat in each place that I visit, just to experience the food of different cultures. I will still continue to be a veggie, though!

I want to go back to Berlin; there are so many museums to go in, so many restaurants to eat in, so many bookstores to search in. I also have to see the Berlin Philharmonic. One day.

One day I will be back.

Iâ€™m a woman with many identities. Iâ€™m a teacher and a student, a singer and an actor, Iâ€™ve got a bachelor degree of engineering, and now, Iâ€™m a PR professional.

Iâ€™m so determined to become a PR specialist that I set aside my undergraduate major and supported myself all way to NYU, financially and academically. Being the only TOEFL speaking teacher without English major in the most prestigious Language Institute in China, I was financially independent. Back in school, by minoring in Psychology and leading the Student Union, I know how to motivate people and implement public events.

I know how to cooperate with different people, which is crucial to public relations. As a teacher, I always find out the biggest opportunity for Chinese students to improve their English proficiency. According to them, my lectures are clear, persuasive, motivated and distinctive. And my boss trusts my instincts in referring employees. He says that I always know the right person in the right place.

Thanks to my diversified background, I have knowledge and contacts in a variety of industries, including education, business, communication, psychology and performing arts industry. While Iâ€™m continuing my PRCC program, Iâ€™m ready to take the next step to apply my knowledge, skills and experience to an internship at a top PR firm in NYC.

Pretty much everyone that has been to New York City has used the subway; the City is known for its walkability and even its yellow cabs are recognizable around the world. But have you ever biked in NYC?

They say that you can never forget how to ride a bike; once you know how to use one, those motor skills will stay with you for the rest of your life. (Well, supposedly.) But in all seriousness, biking is actually a super fast and fun way to get around (or get lost) in the capital of the world!

We know what youâ€™re thinking: OMG BIKING ON THOSE STREETS WITH ALL OF THOSE CARS AND PEDESTRIANS, ARE YOU NUTS?

No.

Ok, but, where do you start? There are three starting points you can choose from…


1. NYU Bike Share

A photo posted by NYU Bike Share (@nyubikeshare) on Jul 15, 2015 at 3:54pm PDT

The Universityâ€™s own bike share is not only very convenient to students and faculty alike, with indoor stations at many campus buildings and residence halls, but it is also completely free! #win

2. Citi Bike

The cityâ€™s official bike-sharing system has more than 300 stations scattered across Manhattan and Brooklyn. With a year-long subscription, it is a very cheap and easy way to bike the City. There are stations near every NYU residence hall and multiple around Washington Square.


3. BYOB (Bring Your Own Bike)

Convenience, no time limits, no predetermined docking. Cons: more expensive, higher initial investment, maintenance, and ohhhh bike thieves are everywhere.

You might be a little nervous to start biking, but believe us: itâ€™s a totally different (and awesome!) way to travel around the City. But youâ€™d probably want to follow some of our tips:


  • Wear a helmet. Pretty self explanatory
  • Cyclists must follow NYCâ€™s traffic rules
  • Make sure your bike has lights and a bell, as they are also required by law
  • Scout the bike paths in your area
  • Check the weather!
  • Buy a lock if you have your own bike â€” thatâ€™s a given
  • See if your off-campus apartment has a bike room
  • Bundle up more than you normally would â€” thereâ€™s more wind when youâ€™re going fast!

You canâ€™t buy happiness, but you can buy a bike, and thatâ€™s pretty close!

Over the following week, as part of the first #NYULeadershipWeek, we will be featuring NYU students and alumni as they reflect on leadership: Â 

Empowerment is a word that is often misunderstood. Pilar Harris (Gallatin, MA â€˜16) seeks to redefine empowerment through creative approaches to social justice. In 2014, Pilar came to New York City to pursue a Masterâ€™s degree at NYUâ€™s Gallatin School of Individualized Studies where her concentration is Womenâ€™s Studies and Urban Social Innovation.

How do you define leadership?

I define leadership as the willingness to respectfully provoke and encourage others to work toward some objective. I cherish my ability to see value in others and that’s what my collaborative leadership style is made of. One of the leaders I admire, Linda A. Hill, sums it up this way: “It starts with patience, and the conviction that everybody has a slice of genius. In too many places, people aren’t given the opportunity to demonstrate their own brilliance.”

What is one word or idea that you seek to redefine by the end of your career?

I’d like to redefine empowerment by the end of my career. As a development/NGO practitioner, one of my goals is to demonstrate that both men and women can be empowered and, most importantly, that individuals can empower themselves.

Please describe a defining moment in your life that has shaped your values.

I was once a counselor at a sleep-away camp for children affected by HIV/AIDS. Bringing creativity and optimism to this role was a challenge and it shaped the way I think about ‘doing’ social change. I now look for opportunities to demonstrate the compassion, cultural sensitivity, and humility that I learned from this experience.

As we are settling in to the new academic year, it is time to reinforce that the utmost safety of our students, faculty, staff and visitors is a top priority for New York University. We are dedicated to maintaining a campus where learning excels in an environment unencumbered by safety concerns or fear for personal well-being. To that end, we provide members of our community with advice to help them protect themselves and their property:

Always be alert and watch your valuables whether you are in New York City or elsewhere around the world. Theft of unattended property is the most common crime no matter where you are. When you keep track of your property and secure your bicycle properly, it goes a long way in preventing crimes of opportunity from occurring.

The following tips can minimize the likelihood that your property will be stolen:

  • Don’t leave laptops, smart phones and other valuables unattended, even for a few minutes.
  • Always keep your bags and backpacks closed and secured.
  • Avoid hanging your bag on the back of a chair where you can’t see it.
  • Use a locked locker to store your belongings whenever possible.
  • Secure your bicycle properly with a chain lock or U-lock, not a cable lock.

If you would like to learn more about avoiding property theft or about what to do during emergency situations, visit:

NYU.EDU/BESAFE

Even the toughest of days can be made brighter with just the smallest of victories. And with an open mind, every situation â€“ from doing your laundry to walking to class â€“ can be turned into a small victory. Itâ€™s literally impossible not to have a great day at NYU!


1. When the elevator goes straight to your floor

Whether youâ€™re in a rush or not, itâ€™s a great feeling to get exactly where you want to go right away. We are New Yorkers, after all. Time is money!


2. When the music youâ€™re listening to perfectly matches your walking pace

Nothing makes you smile more than impeccably-timed music playing to the beat of your step as youâ€™re making your way downtown, walking fast, faces pass, and youâ€™re homebound. (Still looking for the right song? Weâ€™ve got your back with our Fall Power-Up Playlist on Spotify.)


3. When the line for Kimmel, Dunkinâ€™ Donuts, or Starbucks is short

NYU Dining is always coming in clutch because they know good food and coffee make for happy students. And happy students are successful ones.


4. When there is just enough space for you to make it on the train or elevator to class

… Except now you hold your breath and try not to move because youâ€™re all jammed in there like sardines. But at least you made it!


5. When printing your homework with an NYU printer is quick and painless

We have all experienced the long lines waiting to print, but sometimes it turns out perfectly and you still get to class on time. Pro Tip: There are more places (and ways) to print than just at Bobst!


6. When there are a ton of washers and dryers available in the laundry room

Bonus victory: When the lint trap has already been cleaned for you. Thank you, kind stranger â€” you make the world a better place.


7. When you donâ€™t have to stop at any intersections on the way to class

Pausing at crosswalks just ruins your pace, not to mention the rhythm of your step to your music! Uninterrupted walks to class are like the worldâ€™s way of nodding to you to have a good day.


8. When people ask you where you go to school, and you get to say NYU!

But really, people donâ€™t need to ask for you to slyly flash your NYU Card. Go ahead, brag about it. ;)

On Friday, October 2nd, Ken Perlin, Professor of Computer Science, Director of the Games for Learning Institute and Member of MAGNET courteously welcomed us into the NYU Media Research Lab to give us an inside look at what VR studies look like and what he and his team have been up to. For starters, as Ken and his amazing grad students corrected me, they arenâ€™t working on â€œvirtual realityâ€, but rather â€œFuture Reality.â€ For them, this four dimensional simulation existence is our best guess at what living in the future will be like.

So, the only reasonable thing to do was try it out. First off, some volunteers stapped on some equipment, that is to say: anklets, bracelets, and head gear, along with a remote control. Once the Oculus is on, they are no longer standing in the room Iâ€™ve pictured below, but a well lit, empty room with wood floors and tall ceilings. Although the two participants canâ€™t see us, they can see one another (as stick figures of course), and if they want to reach out and grab their what they see of their counterpartâ€™s hand (in future reality) they can (in actual reality).

Then, once they are accustomed to their surroundings, the users then can start experimenting with their surroundings. With this magical wand of a remote control, you can draw in three dimensions, and it can be a collaborative effort with the other user together you can draw and build in 3d. You can walk through each others drawings like a ghost, and change the color of your masterpiece.

Then if that wasnâ€™t cool enough, you can pull off all your gear and prance on over to the other lab where the Vive is also hooked up to the same simulation, except now you are a giant overlooking those other two schmoes in the other room as they draw and dance and attempt to become accustomed to their new surroundings. The next step in future reality is making it possible for you to make drawings in their world from the other room (and maybe freak them out and play with them a bit, haha). But even if it isnâ€™t interactive yet, if I believed that I was truly in a different room when I put on the Oculus Rift, the visuals on the Vive are a million times more realistic.

Once we all went through those simulations, Tom Small from YouTube and Google came to show us his new #360video documentary â€œKissed by a Wild Mountain Gorillaâ€ on gorillas in Congo. Not only did we get a chance to look eye to eye with gorillas - to the point where you want to pull the Google Cardboard as far away from you face as possible because you donâ€™t want to be pulled to shreds by a Silverback - but we also got an inside look at the native peoples whoâ€™s main source of income is the tourism and foreign interest in safari.

I donâ€™t know about all these Virtual Reality horror games I keep hearing about, but this was unbelievable! This is what dreams are made of, but actually!

I grew up in a big town, but I still felt a sense of familiarity with everyone around me, all these recurring background figures in my life. I would address the mailman by name and heâ€™d ask me how school was going. Whenever I went out for a bagel and a coffee, I could expect the same man to be crouching behind a newspaper at a corner table. His name was Bob and he once asked me what I wanted to do when I grew up.

Just the other day, my dad texted me:Â â€œI just ran into Danny from Hang Tai. He asked about you. I told him you were in college and they flipped out.â€ I wouldnâ€™t recognize the owner of our local Chinese restaurant if I bumped into him on the street, but apparently he knows me.

It reminds me of the beginning of White NightsÂ by Fyodor Dostoevsky:

Whether I walked in the Nevsky, went to the Gardens or sauntered on the embankment, there was not one face of those I had been accustomed to meet at the same time and place all the year. They, of course, do not know me, but I know them. I know them intimately, I have almost made a study of their faces, and am delighted when they are gay, and downcast when they are under a cloud.

There is no such familiarity here. People stand in elevators and do not look at each other. I come to the same spot at the library nearly every day, yet I never encounter the same people. I take the subway at the same time every day I go to work, but the cars are filled with strangers, ear budded and unsmiling.

My collegeâ€™s lack of an actual campus makes it nearly impossible to formulate a sense of community in this overwhelmingly large place. I came here craving anonymity, though I suppose I didnâ€™t know what it would actually feel like. But itâ€™s novel and I like it. I like that I can walk down the street on a bad hair day without fearing that Iâ€™ll bump into someone I know. I like meeting new and interesting people, even if I donâ€™t find them in the same spots every day. And maybe, over time, I will become accustomed to meeting the same people, and I will study their faces and interpret their emotions as though they were my nearest friends.

This Â week was a little different from previous. While last week was a sort of busy one with the arrival of the pope happening, this week was a return to the usual work pace. Sometimes I wonder if the office is a bit over staffed in the Graphics department. Often there’s about 6 people in that room including myself and Pratik. Often we’ll get a few logos and graphics to make, but usually it seems like most of the work is done by 1pm. Though this rules gets proven otherwise due to how ever-changing a news show can be. The show itself airs at 3 so, any number of things can change til then. Stories might get cut or suddenly added. They might not be pleased with what was done or have a minor suggestion that we’ll have to accommodate. This part of the job I like, because it feels fast paced and exciting. Not to say that everything else is boring, because it’s anything but that. But, a little surprise alway gets the blood flowing I feel.

The other interesting thing to take place this week is the loss of my work station. See, the graphics department consists of these computers against the wall which are called work stations. Everyone on the job that day gets a work station and go about their tasks. Simple, right? Now my work station might be what you call a worn out one. The station uses Mac computers, like most graphics teams seem to use today, and mine was a bit of an older model. The programs were dated, and it was somewhat slow. But it worked. Up until last week I got my work done on it so I had no real complaints. This week however, the computer crashed. Which was unfortunate, because most of the work I was doing, was kept locally. Â It kind of sucks cause that’s quite a bit of time and effort Â lost. Not everything I made was for the show, but I suppose that’s the risk I took for not having my folder on the network drive.

Well, with a computer now gone, this meant I was back to working with Pratik at the same computer. It did mean we ended up talking a bit more, but like I said, with work being more stretched out until crunch time, it felt perfectly fine. We still got all of our work done with about two hours to spare. Usually I just use that extra time to check out the news or just pick a project to do to brush up on my skills. It’s one of the downsides at working in a Â broadcasting station for a news network. You can’t really just work on what’s coming up. The news isn’t planned so carefully because well, it’s the news. Something is always happening so we always need to be prepared to adjust and give what’s more interesting. Which is more than I can say for the non-stop political coverage of Donald Trump by other news shows.

Telling a New Tale

I will be arriving in Buenos Aires, Argentina in 10 (what!?!?) days! As I bid adieu to America, my last days pass by quicker than I can grapple with. My love for writing makes it clear to me that I should create a blog to embellish on my chronicles, Ahem, cronicÃ¡s, for my beloved family and friends (but mainly as personal reflection). Hence, hc-ronicas was born. Lucky for me, NYU is Tumblr-friendly (and impressively active), so I donâ€™t have to take a hiatus from my favorite social media in turn of starting a new blog so people can keep up with me.ğŸ˜

Whatâ€™s great about Tumblr is that it can be very interactive! I have my blog set up so that other users can ask questions, message me, and submit posts to me. So please feel free to contact me on here because I will be 100% airplane mode beginning the 24th of August- with the exception of some light Wifi use. Not all of us are #blessed with roaming data. Otherwise, Facebookâ€™s always cool and Iâ€™ll receive some iMessages from time to time.

Hasta luego!

Iâ€™ve been here for a whole month now, which is insane! Time feels like itâ€™s gone by both sooo fast and also so slow at the same time. I feel like iâ€™ve known people for such a long time, even though weâ€™ve only been together for a month. Everything is really getting into full gear now. I had a paper due last week, an exam this week and two papers due next week. Itâ€™s starting to pile up and I have to take a moment to look back at the past month and think about everything that I did:

Welcome week was absolutely packed. So much happened in such little time. I really got to know about the school and everything that is offered here. There are so many opportunities here, but never enough time to take advantage of all of them. My main extracurricular focus is working for Washington Square News, which staff applications are coming out for pretty soon - so cross your fingers for me!

My floor has gotten incredibly close. We hang out all the time, and Iâ€™m pretty sure that we know each other more than any other floor. Weâ€™ve gone out basically every weekend and explored around the area. We went to see the lunar eclipse at the Brooklyn Bridge together last weekend. I think that itâ€™s pretty great we have this community on our floor already. Itâ€™s hard to find some solid friends here at NYU, so having that built in community on our exploration floor is really such a relief. I know that even though I might not have a bunch of friends in all my classes, at least Iâ€™ll have my floor (which, the people on my floor are better than people in my classes to be honest, sorry).Â 

Letâ€™s see, what else has happened over this last month!? Well, I went to two fashion week shows! They were small but it was still a great experience and a fun way to start working for WSN. I went to Tia Cibani and Saga NYC. They were two very different but impressive shows in their own ways. Tia Cibani was this beautiful, very grounded presentation with light and festive designs that I could definitely see myself walking down the street in. Saga NYC was a great take on minimalism and monochromatism in an interactive presentation. I met some great people through it and hopefully it establishes who I am within the WSN community. Staff applications are live, so wish me luck there!

Technically Iâ€™ve been to four concerts now, but one of them was the Global Citizen Festival, which basically counts for like ten different concerts. Coldplay was there. Coldplay performed with Ariana Grande. Tori Kelly was there. Ed Sheeran was there. Ed Sheeran performed with Coldplay. Common performed. Common performed with Sting. BeyoncÃ© was there. Beyonce and Ed Sheeran sang Drunk in Love together and I think my heart burst. Pearl Jam performed. Beyonce and Eddie Vedder sang Redemption Song. I died a second time. It was probably the most exhausting but best day every. Hugh Jackman and Stephen Colbert hosted the event, Leo DiCaprio was there, Michelle Obama, Bill Nye, Malala, Salma Hayek, the Gatesâ€™, the Bidens, Big Bird, Bono, Queen Reina, Prime Ministers of many countries, UN members and soooo many other people. Best. Day. Ever

I also went to Walk the Moon with Saint Motel and was super close. That was such a great concert and I love the setting of a show in the park. Central Park is one of my favorite places on the island. The air is so fresh and the sunset was a beautiful backdrop for the start of the show. Both were incredible performers and it was a wonderful night.

The past couple nights I pulled a concert double header. I went to Stromae on Thursday. Heâ€™s amazing. He is so passionate about his music, heâ€™s a great dancer and performer and he brings so much heart to his shows. I love his music and itâ€™s so great to see him reach this incredible achievement of filling up Madison Square Garden. Friday night, I went to the Neighbourhood, Bad Suns and Honey. That was probably one of the most insane concerts Iâ€™ve ever been to. The mosh pit was aggressive and kept swaying and I now know what it is like to be a sardine in a can. The Neighbourhood was soooo good live. Jesse pointed at me during the show, and I also nabbed a set list - I was a happy sardine.

Thereâ€™s so much to come soon. I have to go into WSN to work on layout a bit and I have two papers due next week. Everyone is in the midst of midterms, so we canâ€™t wait to get them over with and celebrate. Weâ€™ve got a lot of floor birthdays coming up, so this is going to be a lot of fun!

More adventures on the way!

His name is BLAINE ANDERSON. He is 18 years old, and originally from BURLINGTON, VERMONT. Heâ€™s currently a freshman at NYU, and has been paired with _____ for the project.

He is currently a TAKEN CHARACTER.

  • Born as one of two, Blaine Anderson came into the world as a wide eyed, fresh young face, ready to take on the world and all it offered. Or, so he thought, anyways. A young and ambitious child, Blaine considered himself the more driven of his brothers, and as soon as he was able to walk and talk, he put this ambition into overdrive immediately. Blaine was soon singing and dancing all around the house, enjoying a duet with his older brother, Cooper, on more than on occasion. His parents, Sophia and Bruce, were happy beyond all belief to see their children getting along â€” after all, three boys can be quite a handle full, but Blaine didnâ€™t seem to mind. If he was with his family, then he was happy.
  • Being raised in a loving household also helped Blaine believe that his dreams could come true. His mother, Sophia, was born and raised in Sorrento, Italy and she was a main proponent in Blaineâ€™s confidence, and enthusiasm. His father, Bruce, was a suit and tie business man, though his demeanor was hardly serious. In fact, if anything, his father was the biggest goofball in the house. And when youâ€™re living under the same roof as Cooper Anderson, thatâ€™s a hard title to beat. With his love of all things Christmas (right down to matching family Christmas sweaters) and off kilter sense of comedy, he and Blaine struck up a close relationship from a young age. Knowing that he had two people to rely on at all times was more than most kids his age could say, and Blaine never took his easy going connection with either one of them for granted.
  • As Blaine aged, though, he started to notice differences about himself. While the other boys in middle school were focusing on girls, and how pretty they all seemed to look, Blaine couldnâ€™t be bothered. Sure, girls were beautiful, and he could admire them from a distance, but he didnâ€™t feel the need to kiss them, like his friends talked about. In fact, the more he let himself think about it, the more he realized that kissing his friends was more appealing. Boys were.. different, and Blaine admired the way their waists tapered down, and the way their muscles contracted and shifted under their skin. It was confusing, to say the least, and so, as any young boy would, he took to the internet. And, immediately, the internet gave back. Having something to call himself â€“ gay â€“ was settling, and Blaine felt the pressures of what other people say float off his shoulders with every passing day. At this age, he was still naive enough to think that maybe â€“ just maybe â€“ it wouldnâ€™t matter. No one had said anything about it to him, anyways, and Blaineâ€™s happy-go-lucky personality was a hard thing to target. He officially came out right before high school, during the winter of eighth grade. And while the initial reaction was pretty standard â€“ his parents were ever supportive of whatever he wanted to do with his life, and whoever he wanted to love â€“ the small bouts of hate began to rear their ugly heads.
  • The end of the year brought a Sadie Hawkins dance for the upperclassmen to celebrate their achievements, and Blaine â€“ being who he was â€“ invited along his friend, Lucas. The two had known each other for years, and Lucas was the only other out person at their school. Going together to show their support just made sense in Blaineâ€™s mind, and once they were at the dance, Blaine discovered that his fleeting moments of worry were for nothing. It wasnâ€™t until after the dance, when Blaine and his friend were waiting for their ride to take them home, that his fears became a reality. A hostile group of boys from the high school attacked them both, leaving Blaine and Lucas helpless on the concrete. Immediately, both were taken to the hospital, and after a few months of physical therapy, Blaine was pulled from public school and, instead, enlisted at a private boys boarding school, just an hour outside of their hometown. The isolation was hard, but the no bullying policy was unwavering, and Blaine found himself settling into his new atmosphere (and his new uniform) within the first couple of months. As a freshman, he didnâ€™t try to approach any of the clubs on campus â€“ he needed to keep his grades up in order to remain enrolled in the school, after all â€“ but the competitive show choir caught his eye immediately. That passion he had for performing when he was little never diminished, and though his work with local community theaters had been stunted, due to his accident, his love of the arts certainly remained. As a sophomore, Blaine developed the courage to audition, and upon acceptance, finally fell into a group of people he could rely on, and people he felt he could relate to. His junior year, Blaine was put on the council, and during his time in an administrative position, Blaine led his team to two back to back National championships.
  • College was lurking around the corner, and Blaineâ€™s eyes were easily on the best city to be in for people like him â€“ New York. NYADA was his first choice, but his time spent off the stage due to his incident cost him a fair chance. So, instead, Blaine found himself at NYU: Tisch, a great alternative for people in the arts. There, heâ€™s a theater major with a minor in music, and with his passion to succeed and his unwavering spirit, Blaine is sure that heâ€™ll be able to make it to the top one day. He, of course, misses his brother, but he knows how strong Austin is after what he went through, and heâ€™s positive that theyâ€™ll find a way to meet up again in the future, given their natural pull towards a career in music.

CHARACTER AESTHETIC

Blaineâ€™s style could easily be described as â€˜preppy chicâ€™. Growing up in a household that wasnâ€™t exactly strapped for money meant that Blaine could splurge a little on his back to school clothing hauls. He prefers the tight fit of slacks over jeans, though heâ€™s not against denim in the slightest. He often wears collared shirts, too â€“ sleeve length doesnâ€™t matter. Layering is also something Blaineâ€™s known to do â€“ in the colder months (or even the warmer months), Blaine tends to pair a polo shirt with a matching sweater vest. During the winter, thicker sweaters tend to be Blaineâ€™s favorite, and though he wonâ€™t admit that he likes labels, Blaineâ€™s top two choices for clothing stores are Brooks Brothers, and the GAP. His most notable feature is his bowtie â€“ Blaineâ€™s collection is expansive, and maybe borderline out of control. He wears one with every ensemble he pulls together, however, and he tends to match the patterns and colors with as much style as he can. His shoes are almost always Oxfords, though the warmer months tend to put Blaine in boat shoes â€“ something he got accustomed to at a young age through the various country club visits he took with his Dad back in Vermont. Heâ€™s also got his Dadâ€™s old watch on his left wrist at all times.

Physically, Blaine is easy to pick out among a crowd. Heâ€™s shorter than most males, standing at five feet, eight inches tall. His hair â€“ while curly in itâ€™s natural state â€“ is always slicked back with a thick sheen of hair gel. When theyâ€™re left unattended to, Blaine swears he can turn people to stone with just a single look. Itâ€™s not very often that Blaine lets anyone see him in such a state. Due to his Italian roots on his motherâ€™s side, Blaineâ€™s skin is also easy to tan and color during the summer.

His name is SEBASTIAN ANT'ONY SMYTHE. He is 18 years old, and originally from DENVER, COLORADO. Heâ€™s currently a freshman at NYU, and has been paired with Kennedy Fabray for the project.

He is currently a TAKEN CHARACTER.

  • Sebastian Smythe, and his twin, were born in Paris, France to Xavier and Adelaide Smythe. Their birth was rejoiced, though the novelty quickly wore off and, within weeks, Adelaide was back to her social functions while Xavier immersed himself in his work. Being a lawyer, his services were always in need and his lovely wife was more than willing to reap the benefits, such as top of the line nannies that worked around the clock to provide her children with excellent care. They had a need for nothing as they were given anything that they could possibly dream of having, even as infants.
  • At the tender age of 6, Sebastianâ€™s life was changed. The Smythe family uprooted and made the move to the states where Xavierâ€™s spectacular skill sets were in much need. With the amount of money they were throwing at the Smythes, how could he think of saying no? Some would say that this was the start of Sebastianâ€™s entitled â€“ and somewhat petulant â€“ behavior. Things changed almost drastically. From lavish parties and the city of love just beyond their doorstep to Denver, Colorado â€“ middle America where they had no choice but to start over with no friends or family to assist them. Although money was abundant, their nannies were far more strict, and deemed him undeserving of the treats he demanded, frequently putting up a great fuss until, inevitably, the nanny had no choice but to give him his much desired treat. Rather than discourage his behavior, it was Xavier that encouraged Sebastian to fight for what he wanted and to never take no for an answer. He wouldnâ€™t know the impact that this lesson would have on Sebastian in later years.
  • No one could deny that Sebastian had a charismatic nature that drew people towards him and am innate ability to talk himself in (and out) of any situation. It was the one thing that made him so popular in school. Whether you loved him or hated him, you simply couldnâ€™t stay away, and Sebastian reveled in all of the attention. Why shouldnâ€™t he? After all, he fought for his social standing in school â€“ with his straight Aâ€™s and ability to stand up to any who dared to see him as weak. And though he had money, it was something that he knew not to take for granted. His father taught him better than that. He could learn to survive without it, though he couldnâ€™t deny himself the pleasure of indulging his own whims and spoiling himself as only a Smythe knew how.
  • Sebastianâ€™s future had been planned out from the moment that he discovered his love of debate. There were no questions about what it was that heâ€™d like to do when he could follow tradition. Sebastian was expected to follow in his fatherâ€™s footsteps and he was fine with that. He looked up to Xavier and was more than pleased to one day be as respected and beloved as his father was among his friends and colleagues. All it took was one day, one moment, for Sebastian to begin questioning it all. â€“ Sebastianâ€™s sexuality had never been a topic of conversation among the Smythe family. There was no need with Sebastian showing up to events and parties with pretty girls hanging off his arm. Yet there was a part of himself that he was hiding. One which was discovered when his father walked in to find him in a half-dressed state with another boy. The conflicts that would arise from that moment would cause a sense of uncertainty to rise within Sebastian. Was his father really the type of man that he wanted to emulate when he was so quick to turn his back on his own child when faced with Sebastianâ€™s bisexuality; just because it was something he didnâ€™t entirely understand or accept?
  • It all came to a head when graduation neared and Xavier could no longer keep quiet his views of his sonâ€™s behavior. An ultimatum was made: if Sebastian were to forget about his little â€˜experimentâ€™ with other boys and no longer shame the Smythe name with his â€˜despicableâ€™ acts then Xavier would continue to fund not only Sebastianâ€™s schooling, but would provide him with a hefty sum to keep him, and his future family comfortable. If not then Sebastian could consider himself cut off and disowned. Xavier would â€œnot tolerate a son who chooses to be gay.â€ It didnâ€™t take Sebastian long to make a decision. Xavier taught him to stand up for himself and thatâ€™s what he decided to do when he turned down his fatherâ€™s money and chose to go to NYU, a city far from home where he could live his life, and find his true calling, whatever it may be. With the help of his mother, he found a way to pay his tuition, though Adelaide could hardly afford to anger her husband further by providing Sebastian with little more than some spare cash for books, leaving him in desperate need of money by the time classes were well underway.
  • The experiment was not something that Sebastian would have considered, under normal circumstances. He had no desire to involve himself with any one person in particular, especially one who would not be within a short driving distance. Yet it was the money, above all else, that made it difficult for him to say no. Itâ€™s no secret that he thinks that thereâ€™s no such thing as a soulmate but heâ€™d rather grin and bare it than have to spend his time working meaningless jobs, surrounded by incompetency and stupidity for some extra cash.

CHARACTER AESTHETIC

Standing at 6 foot, Sebastian has short, brown hair, with a classic gelled upward style, and hazel-blue eyes, which can appear a light shade of green in the right setting. He has a preference for fashion over comfort, often choosing slacks over casual denim, although he isnâ€™t opposed to dressing down. Due to his desire to be successful like his father, likely in the law field, he has avoided any body modifications such as piercings and tattoos, as it is typically frowned upon.
