NYU Global Spiritual Life has created numerous programs to promote informed dialogue about religion on campus and beyond.Â Faith Zone is one of the many programs that allow students to learn how to facilitate honest dialogue about religion and spirituality. At the end of the Faith Zone Training, every participant leaves feeling as though they can make a difference in their own community using the things they learned. Here are our Top Ten Tips for Multifaith Work that we recommend every student uses when taking their Faith Zone Training to the real world.Â 

1. Check out our Principles of Multifaith Engagement:

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  i.Reflect diversity, accounting for the complex and intersectional identities of our constituents.

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  ii. Rooted in fact-to-face encounters and deep relationship-building within and between communities and/or individuals.

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  iii. Committed to social transformation and civic engagement (i.e. multifaith issue-based solutions to social problems such as poverty, prison industrial complex, human trafficking).

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  iv. Focused on introspection and meaning-making as a way of understanding spirituality.

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  v. Inclusive of and attentive to personal narratives through intentional storytelling pedagogy, not just representative of religious creed.

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  vi. Supportive of Integration of the whole student experience throughout their academic and co-curricular development.

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  vii. Supportive of coursework that promotes multifaith leadership.

2. Create a safe space that encourages dialogue. Approach every conversation with a co-learner orientation.

3. Ask people about their personal practices. Not all people within a religious or spiritual community practice in the same way.

4. Donâ€™t be afraid of making mistakes. Let those around you know that they can voice a concern if something you say offends them.

5. Whenever possible, organizers should reflect the diversity of those who will be participating in a particular event.

6. Events should be easily accessible and comfortable for all potential participants. Some things to consider:

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  i. Religious Holidays (available on Google Calendar)

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  ii. Prayer times

7. At an event itself, ensure that the structure of the event is inclusive. Some things to consider:

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  i. Dietary needs such as Kosher, Halal, vegetarian, vegan etc.

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  ii. Physical contact between genders

8. Create an environment where people feel safe making requests for religious and spiritual observance or practice. Make it clear that there will not be ramifications for making that request.

9. Use inclusive language to welcome students who do not identify with a particular faith tradition or identify as atheist or agnostic.

10. Seek help or advice from Chaplains and GSL.

If you have any questions, please contact Ariel Ennis at ariel.ennis@nyu.edu.

Over the following week, as part of the first #NYULeadershipWeek, we will be featuring NYU students and alumni as they reflect on leadership: Â Â 

Helping others near and far through acts small and large can often create ripples much greater than expected. Raniah El-Gendi, an MPA candidate, is focused on improving international development efforts with an emphasis on social advocacy and international community organizing all the while being reflective and mindful of our shared humanity.

How do you define leadership?Â 

I view leadership as the ability to empower others. It is the skill of knowing how to bring out the best in others and motivating many to work towards a communal goal. For me, leadership isÂ about coordination: piecing together the different components and talents available so that theÂ sum is greater than its parts. Great leaders, in my view, are those individuals with the ability toÂ admit their vulnerabilities and learn from those surrounding them to strengthen their ownÂ narratives as well as that of all those around them. It is the characteristic of a person whoÂ constantly takes on multiple perspectives and is able to use them accordingly.

Â What has been your biggest leadership failure? And what did you learn?

Two failures in particular come to mind. One was when I was a good deal younger and wasÂ responsible for managing individuals much older than myself. Being so young, at the time IÂ didnâ€™t realize the importance of setting a proper tone for the work environment and of theÂ nuances involved in coworker relations. Now, I handle the same challenge by approaching eachÂ situation uniquely and with humility. What I view as the more important failure however, is theÂ instance of having individuals being left behind who I wasnâ€™t able to reach out to or connect with on an individual level. For example, if I see someone who after a program or meeting is sitting alone and didnâ€™t contribute, or wasnâ€™t integrated into the larger group interaction or conversation, that for me is a leadership failure. It means that I wasnâ€™t able to create an environment that was as Â inclusive as it needed to be. That teaches me to think about the people on the fringes; how can I be mindful of, and attract those individuals?

Â What is one word or idea that you seek to redefine by the end of your career?

Â If I can work towards redefining peopleâ€™s understandings of a single concept it would be that ofÂ â€œshared humanity.â€ Once in college Â a highly educated peer who was serving the country in the armed forces responded to a debate we were engaged in regarding national responsibility to respond to overseas refugee crises, an issue even more relevant today. He stated something along the lines of â€œitâ€™s not our problem, why should we be sucked into their mess?â€ That was devastating for me. I didnâ€™t Â think that young man was Â a bad individual but so many people today would agree with his stance. If I could just impart onto others this notion that we are tied to one another no matter what small corner of the globe we may find ourselves in, we are tied to each other by virtue of our humanity. When we understand how powerless we actually are in determining what circumstance weâ€™re born into, it becomes clear that to value your life over anotherâ€™s by virtue of living in a place that is better off or having access to certain resources, that is the worst type of arrogance possible. And if we canâ€™t care for one another by simple virtue of our shared humanity, then really, what are we trying to accomplish in life?

Please describe a defining moment in your life that has shaped your values.

I believe the defining moment in my life was losing my father after my high school graduation. Sometimes it takes a life-changing event to make you ask yourself tough questionsÂ about who it is you actually are? What type of person do you want to be and what will it takeÂ for you to get there? Unfortunately, our culture in the U.S., and in New York in particular is notÂ necessarily always conducive to self-reflection and mindful meditation and so I find that oftenÂ we rush through life without challenging our own beliefs and practices and getting to theÂ core of why we do what we do. I think constant self-reflection is something we need toÂ encourage more, especially among young adults and adolescents.

Â For me personally, when I had to face the hard reality of overcoming tragedy as I began college,Â I realized that at some point I had to live my life according to what I believed in. Thereâ€™s no useÂ in having philosophies and moral judgments if youâ€™re not going to stand by them with yourÂ actions. This has greatly shaped how I interact with others to this day and my efforts to leadÂ genuinely, with integrity.

Of all the freshmen stereotypes, there is one that shines brighter than the infamous lanyard: not exploring the city beyond 14th Street. We get it â€” Union Square can be hectic and overwhelming, but that doesnâ€™t speak for the rest of the City!


1. Shop at the Union Square Greenmarket

Abundance! #UnionSquareNY #UnionSquare #EatLocal #ShopLocal

A photo posted by Union Square, New York City (@unionsquareny) on Jun 18, 2014 at 7:36am PDT

Sure, it might be on 14th Street, but itâ€™s still technically above it! Every Monday, year round, shop for fresh fruit, vegetables, and other artisanal products from the Tri-State area. Once autumn comes rolling in, itâ€™s a great place to pick up pies, pumpkins, and apple cider, too!


2. Visit the Frick Collection

A must-see, the Frick is home to some of the finest 18th century art, including works of Vermeer, Rembrandt, Fragonard, and many other great classics.


3. Window-shop up Fifth Avenue

A photo posted by larissyd (@larissyd) on Sep 29, 2015 at 3:20pm PDT

From affordable prices to high-end fashion, Fifth Ave. hosts a selection of the most influential brands and designers in the world, making it one of the most recognizable streets in New York and in the world.


4. People-watch at Grand Central

When people think of New York City, Grand Central is one of the first things that comes to mind. As a hub of the Tri-State area, 750,000 people pass through it daily â€” a great spot for people watching (as long a youâ€™re not in their way)! Plus, thereâ€™s a Shake Shack in the Dining Concourse…


5. Study at the New York Public Library

A photo posted by The New York Public Library (@nypl) on May 30, 2014 at 4:44am PDT

It doesnâ€™t get better than this! Take a break from Bobst and study in one of the most incredible rooms in the city.


6. Row a boat in Central Park

Whether it be with someone ~special~ or with friends, itâ€™s a fun little adventure in the heart of Central Park, with mesmerizing views of the surrounding skyline. Itâ€™s hard not to fall in love with this City with that view…


7. Relax in Sheep Meadow

Ok, we love Central Park so we’re going to list it twice. Rent a bike at 59th Street and venture into the park. Take a book and read on the vast lawn, or get a little lost for fun. SO MANY OPTIONS.


8. Visit the Cloisters

A photo posted by The Metropolitan Museum of Art (@metmuseum) on Jul 26, 2015 at 8:41am PDT

Set in Fort Tryon overlooking the Hudson, the Cloisters re-creates the French monasteries of the 15th century, and houses the Metâ€™s medieval art and architecture collections. A wonderful getaway from the City, in the City.


9. Go ice skating at Rockefeller Center

Itâ€™s not a New York winter if you havenâ€™t visited the decked-out Rockefeller Center. Whether youâ€™re an amateur or an advanced skater, thereâ€™s nothing more fun than gliding away with friends before getting a cup of hot chocolate.


10. Tour NYU’s old campus in the Bronx

A photo posted by HashtagNYU (@hashtagnyu) on Apr 26, 2014 at 10:21am PDT

NYU has a fascinating history at University Heights, which is now home to Bronx Community College. Walk through the Hall of Fame and imagine what it would be like if NYU had a football team… A bit of a trip, but so worth it!


11. Explore Spanish dining in Spanish Harlem

Te gusta la comida? From the hundreds of taco joints and food carts to upscale tapas bars, the neighborhood offers a wide variety of super delicious Spanish cuisine.


12. Rush Broadway

A photo posted by An American In Paris Broadway (@americaninparis) on Aug 8, 2015 at 7:27pm PDT

Because thereâ€™s nothing more rewarding than the thrill of getting front row seats to THE musical of the moment at a great price. Plus, they are sometimes in the front row! NYU’s Ticket Central can also help out with this one.


13. Go on an adventure at the Bronx Zoo

The Bronx Zoo is the largest urban zoo in the world, and is home to over 4,000 animals. Spend the afternoon there to see animals from all corners of the Earth! What a better way to spend the day?


14. Â Watch the sun set from the Top of the Rock

A photo posted by Rockefeller Center (@rockcenternyc) on Apr 7, 2015 at 10:54am PDT

A classic, breathtaking view of the city. Youâ€™d totally be able to see Bobst, if that pesky Empire State Building werenâ€™t in the way!Â

Over the following weeks, as part of the first #NYULeadershipWeek, we will be featuring NYU students and alumni as they reflect on leadership: Â 

Pamela Campos-Palma is an MPA candidate at NYU Wagner who is passionate about empowering under-represented communities. She has an extensive background and record in governance, higher education, and community and political organizing.

How do you define leadership?

Early on, my time in the military and other challenging environments taught me what leadership is not: leadership is not individualistic, itâ€™s not about prestige, power, or managing things or people merely to check boxes. Leadership to me is the living, holistic embodiment of values centered on inspiring others to be their best selves for positive influence and impact. In this vein, leadership to me is about community, integrity, respect.

What has been your biggest leadership failure? And what did you learn?

I find the paradox of leadership fascinating–something so often glorified and put on a pedestal, yet leadership is often a messy, challenging, isolating place to live. Many of the best leaders I know are ones whoâ€™ve known hardship, thus their fearlessness to jump in no matter the challenge, often leading the way out of passion for people, communities, or larger-than-life issues. My whole life Iâ€™ve been praised for â€œworking under pressure, working well in stressâ€ and certainly itâ€™s a honed skill I know I have due to my life experiences. However, my biggest leadership failure has been not asking for help and not having boundaries between my work, and my self care. This continues to be a working challenge for me given my service-minded, community-driven style of leadership. More and more Iâ€™ve learned the glorification of productivity and pressure can result in a distorted assumption that leaders should be working under constant duress or else they arenâ€™t truly committed to their cause, community, or Â team. Iâ€™ve learned that if I donâ€™t take care of myself, I canâ€™t be my best self, and I canâ€™t ask others to be theirs.

What is one word or idea that you seek to redefine by the end of your career?

An idea I seek to redefine has to do with dissent, differing opinions, and being okay with not being 100% right. In a time of great advancements we are still very much stagnant, even regressing, when it comes to our potential as a society. I attribute much of this to general, strengthening sentiment of individuals needing to never be wrong or vulnerability seen as a weakness. Many things in our lives are starkly polarized–yes or no, black or white. Yet the shining lights of opportunity and solution are often in the grey, in differing sides being open to new perspectives and ideas and finding middle ground of better understanding. Too often stepping outside the status quo box is punishable, ridiculed, chastised. We are tremendously more than capable of unlearning things weâ€™ve thought to be whole truths, to be vulnerable, to get uncomfortable if it means coming out stronger, wiser, more interconnected. Boxes of linear thinking keep us caged, ignorant, and limited to our true collective potential.

Please describe a defining moment in your life that has shaped your values.

Growing up I spent a lot of time with my mother, a single parent who immigrated to the U.S. from Honduras. In Honduras she was discovered as a prodigal basketball player, a life she left behind to give me opportunity and a better life. As a child I saw her face many challenges, language, and culture barriers. Yet despite having few means ourselves, my mother would always, without hesitation, go out of her way to help people. From speaking with the cleaning staff at the mall in Spanish, to staying with a man who had a seizure at a bus stop until the ambulance came. She was always reaching out to strangers in kindness without expecting anything back. I once asked her why she felt she had to do this. In her ever-convicted voice she reminded me that people are people, just like us, no matter if it’s the President of the United States, or someone without a home. She subconsciously taught me to act with compassion no matter my own circumstances, to respect others no matter their lot in life, and the impacts we can make if we step outside our comfort zones. She inspired the leader I am today.

Winter is coming and no one knows that better than NYU students, of course. That being said, weâ€™ve got to cherish all the crisp fall days we have left. Soon it will be nothing but below 30-degree weather and a noticeable lack of snow days. But for now, weâ€™re only just approaching orange leaves and the faint whisper of Halloween-costume planning. What better way to spend the last days of warmth than with a little adventure? Before all outings require five layers, jump into some of these great activities…


Take a river cruise

Itâ€™s totally clichÃ© but seeing the Statue of Liberty really is a magical sight, especially when youâ€™re admiring Lady Liberty from the side of a boat. As soon as the temperature drops, you wonâ€™t want to deal with the wind chill. Plus if you take a cruise now, and you can stock up on some beautiful landscapes to post for those â€œtake me backâ€ TBTs in January.


Go to Smorgasburg

This one will still be here in the winter but it will relocate to a brand new, less picturesque indoor space once it starts getting cold. The outdoor Smorgasburg closes in late fall, so get there while you can! Where else will you get your ramen burger, Belgian fries, and plethora of delicious desserts all in one place? Your stomach will thank you.


Sit in the Park

Yes, our beloved â€œWaSquaPaâ€ will still be there in the winter, but it wonâ€™t be as beautiful as the warm, packed park you can enjoy right now. Soon enough, the fountain will be off and the trees will be bare. Donâ€™t get us wrong, the sight of the arch will bring any NYU student to tears no matter the season, but it will just be better to view from inside Kimmel once it really gets cold.


Visit Coney Island

Games, rides, food, and the opportunity to fulfill your secret dream of recreating the spinning teacup scene from Uptown Girls. Itâ€™s a win-win-win-win. However, Coney Island is an activity that isnâ€™t the same during winter hibernation, so be sure to make this trip soon.


Walk the High Line

Itâ€™s way easier to lazily stroll down the High Line when you donâ€™t have to power walk to keep your body temp up. Take advantage of the warmth and check out the beautiful greenery, great views, and perfect backgrounds for your next profile picture.


Picnic in a park

Your mind may have automatically assumed Central Park, but there are so many more parks to choose from! Head over to Brooklyn and spend the day in Prospect Park or venture to Queens and relax your afternoon away in Flushing Meadows. So many options, so little time!


Gaze into the distance on a rooftop

While some cities are built outwards, Manhattan was built upwards. This means there are a lot of amazing NYC rooftops with breathtaking views. You and your squad could easily spend a few hours on the MET rooftop looking over Central Park. You could even take a yoga class, catch a film, or mini golf â€” all on a rooftop! Definitely do this before all roofs are mostly covered in snow…

Everything is pretty much within a 5 minute radius of the Washington Square area. Tisch may haves lectures or classes held in Cantor, I’m not sure, but that’s only like 4 blocks away from the WS area at most. The only other places I could think of that classes are held are on Mercer Street and 12th St (about a 15 minute walk I’d say from Washington Sq), but classes held there are usually things like MAP courses (science, math, Writing the Essay) and I’m not sure if as a Tisch student you’d have to take those. If you do, they probably hold them closer.

As far as dorms, closest to “campus” in order would be Goddard, Weinstein, Hayden, Brittany, Rubin, Founders, and Third North.

Goddard isÂ onÂ Washington Square Park, so you’d literally be able to roll out of bed 10 minutes before class and get there on time. However, it’s a Residence College so you’d have to do a separate application for it. Basically do service projects and events with the residents in the building I believe.

Weinstein isn’t on WSP, but it’s so close, it might as well be. About a 5 minute walk to classes, just like Goddard.

Hayden is a little bit farther but not by much, maybe 5 minutes extra. It’s on the opposite side of WSP.

Brittany is on 9th street so it’s about 5/6 blocks away, but I don’t think it’s open for Freshman next semester due to renovations.

Rubin is on 10th St I believe. There’s no A/C so I wouldn’t recommend it.

Founders and Third North are on 12th St, being the farthest dorms. Founders has the big rooms, Third North being apartment-style has the kitchens. About a 15-20 minute walk to class, depending on how fast you walk.Â 

If you’re just concerned about distance, I’d stick with Goddard/Weinstein or Hayden. They each have something to offer. I linked each of them with their NYU page that gives a list of their features and services, in case you wanna know more about them.
